description:
We found a new "favorite place" to dine !!!
Funny to think it is so close to our home  & it took so long. We checked it out when we went on a "bistro kick" after we read an article in the SF Chronicle all about our bistros in our town & we made the rounds & Baker Street got top billing in our book .  The staff is professional & caring &
I observe how the guests are treated & seated & find it a pleasure to watch  The food is wonderful and classic French . Not that I am a pro but we know what we like & we keep going back for more & have brought our family & friends!
The dishes are big enough to share as "we can not eat like we used to...say hi to Chantelle, she is a wonderful aspect of a special dining experience!
& do not miss the "sautéed strawberries  with vanilla bean ice cream .....it is a fantastic surprise to end your meal!!! 
Phyllis & Roger
author: Phyllis S.

description:
I've been to this place a handful of times. It's owned and ran by true Frenchies and it's a fun authentic bistro vibe. I've never had an issue with my food. Eggs are always perfectly cooked and the pain Perdu was great. Coffee is excellent too. 
I will say that the space could use some sprucing up. The decor is a little cheesy and outdated and the tables and menus could use a wipe down. 
The service, menu, and wine is what gives this place 5 stars. I will be back :)
author: Nicole K.

description:
Baker Street Bistro is a small, medium-high cost, sit-down French restaurant on the west side of the Marina neighborhood that serves French classics in a uniquely decorated, homey environment.

The restaurant is very cute with lots of decorations everywhere, warm tones, and soft seating. 

I first came here with a small group for their exceptionally priced prix fixe menu which was originally $20 (now $25 as of Aug 2018) for a soup of the day +  plate of the day + mixed greens + dessert of the day. Because of its great deal, it's only offered Tuesday-Thursday and Sunday nights. Sadly we were told that they only served a limited number of them and could only offer us 1 prix fixe course for our group of 6 which disappointed us. 

We had the boeuf bourguignon ($30, beef stewed in red wine w/ veggies), the cassoulet Toulousain ($32, beans, tomatoes, sausage, and a duck leg), the Bourride Provencale ($25, seafood stew), and a prix fixe course here and while nothing was "bad", everything besides the prix fixe felt like a poor value.The portions weren't large, nothing seemed very labor intensive nor were the ingredients particularly special. In addition our server forgot an item on our order and it took longer than expected to have that item removed from our bill.

Conclusions: I would highly recommend Baker Street Bistro for their neighborhood prix fixe menu but otherwise I would advise spending just a bit extra to go to a high-brow establishment like Jardiniere in Hayes Valley or saving money and going to Chez Maman in Potrero.
author: Andrew H.

description:
My parents travel a lot. They were finally back in the Bay and wanted to have dinner with me and the roommate. Knowing their love of old school French food, I picked Baker Street Bistro. I made a reservation for four about a half week prior for Tuesday, May 1st at 6:30pm.

Neighborhood Prix Fixe ($25) x2
*Soup of the day, plate of the day, mixed greens, dessert of the day
*No substitutions & no sharing for the prix fixe
*Available Sunday through Thursday evenings from 5:30pm until sold out
*No Prix Fixe on Fridays and Saturdays

Both of my parents got the prix fixe. That day, the soup was clam chowder, the plate was pork, and the dessert was chocolate mousse. The soup was good. Not too thick and with a good amount of clams. (I'm more of a brothy soup girl.) The dessert was also tasty. A nice rich chocolate mousse. And I always need greens, so the salad fulfilled that craving. The plate of the day was the most disappointing. Came with mashed potatoes and a white sauce, but the meat was dry and overcooked. You definitely needed a lot of the sauce to counteract the rubbery texture of the meat.

*Assiette Charcutière: Pâté de campagne, dry saucisson, smoked duck breast, garlic sausage, cornichons & onions ($18.50)
*Escargot Bourguignon: Snails (1/2 dozen) in garlic & parsley butter sauce ($12.50)
*Foie-Frais de canard poele aux pommes et aux raisins: Fresh pan-seared foie-gras ($22)
*Steak Grillé, Beurre Maître d'Hôtel, Pomme Frites: Grilled New York Steak, Maître D' Butter, French fries & mixed green salad ($30)
*Coquilles St-Jacques Sauteés, Purée de Brocolis & Courgettes Sautees: Pan-seared wild sea-scallops, red pepper coulis, sauteed zucchini, broccoli puree ($30)
*Sparkling Brut, J. Roget ($12 glass)
*2013 Châteauneuf-du-Pape, Domaine Juliette Avril, Rhone Valley ($60)
*Coffee ($3)

First off, the foie was fantastic. A great portion for the price. I ate a fair amount and even dipped the bread in the tasty foie oil. Mmmmm, meat butter. I really enjoyed the roommate's scallops. Such great flavor as they used Hokkaido scallops. My steak was cooked nicely (in between rare and medium rare), but the meat itself didn't have much flavor. I did enjoy the fries with ketchup and mayo though. Fried nicely so crispy. The snails were okay. Not much flavor, so we had to add a fair amount of salt. I wish the butter had more garlic and parsley. Would have made the dish better.

Cute neighborhood french bistro. I'd definitely come back for that foie. And at $25, the neighborhood menu is such a great deal. Tasty and affordable.
author: Elena N.

description: We were a party of 8 last Saturday night.  We had a wonderful meal and excellent service. We chose this restaurant because we could walk to the Palace of Fine Arts from here, but it was very good and we would definitely go back again. Thank you Doriane for taking such good care of us!
author: Sassy M.

description: Everything is so delicious, I had the croque madame and it's probably the best I've had. The cheese on top of the bread tasted so creamy. Everything taste so yummy, including the 2 dessert (cream puff, peach tart) that we had. I will for sure come back again next time I visit SF.
author: Tina K.

description: This brunch stop is going to be hard to top. The food was amazing and everyone was super nice. Could be my new weekly place.
author: Katie B.

description:
How is it this place has 4 stars, it seems all of the accurate reviews for some reason didn't make it the Yelp cut and they're hidden.  Although service was fine the food left a lot to be desired.  I ordered salmon tartare, onion soup, and beef stew all less than ok.  Soup and stew were served barely warm.  Also portion size on stew incredibly small (turns out that was not a big problem as it was not interesting or delicious enough to eat) 
Salmon was over dressed with herbs.  Thought a restaurant at this location would be better because possibly they catered to the local Pac. Heights/Predsidio neighborhoods, not so it turns out.  Cute space but the food is not worth your time or money.
author: M M.

description:
A great weekend brunch spot!

I came in on a Sunday at about 11:30am and I was very pleasantly surprised to find the place half empty. I was seated immediately and service was quick. I had a mocha, which was tasty and chocolatey, and the Eggs Copenhagen (i.e., salmon benedict). The benedict was quite good, the eggs were perfectly poached, the English muffin was fluffy, and the Hollandaise sauce was gooey and flavorful. The salmon was great, but I would have liked a bit more of it. The side greens were OK and the breakfast potatoes just tasted like rosemary, which wasn't good.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Came for Easter dinner without reservations. We were given the option of outside seating which we didn't mind since they had heating.  Service was friendly and food decent.  The last time we had French was terrible so this was nice change. 

Steak & frites ($30) was a too salty for me.  I'm not sure if it was the steak or the maitre d'butter and usual salad is overly dressed.  I keep forgetting to get dressing on the side. 

Scallops were sweet and perfect  but light ($30) I'd still be hungry if that was all I ordered.  Escargot ($12)was nothing to write home about. Loads of butter and also a little too salty.  

Neighborhood prix fixe seems like a deal and brunch menu looks good. Will have to give them another try. Feels like a loved neighborhood place.
author: Naty D.

description: Loved this little place! Owner and wait staff were very friendly and accommodating. We enjoyed talking with them and even joked around a bit. The food was delicious and the service was great. We sat outside for quite some time after our meal and did not feel rushed at all. We live n Vacaville, which is about 90 minutes away, but would come back in a heart beat!!!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Had a great time having dinner here on a Friday. There weren't too many people which is great for Friday night! The atmosphere is very cozy and cute, very French; tables are super close to each other that you have to pull your own table out to get in/out. As a result, you see some tables starting to have conversation with their neighbors, which is very pleasant :) 

For the two of us, we shared:
- half a dozen oysters: very fresh
- tomato soup: simple and tasty
- Risotto de Légumes: veggie risotto that is very homey 
- Moules Provençale: mussels with fries, a bit too buttery on the sauce, but tasty!

Overall, the food is good quality, delicious, and satisfying. Service is very friendly. I would recommend this to anyone that's looking for something low-key, pleasant but delicious meal.

The Presidio was only 2 blocks away, so it was also a great perk to take a walk after dinner! Great option for a first date (even though it wasn't ours)  ;)
author: Wendy K.

description:
A cute and cozy weekend breakfast/brunch spot. The highlights: They have the friendliest and most attentive staff, comfortable atmosphere, not overly crowded like many SF brunch spots and delicious food.  

I ordered the Croque Madame and it was extremely filling, could have been a plate to share. 

Lots of outdoor seating if it is a sunny day in the city.
author: Morgan W.

description:
We came here as part of an off-site for work. Since they technically close at 2:30pm, but we had to take a late lunch due to the earlier part of our off-site event, we made a reservation for 2pm for 14 people and sent in our orders ahead of time. We ran even later than anticipated due to technical errors where we were earlier, but the staff was still amazing and super friendly. Here's the breakdown:

Ambiance: Cute, quaint restaurant. No frills, but has that authentic mom and pop vibe where you know the food is going to be amazing.

Food: Even though we sent in our orders ahead of time, they didn't prep anything until we got there and they confirmed our orders. As an appetizer, we ordered a plate of Escargots Bourguignon to share. What's better than anything covered in butter? These were great though, and not chewy at all. I ordered the Moules Provençale with french fries. Others in our party ordered the Bourride Provençale and Paillard de Poulet. My mussels were excellent and the fries were solid. The seafood stew was also really good. The broth was rich and prefect for bread dipping. However, I don't think those that ordered the seafood stew ever got their side of risotto...

Dessert: Not your stereotypical desserts! We ordered the Profiteroles, Fraises Balsamic, and  
Tarte Tartin à la Poire. All very good!

Drinks: We ordered a couple bottles of red wine for the table, which were pretty good. Our waters were constantly being refilled and several people ordered, Coca-colas, lemonades, and an Arnold palmer. 

Service: The staff was very friendly and attentive. It definitely helped that we were the only ones in the restaurant by that point, but they never made us feel like we were a bother and they ensured that we had everything they wanted before they closed the kitchen.

Price: For 14 of us, with entrees, appetizers, entrees, wine, desserts, and coffees, our total was around $700. Not bad.
author: Leana L.

description:
Wholly satisfactory. Not great. Perhaps it was due to arriving within an hour before closing. This restaurant's in a quieter part of San Francisco and welcomes you to a warm and artsy interior. We didn't wait long before our friendly server seated us. 

We ordered the Sauteed Chicken Breast and New York Steak as our entrees. Unfortunately, the kitchen ran out of mashed potatoes, so we had to make do with fries. The bread roll did not come out warm and soft, but instead was hard and cold. The chicken tasted bland and the steak was okay. Better steak can be had for about the same price. I don't mind coming back again, but probably during brunch hours instead of dinner.
author: Justin F.

description: This restaurant just Canceled my birthday dinner three days before the reservation without contacting me directly. I got an email from OpenTable. Very bad business practice.
author: Jan C.

description:
This review is for brunch only.

BSB is a great neighborhood spot! Solid French bistro vibes with the food and service to match.

They have a beautiful vibe at their restaurant. The front of house staff is mostly French and you can tell they take pride in showing off the bistro-style of their cuisine.

Memorable Brunch Dishes-
Tomato basil soup
Croque monsieur 
The benedicts!

-1 star for no oysters at brunch and having some accidental extra charges on the bill ;)

Can't wait to come back for dinner. I am sure this place is 5-stars all around and cannot wait to frequent it more often as we live around the block
author: Nathan L.

description: Excellent food; excellent service... pet friendly!   The staff is SOOOO personable.  I can't wait to keep going back and try everything on the menu!
author: Evelyn W.

description: Love this cute restaurant. Its very cozy, has a romantic ambiance and I felt like I was back in Paris dining! The food here is superb and well presented. The owner gives a personal vibe as he greets each customer who comes in. The time we were there was an hour before closing but we still received the best customer service from the servers. One even volunteered to take our pictures. We never felt rushed at all. I highly recommend Baker Street Bistro to everyone. Oh its perfect for date night too!
author: Stephanie L.

description: Super delicious, excellent service. What more to ask for? We had a party of 13 hungry and in a hurry, and they were very accommodating.
author: Angelique M.

description: Absolutely love this place! Anything we have ever ordered has been amazing. I always crave the steak and it comes out perfectly with salad and fries. Brunch is awesome too! Service is always on point and love the small neighborhood vibe in cow hollow.
author: Leina K.

description: Absolutely love this place...especially for the escargots!  They have really good soups like rich tomato and split pea.  The seafood pasta was a huge hit at our table.  Great service, too.
author: Vickey K.

description: Brunch service was below satisfactory- one waitress and one busboy waiting 13-15 tables. When observing other patrons, you could sense the same sentiment of slow, inattentive service. Croque Madame was on point, oeufs florentine was bland. Decor and interiors are very pleasant.
author: Alex B.

description:
Had the mussels in the cream garlic sauce and croque monsieur. 
The mussels were outstanding. Almost four dozen of them in the most delicious sauce with shallots and tomatoes. It came with a cone of french fries that were hot and crispy. 
The croque monsieur was the best ever. It was covered in cheese on top. The sandwich was flavorful with oozing cheese inside along with ham
The waitress was very attentive even though she was the only waitstaff.   I can't wait to eat here again
author: Bacon G.

description: The mussels are lovely! We had great service (party of 8) and the kitchen is very prompt. The ambiance is perfect for dinner with friends or date night. Will definitely come again.
author: Erika O.

description: I loved this quiet little restaurant in a quiet side street neighborhood minutes from the Golden Gate Bridge. I wanted everything on the menu. I got the Confit de Canard which was very yummy. The little bite size potatoes were perfectly crisp outside soft inside and fabulous. I couldn't eat the stuffed tomato because it had bread crumbs and the spinach I got instead had an unusual and very delicious seasoning. My friend got the chicken with an orange sauce (I can't remember its menu name) that was even more tender and delicious. I look forward to returning when the weather is warm enough to sit outside. A great halfway meeting place for friends from Marin meeting friends from the Peninsula.
author: Cari A.

description: Hubby and I found this neighborhood treasure after taking care of some business in SF. We were lucky enough to have sunny sitting outside weather! We started off with a juicy bottle of French white wine and the charcuterie plate which was excellent. I usually am anti pate but I liked theirs. We shared the mussels with cream sauce and French fries....oh soooo good! For dessert we shared the profiteroles. The chef did a great job with the seasoning and we could tell the quality of food was excellent. The service was attentive as well. It was great to see lots of locals enjoying their neighborhood restaurant! Wish we had something like this in our area. Definitely will be back next time in SF. Price was reasonable for portion and quality of food.
author: Lola M.

description: My fav. Place for a Great And Czarming evening with french food in SF. Real diamond. Its perfect for a romantic date. Great french Onion soup
author: Malgosia K.

description: Our friend Eva saw this place on Check Bay Area a while ago, she frequented it once and said it was great and we should try. Boy am I glad we did. I stared with a Bellini, and we all had the onion soup... Amazingly delicious. Not at all overly salty like most other places. You could tell they cared about the dish, enough to garnish it with fresh chive. I ordered the duck breast and man... YUM! We each got a different dessert, one Strawberry balsamic ice cream, Chocolate Mouse and Vanilla cream which was like eating clouds. Absolutely delicious. The waitress was kind, courteous and attentive. Not once did we feel rushed. It was like being in europe. I highly recommend. And they have out-door seating too, so if you have a pet you can enjoy your meal with your four legged buddy.
author: Brian C.

description:
One star for shockingly poor service. Food is fine in fact quite nice as evidenced by the four stars of many of the guests but definitely not worth enduring this one particular French server. Want to share our poor experience due to the very rude server at this bistro, which we previously found to be a quaint and lovely  little neighborhood spot. We booked an open table rezzie for a somewhat spontaneous group dinner for a 40th bday for 8 people at 8 pm on Saturday evening. While open table confirmed the reservation for 8 pm, the restaurant called and left a message for an 8:30 start instead. No problem. 

However, When the group arrived, the server advised that the kitchen closed in an hour and everyone needed to hurry and get their order in. So, while they pushed out our start time by 30 mins we needed to hurry up and order. As a former server of a fast paced higher end seafood grill, I understand how the kitchen works and that it's nice to close up shop in a timely manner. But asking a group to come in later and then rushing them to order - was the first offputting event of the evening. Also, an 8 pm dinner on a Saturday night is hardly a late night dinner.  

Next, as she took the drink order, she singled out one of our group, the wife of the 40 year old and advised that she would give everyone drinks except her. The server said it loudly and in an Unkind way which was mortifying for our guest basically implying that she was too drunk to be served. My friend had a drink or two before dinner but was in no way, shape or form, sloppy or out of hand. We actually applaud when a server makes an assessment to decline drinks to someone who has been previously overserved but there were two problems with this: 1)she focused on the wrong person in the group (admittedly there were others who had been overserved) and 2)she said it in a way that was humiliating and loud. Even if she truly believed our friend was too drunk to continue to be served, she could have very easily said it in a more professional way.  This was how the meal started. Not good. 

The group had to make a fast decision to either stay and eat or to leave based on the very poor service and attitude but given the time of not and the size of the group, we decided to stick it out. Bad idea!

The server and one other staff member proceeded to sit and linger across from the table, while we finished our meal further adding to a very uncomfortable experience for what should have been a super fun night. 

If the restaurant didn't want a group of 8,at 8 pm on a Saturday night,they should not have accepted the reservation. 

I am born and raised in San Francisco as were several others at the table. Several of us have been to this establishment over the years and have been served by the French woman.  While she can be abrupt and very French, this time she crossed the line and was just plain horrible, putting a huge damper on an otherwise fun day and milestone for our friend. It was truly one of the worst experiences with a server any of us have ever had. 

Needless to say, no one will be returning and we will do our best to let our friends, family and acquaintances that the service is seriously subpar.
author: tammy o.

description:
Went there again for lunch... We had hamburgers (Hummmm) actually very good, we dont usually eat hamburgers... the frites were perfect...
haveta go there for dinner sometime but hate to be in the traffic in/to and from the city...
author: Peter N.

description: Dined here three times over the course of a month and each time it met and exceeded my expectations.  Eggs Benedict and mimosa were perfect, outdoor seating for brunch was great,  small, friendly, local walking families stopping in.  Dinner of Mussels and french fries were fantastic and over the top in flavor, preparation and size of portions! Waitress was super and efficient and friendly.  Definitely go here.
author: Diane A.

description: We loved everything in this place.  All of the cheeses in every dish was exceptional.  A wonderful little find with friendly service and a cozy atmosphere.
author: Michelle D.

description:
We came here after the Run 10 Feed 10 in SF.
Food was absolutely DDDEELLIISSHHH!!!
I had the French toast...
The coffee is good and SUPER STRONG! 
Everyone in my group truly enjoyed our food. They give u a lot of food too.
Its a bit pricey but the food is so good it's worth it, and they give u great sized portions so it's totally justified.
Its such a quaint little spot. The staff is SUPER friendly. 
We sat inside right by the door. There are tables outside, but we were cold. I really loved this place. I want to go back that frenh toast was so damn good!!
author: Allie C.

description:
OMG!!!! This place is beyond fabulous!  This is undoubtedly the best French food is SF, reasonably priced, excellent service and great location!!!  

Reservations for 7:30 and we were seated on time even though the place was crazy busy.  We had the escargot which were little pieces of heaven in a garlic/butter sauce that I wanted to lick off the plate. Our friends had a lovely goat cheese salad.  Main: I had the duck a la orange. It was perfection!!!  If you love duck, get yourself there and order this!!!  Served with spinach and a crispy polenta.  Here's the thing - I do not like polenta.  Not one bit - yuck.  I LOVED this!  Hubby had the lamb chops were were also perfect.  My cousin had the lamb stew which was heavenly.  For dessert you have to try the strawberries in a balsamic- brown sugar glaze thing over ice cream.  To die for!!!  For 4 of us, with corkage (one of our party bought their wine), 2 desserts  the bill was 208.  With tip, about 125 a couple and worth every penny!!

What a great evening and I can't wait to go back!!!
author: Debi S.

description:
Went in for dinner with no reservations at 6pm on a rather rainy Friday evening. We were seated right away but I can see how this place can get busy fast - even on an ugly March evening it got full pretty quickly. 
The bistro is nicely decorated and it does have a French vibe. 
I echo about every review here by highlighting how amazing the staff is. The French waitress that helped us out was extremely friendly and attentive. She really made our entire experience ten times better and it was pretty great to begin with. 
We started with a salad, had the scallops and ended with the creme brulee. Everything was delicious and the waitress suggested the perfect wine pairing (after encouraging me to taste and decide between her two choices).
At the end, we had to rush off to catch a movie so we paid and left while our waitress was helping other guest and we didn't see her to say goodbye. She did come after us, opened the restaurant door, thanked us for our visit and said goodbye! First time this has happened to me!
That's the kind of place Baker Street Bistro is!
I am already looking forward to my next visit. Highly recommended.
author: Adelia C.

description:
A nice change from the normal "American fare" in the marina. You can't go wrong with their takes on traditional French cuisine! 
-meat and cheese plates 
- anything duck related is fantastic and flavorful
The seafood stew is mediocre but a good array of fresh fish.

Small place but they know what they're doing!

Decent wine selection with heavy handed pours!
author: Sarah P.

description: Thank you Baker Street Bistro for an amazing dinner. The French onion soup was phenomenal, the lamb chops cooked to perfection and he the carrot/ginger mash was everything I had hoped for from reading the description. Well worth the trek from union square.
author: Rex T.

description:
Came here for a shockingly warm Valentine's Day brunch with a platonic friend lol. 

There was no wait and we sat outside which was nice. All the other tables were full, so I assume there's normally some kind of wait. 

The place is a little disjointed and I think perhaps understaffed. We had two different people serving us, and it confused us a little, and had to ask a few times to get things. No biggie, just something that I noticed. I feel like brunch spots are usually superr busy, so keeping everything tight is important. 

I ordered the ratattui (however you spell it...) eggs not to be confused with the cute movie about the rat. I thought it was unique and French and might as well try it. For a french restaurant, this place had a decent amount of veg options. I was thoroughly unimpressed with my meal, and the ratttoui...brb I'm just going to google this. Ok ratatouille. My ratatouille (obviously just copy/pasted) wasn't very flavorful. Coulda used some basic s/p and maybe fresh herbs. The bread wasn't fresh either and I thought maybe a French brunch place would pride themselves in that. Also you know how you usually leave Sunday bruch stufffeddd and ready to Netflix and chill the rest of the day? I know I hate being TOO full, but I  was hungry by the time I got on the Caltrain and back home like 1.5 hours later. 

Nice, cute spot, walking distance to Palace of Fine Arts + GG Bridge, but otherwise my food was just alrighty.
author: Aria S.

description:
Cannot understand the good reviews others have given this bistro. The experience was not at all what one would expect from a restaurant where main dishes start at $25.Maybe we went on a bad night ???
Claustrophobes beware! Tables are small and literally inches apart affording no privacy whatsoever. We could clearly hear conversations from each and every one of the tables beside and near us even though patrons spoke at sotto voce! Annoying too. So close together, staff had to move tables anytime anyone got up from, or returned to, a table. Those, like me, sitting against the wall on bench seats - all ladies naturally - had to keep purse and jacket on our laps. Not surprisingly a waitress knocked over a patron's wine glass while trying to squeeze a dish onto one of the table. The glass broke and sent glass shards across neighboring tables. We were two tables over and felt the spray. No apologies incidentally although the waitress did say it was her fault.
Food not at all reminiscent of Paris! To claim it is would be an insult to French food. Started with a bread basket of soft spongy sourdough bread accompanied by frozen butter packets. The fish stew was disappointing - the broth was bland and the fish was chewy and tasteless. Anxious to leave, I asked to take it home. They packaged it in a flimsy plastic container normally used for a sandwich or dessert. 
We chose this restaurant because it is relatively close to the Palace of Fine Arts. But will go somewhere else next time.
author: R C C L.

description:
We were walking out of the Presidio looking for a place to eat for lunch when I saw that I had bookmarked this place on Yelp.  There were 2 sets of doors and there was no sign so it wasn't clear which one to go in from.  When we walked in, we asked for a table of 4 and the only server there said she would get a table for us shortly and asked us to wait outside.  What was supposed to be a short wait ended up being over 15 minutes.  By that time, I was starving so I prayed that this place was going to be worth the wait.

Once we got seated, we realized they were serving brunch.  I'm not a huge fan of brunch so my choices of food was limited.  We were ready to order, but since there was only one server, it took forever for her to make it to our table.  Although we flagged her down, she still didn't come by right away.  By that time, I was getting annoyed.  We had to wait 15 minutes to order.  For a small place like that, it seemed like it was too much for her to handle.  The more annoying part was that she was more attentive to the table next to us and often ignored us.

I ordered a Croque Madame, which was a hot ham and cheese sandwich with fried egg on top along with a side of fries.  When my food came out, it didn't look too appealing as it was a big flat sandwich smothered with cheese and a side of mixed green salad.  My father-in-law said it looked like a patty melt.  Although it was nothing special, I ended up eating most of it since I was hungry and giving the rest to my husband.  The fries were good, but nothing special either.  

When we were done, we were ready to leave, but had to wait 15 minutes to get our check.  They said they had to reboot the computer, but by then, I was done with their excuses and being so slow.  I don't think I'll ever come back again.
author: Erica S.

description: 5 stars for the mussels alone.  Really the best mussels I have ever had and I will certainly plan to return for those.  The service was great, seating a bit cramped with other parties, but one of the couples next to us had brought a good bottle of wine with them and they weren't finishing it so shared with us which was really nice, and I would say the environment of this place breeds that type of hospitality.  Great spot and I can't wait to get back.
author: Joshua D.

description: We lived across this wonderful restaurant for many years and was a family favorite back when Jacques owned it! Their Hanger Steak (no longer on the menu) was fabulous! I'm glad to see that the quality of their food has remained the same. Looking forward to visiting again. xx
author: Victoria Z.

description: Loved the ambiance, food, staff and service. The only reason I'm not writing a longer review is that I want to keep it to myself!
author: michael s.

description: Breakfast is amazing here. Reasons why: the customer service is great, everyone speaks French which makes it feel authentic, the plates are beautiful and taste amazing and the atmosphere is warm and comfortable. We loved the place so much, we came back the next morning, for breakfast.
author: Gabrielle L.

description:
Came here for my mother's birthday on a Sunday with a reservation at 5:30. 

Upon arrival, we had a choice to sit either indoors or out. And we chose out because the weather was absolutely perfect and it made our dining atmosphere that much more special. 

Between 5:30 and I believe 6 or 7, they offer a prix fixe dinner. I wanted to give my family the option of ordering that as well as other main dishes from the menu. 

Our waitress was great and she had a very appealing French accent that made our experience even more memorable. She gave us menus and answered any questions we had. We ended up ordering a lot. 

My sister and father both got the prix fixe dinners, which included tomato-basil soup, a salad, pork loin with mashed potatoes as an entree, and fresh fruit for dessert. My sister wanted to try the French onion soup, so we ordered that as well. My mother and I wanted to try something different. So we ordered mussels and escargot for appetizers. My mother ordered a beef stew as an entree and I chose the duck confit. 

Our waitress offered us a timely manner as to how our food would be served. She brought things out so that everyone would be eating their entrees at the same time. She was great. Our family loved her service. I wish I got her name. 

She first brought out the mussels and escargot. These mussels were absolutely delicious. They were perfectly cooked and the sauce it was cooked in was addicting. It was served with bread and pommes frites (aka french fries). The escargot melts in your mouth. It has a rich, buttery sauce and made me forget I was eating snails. 

Then the soups came out. Two tomato-basils and a French onion. It came out piping hot. And everyone enjoyed it. 

Then our entrees came. And by then we were so full. I was really excited to try my entree though, so I pushed through. My duck confit was rich and delicious. It was tender and juicy on the inside and had a crunchy skin. My mother's beef stew was tender and rich. My sister and father's food was juicy and also cooked perfectly. We were in French heaven. 

Although we were stuffed, we decided to order creme brulee to end our night as well as the prix fixe fresh fruit dessert. And it was perfect. 

The overall bill ended up being a little over $200 but was well worth it. We also got a bottle of red wine. 

A helpful tip? 
Come early to find good parking. The residents here are not very forgiving. One of them tried to tow a car while we were having dinner and he was kind enough to ask around before he called. 

Good luck. And enjoy!
author: Kimberly E.

description:
This French Bistro made its way onto a TV food program feature, and now it's a local favorite. l myself drove with family 40 miles to eat here, and for a one-time only trip, I found it worth it. Quaint, intimate, and without pretentiousness. Our waitress was very kind and conversational, and eased in with some nice ice breakers to find out what our preferences were. I eat like a large fat American, I said.  

I love my mussels. I was justly coaxed into ordering the gargantuan bowl of tomato, onion, green onion MUSSELS & WHITE WINE broth. Fortunately I was able to also try the LAMB CHOPS which are smoky and succulent, with that pepper kicker, and would be a great second choice if you don't go with seafood. With my primary dish, I wisely paired it with a chilled Viognier (Languedoc) glass, always a nice palate sedative. Profiteroles are my favorite French dessert, and they do them lavishly here. #vocabulary
author: Sean C.

description:
Awesome brunch dishes! 
The Croque Madame is great!
We also liked their Eggs Florentine. Their eggs cooked just the way we wanted (we had issues with Bill's Cafe at Pleasanton last week).
Cinnamon French Toast is great! Love the yogurt sauce and fresh fruits. 
Yummy French Fries!
Coffee and Mocha great!

Pretty pricey food, but all worth it!!!
author: Ariene S.

description: Amazing food and amazing service! From the host to the waitress, chef and bidder it was all amazing! We had the French onion soup and goat cheese salad and main corse Salmon it was all perfectly made. I felt like I was in France it was a beautiful dinner. We'll be back soon!
author: Amber S.

description:
I love this place on several levels. It's French, so are the people running it, so is the music, decor and food. 

I had, yes, the prix fixe meal, only difference is I had two pork cutlets. $20. Very nice deal. Few cons*

Now kids, this isn't La Folie or L'Etoile or another fancy shmancy place. It is supposed to be, and is, a bistro. Imagine working somewhere in the City and either walking to Union/Chestnut or to the Marina Green and stopping here for a very recommended charcuterie plate and perhaps their yummy Bordeaux! Sit outside, wear a beret, read Le Monde and listen to Gilbert Becaud. This place brings it to you. 

Baker St Bistro is the real deal. Go!!!


*cons=parking perhaps at busy times, tables are choc-a block and it's recommended that you don't do an appi as it is too stuffing with a meal, and finally take if easy on the wine as it can run u easily over $140 if u have 3 glasses of wine and a coffee, a price fixe, and an entree and salad.
author: Kevin F.

description:
After having seen the stellar reviews on Check Please, my wife and I decided to check out this very quaint little bistro. 

We arrived with a reservation at 5:30pm on a Saturday, and were seated quickly. Baker St Bistro has a prix fixe menu effectively for happy hour (5:30-6:30 as I recall) for a measly price of $20. That includes the soup of the day, a small salad, an entree, and a dessert. Quite a deal!

My wife did the prix fixe and was served cream of mushroom soup, which was a big portion and very tasty. For her entree, she had roast chicken. The chicken was good, nothing outstanding but cooked perfectly with a side of mashed potatoes. For dessert, she had some chocolate mousse, which was awesome. Very flavorful and light and fluffy.

I ordered ala carte and got the escargot for an app, which was all the buttery deliciousness you'd hope it was. A must try.
Then I got the duck confit for an entree, and it was perfectly cooked and tender, highly recommended. To top it off, I got profiteroles, which are cream puffs and ice cream. Even though I was very full, I ate every bite! All was good.

The place is very charming, the service was great, and the food was very good. Good times!
author: Ian W.

description:
8/1/15:  I think that our infatuation with this place is over.  Still solid food, but I don't think it's anything special anymore.

1. Fresh Squeezed Limonade $3.5:  One of the better lemonades (or lime-aid?) I've had.  Very intense flavor and plenty of kick.  Not too sweet and super tangy.  Perfect.  9/10

2. Sandwich de Baguette $10:  Kinda small really.  Decent length, but it's less than 2in wide.  Standard grocery store ham.  Cheese was artisan though.  Greens salad was okay.  5/10

3. Oeufs Baker Street Bistro $14.5:  I wouldn't make this my restaurant's signature dish for sure.  The eggs benedict is pretty standard.  The poached eggs themselves were good with correctly running yolks.  But really not a fan of the tomato sauce.  I applaud them for trying to be unique, but I would work on this one more.  I suppose there's potential, but to me this is not much better than pouring canned spaghetti sauce on your eggs.  Also, the seasoned potatoes it comes with are soggy and wet--left most of it.  4/10

Good brunch, but not worth a special trip or anything.

3/5

#french #breakfast #brunch #lemonade #eggsbenedict
author: Dean C.

description:
Pros:  no wait 
            Friendly service

Cons :  long wait for food
              Food is ok
             Street parking
author: Bayarea K.

description:
Baker Street Bistro was a disappointment. My husband and I like to try out different brunch places around the city and we were in the Marina area so we thought we would check it out. 

The wait wasn't too long on an early Sunday afternoon so that should have been a hint that it wasn't going to be too great. After looking at the menu and making our choice, Oeufs Copenhague which is poached eggs and Salmon  and Pain Perdu which is cinnamon French toast, we attempt to order and the server says we're all out of Pain Perdu. Well that's a disappointment so we decide to split the Oeufs Copenhague with some coffee. Time goes by and nothing is brought to us, no coffee no water, nothing. The couple next to us was seated at the same time and already had their coffee and water. We had to flag someone down and ask for our coffee. We finally get our poached eggs and Salmon and the taste is good but nothing out of the ordinary. We drink our average coffee but we're never offered refills. There are still no servers around so we have to go to the front for the check. 

With so many options in San Francisco we won't be coming back to this restaurant.
author: Joseph F.

description: We returned from Paris earlier this week; still tired from our trip, decided not to cook and popped over to Baker Street Bistro (BSB) for San Francisco's version of the food we'd been eating for the past couple of weeks. The food at BSB was fantastic, service prompt, atmosphere relaxed and the cost very reasonable. If the wine were a bit cheaper I'd say the most restaurants in Paris had nothing on BSB.
author: Tushar N.

description:
Everything is great here. I stumbled into this little local gem after I finished my regular doc appointment down the street. Order the Pain Perdu (French as French toast) comes with fruit and yummy cream. Ordered escargot on the side, prepared well

Everything was wonderful ! Crowd was very classy yet casual !
author: CY C.

description:
When you are greeted at the door on a Saturday night by a sloppy (though, perfectly pleasant) kid in flip flops at a restaurant that is charging $30 for mains, you get a little suspicious.  If I'm going to lay down over $100 on a meal, I want a little more, like shoes.

Woefully understaffed.  There was one woman kicking ass and covering all the tables.  Kudos to her for keeping it together.

Food was just bad.
French onion soup had good flavor but was topped with a cheap cheese.  Green salad, was a pile of lettuce on a plate with a handful of under ripened beefsteak tomato pieces, I guess you would call them.  I mean, lettuce is lettuce, not bad but not noteworthy.
The cassoulet was like someone had seen an ingredients list and a picture - but not looked too closely at it - and decided to give it a whirl.  Cheap ingredients cooked separately poured into a clay dish at the end, which is just wrong.  
The risotto was soupy rice with a thick layer of cheese on it.  I'm not even sure what it was but it wasn't risotto.  All the ingredients tasted cheap actually, that was the most upsetting part.

The server noticed how we left both mains basically untouched and took them off our bill, which was appreciated.  As I stated earlier, she was kicking ass.

If there are people from France cooking in that kitchen they should of gone home that night in a puddle of shame.  Same with the manager who was having flip flop guy do the hosting. 

I do know we will not be back.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
We stumbled upon Baker Street Bistro and it was a great find. We had 4 adults and 2 kids, and the restaurant's ambiance was welcoming to all. There were outside and inside seating areas. Our server was friendly without being overbearing and made us, including the kids, feel comfortable. We ordered a variety of dishes, and everyone enjoyed what they had. 

I got the seafood stew, and every element in the stew was cooked just right. Usually in a seafood stew or soup, there is at least one element that will be over cooked, but everything tasted fresh and delicious. I tried a bit of the French fries, and they stayed crunchy even after a while. The coffee was good too.
author: James K.

description: The food, ambiance, and service are all awesome.  The charcuterie plate was delicious with nice selection of meats. Good selection of wines. Great outdoor seating for the day and cozy indoor space for dinner. The lady serving is very friendly and answers any questions about the menu gladly and in detail!
author: Neha M.

description:
This place is a super cute weekend brunch spot, and the best part was that there was absolutely no wait :) 

The staff was extremely sweet and friendly, and served us our food rather quickly. We ordered the benedict and the steak & eggs which were both pretty good, but on the downside the potatoes on the side were kinda cold. Usually the roasted potatoes are my favorite part of my brunch meal so I was a bit disappointed. 

But other than that, the place is a really nice quaint spot and I would give it another shot!
author: Angela D.

description:
If tasteless food is what you crave, you'll find it here.

There were three of us for dinner.

For Entrees (appetizers) we had Escargot Bourguignon, Soupe à l'Oignon, Salade Verte Vinaigrette, and Foie Gras.  The escargot tasted only of butter - not even a hint of garlic.  The onion soup looked good, but had very little taste - the broth was almost like water.  The salad was fine, but it is hard to mess up mixed greens from a box with a vinaigrette.  The foie gras was well prepared, but the most remarkable thing about the dish was the fruit spread and the grilled grapes.

For Plats we had Bourride Provençale; Steak Grillé, Beurre Maître d'Hôtel, Pomme Frites; and Boeuf Bourguignon.  The guest having the fish stew could only describe it as "interesting."  He was unwilling to provide any further details.  The Boeuf Bourguignon was mediocre at best.  I'm used to Boeuf Bourguignon having a gravy that is red from the wine- not brown.  Plus it is generally served with peas, onions, and potatoes, not potatoes and carrots which is more American.  In addition, it had not been prepared recently.  The steak seemed to be the best of the choices made - a sad reflection on a French restaurant.

Dessert included Tarte Tartin à la Poire,  Fraises Balsamic, and Profiteroles.  The dough for the  
Profiteroles was so tough that it required a knife to cut them - enough said.  The Fraises Balsamic was made with strawberries that were so far from ripe that they had no taste whatsoever.  The Tarte Tartin was described as "tasteless and boring."

Service went from one extreme to the other.  Either they were always at the table or they totally ignored you.

The joint opinion on the meal was "meh."  We won't be back.
author: Scott M.

description:
Great spot for brunch. 

I walked in by myself and around 1:30 pm on a Saturday and was seated immediately. 

The hostess was very organized and attentive. She even helping me clean up my clothes when she saw I had accidentally spilled some syrup.

I got the Pain Perdu (french toast) and it was great, just sweet enough. 

I loved the small café atmosphere and would like to come back sometime for the Prix Fixe dinner.
author: MeiXing D.

description:
I have been looking forward to going to this restaurant for a long time. We finally did yesterday but it was a big disappointment. We made a reservation through OpenTable, but when we arrived, on time, the manager, who was very cold, unwelcoming and rude, did not appear to acknowledge our reservation. He simply told us to sit outside (about 50 degree) to wait "for a few minutes". Not apologetic at all. After sitting for a while and recognizing that this guy was not going to get us a table in reasonable time, we grab a more shielded table outside for our dinner.
We ordered escargot for appetizer, which is very delicious. For main dishes, we ordered beef bourganon and duck breast. Both are good but not outstanding. For dissert we had pear tart with strawberries. It was again good but not outstanding. The service at the table was fine, contrary to that of the manager. But that can hardly compensate for the rude and indifferent treatment we got from the manager. We have not received the points from reservation through OpenTable. The points are no big deal, but this is another indication that they simply ignored our reservation.
Over all, I would rate the food a 4, but service a 1 because of the rude manager. I cannot imagine going back again to experience the irritation of having to deal with that manager.
author: Tuck W.

description: We came around noon and had the most charming seat by the window. Cushions. Proper tea served in spot with a jug of warm milk. Can't speak for the coffee. Our waitress was French and very pleasant and friendly and helpful. A really lovely experience. The decor is charming. And the food didn't disappoint. Cream of mushroom soup was inhaled- delicious. And the croque madam was a real treat. Perfect for a hangover! Side salad had a delicious vinaigrette as well. All in all a really lovely, charming experience
author: Kitty S.

description: Food is excellent, recommended.  Mussels are really good.  Only drawback is difficult to find parking.
author: K W.

description:
I just had dinner here with a friend and it wasn't too busy which was nice. 

We had the duck confit and chicken. Both were moist and the sauces they came with were great. The mashed potatoes with the chicken was ok. 

The brunch menu looks really good and hope to try it sometime!
author: Daniela J.

description:
I can't comment on the food because the waitress straight wouldn't let my family of four eat here.

The place was near empty and there was nobody on the patio, so I asked to be sure we could sit out there. She said that we shouldn't because it was too windy. I looked around and there wasn't a breath of wind. I told her we'd like to try anyway. She tried to talk us out of it.

Once we settled that, I asked if they had a high chair.

"no! booster?"

"Ok, that's fine"

"For who? Him?", she asked, pointing at my 1 year old son who I was carrying. Before I could answer she continued, "no! He's too young!"

"What??" I asked, increasingly confused. We live in the city and take our kids everywhere, and I've never encountered someone so antagonistic to kids before. 

"Is he very active? He'll fall out"

I reassured her, "No, he'll be fine we put him in boosters all the time"

"No!" She began shouting

"Look, I know my kid, he'll be fine"

"I'll have to ask the manager"

"You know what forget it, we'll eat someplace else"
author: Aaron B.

description:
French without the snottiness.  I'd call it "upscale peasant French". Could there be a more perfect possible choice on a cold winter evening? I'll leave that as an exercise for the reader.

We were here for dinner before a show at the Palace of Fine Arts; a great pick from my friends J and M. Service was attentive but casual, and we were allowed to wallow in the menu as long as we liked. (We had a bit of extra time).  

One sign of a good restaurant: So many things I wanted to try on the menu! Yet I could only pick one (damn). But it was winter and they had cassoulet on the specials list. So in the end the choice was inevitable (for me).

My cassoulet was impeccable: a crispy duck leg with meat falling off the bone; garlic sausage, tomatoes, bacon and onions in a perfectly-seasoned white bean stew.  It tasted like the ingredients had been cooking together for a week. (Had they?)  I almost hurt myself finishing it.

My friends loved their Beef Bourguignon, and my daughter J put a serious dent in their steak and fries.  Very happy tummies all around.

The wine list wasn't spectacular but it didn't need to be. Upscale peasant french doesn't require $200 bottles, and they had plenty to choose from, and from all styles. I enjoyed a glass of syrah while my friends were tasting pinots.

Dessert was a blissful blur; they had my favorite ending for a big meal: a small chocolate mousse, a glass of port, and a coffee.

After dinner we flowed happily out into the cold night. It was a good thing we walked to the show, just to shed some some of those excess calories; I'd say they were the highest-quality calories I've had in a long while!
author: Dan B.

description:
We went to Baker Street Bistro to celebrate the wife's birthday.  Best decision for the day.  It is now our new favorite french place to go in the city. 

The food.  Wvery dish from aperitif to entrée to dessert was excellent. I ordered the charcuterie and it was fantastic.  A nice selection of cured meats and paté large enough to share.  The soup de jour was mushroom and it was very smooth in texture and not overly creamy.  The escargot was perfectly tender.  Flor entrée I ordered the seafood stew.  It had plenty of variety and was savory and tasty.  The duck breast was perfectly cook and not dried nor greasy.  The lamb chops were very tender and flavorful.

For dessert we had the tartin,  mousse chocolat and fraises balsmic.  All were good but the fraises balsamic was fantastic.  As soon as we ordered it our server immediately said we would love it. She was right, we did. 

The service was excellent and the timing of each service was just right. The setting was as well.  Small and quaint in a neighborhood setting. 

Cannot wait to return again.
author: P.Y. H.

description:
Breakfast Review 

Decent French spot that offers indoor and outdoor seating.

They have a nice amount of options and after a few minutes of hesitation I went for the Salmon with Eggs Benedict, good tasting dish.

Everyone in our group of 5 was happy with their food and service.
author: Tim R.

description:
Looking for a brunch spot after a hike in the presidio and ended up here at this cute little bistro.  Service is friendly, though was hard to grab their attention when we were ready to get the bill.

Tried the French toast and the Canadian ham benedict.  Both were good and hit the spot since I was kind of starving.  I could've done without the coulis with the French toast but it definitely added to the visual presentation.

Sitting outside with a cup of latte and good company made for the perfect end to our hike.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Wow! What a great example of the San Fran experience. Delicious food, lots of hugs, and attentive staff and an ambience of very human warmth. 

This experience helped turn around an otherwise rough morning and for that I am very grateful. 

Thank you Bakers Street! I will be visiting you on every one of my trips to San Fran. :)
author: Mikal A.

description:
It's been years since I've patronized this far-and-away Marina bistro, and the name always makes me think of listening to Gerry Rafferty's song back in college. That sax riff in the middle takes me back. Give me a minute... OK, I'm back on Baker Street and this time for a Saturday brunch with Jamie W. after taking an interesting morning shuttle tour of the Presidio's hidden mysteries. We were planning to go right up to Point Bonita since the lighthouse was open, but we were quite famished. Yes, I use that word. On purpose. Anyway, I had a flashback to Baker Street Bistro, a good one, so a Parisian-style déjeuner sounded très bon pour nous.

And that's all the high school French I can remember. Anyway, it looks to be popular among the locals since the waitress appeared to recognize all the customers except us. That didn't stop us from receiving attentive service though. Everything on the brunch menu looked appetizing in a very French way. Jamie went for the $12 Oeufs Bénédicte, eggs benedict to us unilingual plebeians, lovingly prepared with a pair of firmly poached eggs ladled generously with hollandaise sauce as they rested on Canadian bacon and a split English muffin. It came with a side of mixed greens and home fries (see photo). Now I would have normally repeated an order as luxuriant as that, but for some reason, I was drawn to the cafe sandwiches.

The $11.50 Croque Madame was calling out my name with a Brigitte Bardot accent. A smart move as it was a criminally luscious creation, a slice of ham with a thick layer of melted Swiss cheese topped by a fried egg sunny-side up, all of it resting on two slices of toasted pain de mie that were pure buttery decadence. No potatoes thankfully given the artery clogging that must have been occurring in real time, but a side of mixed greens to alleviate one's conscience about the caloric intake...NOT! (see photo). Sinfully delicious and totally worth it. Funny how comforting an overwhelming slab of melted cheese will do for you. Anxious, panting canines surrounded us. I closed my eyes and dreamt I was at the Tuileries Garden.

FOOD - 4 stars...decadent brunch items make this a most worthwhile weekend indulgence...the Croque Madame is a must-eat
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...the outdoor seating is perfect on a morning on the brink of warming
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite attentive
TOTAL - 4 stars...play that sax solo again..."windin' your way down on Baker Street.
light in your head and dead on your feet..."
author: Ed U.

description:
Sincere, warm service and fabulous food made this a wonderful place for dinner.  

The mussels did not disappoint, a huge portion and I could not help myself from dipping the crusty bread in the broth.   My husband had a seafood stew which was wonderful as well.
author: Lauren W.

description: Had the charcuterie plate followed by an amazing apple tart, then had to return the following night to have the main courses we had wanted to try.   Great food.
author: Phil S.

description: Adorable Place away from me hustle and bustle of the busy City. Call Frank atmosphere attentive wait staff. Delicious brunch options I recommend the eggs benedict with rosemary potatoes. Also have to try the French toast voted best in the Bay Area
author: Dannielle R.

description: I'm visiting from out of town and found this hidden gem. So glad I stumbled upon this place. Their lunch salad with chicken and capers left me craving for it a couple of days later. When I came back, they weren't serving the dish but I opted for their beef bourignnone (killed the spelling) and it was fantastic! The place is small and quaint and I enjoyed sitting by the window. Must have had three glasses of wine. Anyways, so good and I will definitely be back! :-)
author: Oscar P.

description: Mmmm, mussels provencal, and French fries....This small neighborhood cafe prepares French delights plus beautiful breakfast dishes and salads to enjoy indoors or at outdoor tables. The cozy dining room with antique wall clocks is utterly charming. Meals are served by a decidedly friendly hostess, so you leave there happy as well as satisfied.
author: Lynn S.

description:
Late lunch on a Tuesday. The food and service were outstanding. generous portions, attention to detail. Fine bistro fare Steak frites, mussels in a gorgeous broth, escargot) and outstaning desserts- floating island, warm strawberries with balsamic and pepper were amzing - even though full already, we ate every bite! 

Love this place - no wonder they have been in business for 35 years.
author: Pat R.

description:
I won't lie - when my friends told me we were going to the Marina for brunch, I cringed a little bit.  It's already a tough area for parking, but factor in the gorgeous weather drawing people outside and it was going to be that much worse.  At least, so I thought - multiple spaces in front?  I like this Baker Street Bistro place already!

On top of getting nearby parking and the sunny skies above, it was awesome that we were able to snag a table outside.  What's more...the food was pretty good!  Although nothing about it really stood out, my Eggs Benedict dish wasn't too shabby (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baker-street-bistro-san-francisco?select=TYWWiz3J2mPo91QQWMd9uw#AyUN2fM9ww-44ggpPSEAaw).  The eggs were poached perfectly, the Hollandaise sauce had just a touch of acidity, and the Canadian baon was oh so good.  Sadly, the home fries were my least favorite part of the dish.  Although they weren't awful, they weren't as good as they could have been either (needed more seasoning).

What did stand out for me was the Pain Perdu (Cinnamon French Toast) my friend had ordered for the three of us to share.  Although the added fruit and strawberry coulis made the dish a little sweeter than I would have liked, the French troast was terrific (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baker-street-bistro-san-francisco?select=TYWWiz3J2mPo91QQWMd9uw#rgpaXJRizzFg-jKuv3Z31g).  The slices were lightly browned, covered with just the right amount of cinnamon, and maintained some bite while still soaking in the syrup.  No soggy and mushy French toast here!

Based on our meal and the reviews I read from other Yelpers, I'd say there's a fairly decent chance I'll be back at some point to check out their dinner menu.  However, as much as I would like to say it would be soley because of the food, the (relative) wealth of parking in this part of the Marina might have something to do with it too.  Hey, can't fault me for being honest!
author: Mike L.

description: Great brunch food. Good service and atmosphere. Really cute place, with lots of people eating the eggs Benedict Copenhagen, including me. I wasn't dissapointed. The cinnamon was a little light on cinnamon taste, but otherwise pretty good.
author: Win K.

description: Wonderful food for an affordable price and nice atmosphere. Went here for mom's birthday and she loved it. We all did. The staff was friendly and lovely. Yummy food and good portions. Great prix-fix deal. Also seemed very authentic- server was a very nice and patient French woman. Merci Beaucoup!
author: Elise N.

description:
This cafe has both indoor and outdoor seating available and the ability to accommodate large groups.  The waitress is charming and makes great menu recommendations.  Nearby street parking was very easy to find and the restaurant is a short stroll to the Palace of Fine Arts.  

The seafood stew is a must try.  Not only was the broth absolutely delicious but the stew was LOADED with seafood and absolutely did not skimp!  My relatives, who were visiting me from Taiwan, beamed about how delicious it was.  In fact, everything I've tried, from the omelette to the duck confit, has been very good.  Prices are very reasonable, especially for the quality of the food provided.

I use this spot to entertain business colleagues whenever they are in town and it has never disappointed.  Highly recommend!
.
author: Linda H.

description:
We went here for brunch with another couple. The food was strictly OK. I get the feeling that this place may be much better for dinner. We actually waited a really long time for our food (maybe around 35 minutes) even though there weren't many people in the place and we ordered really simple dishes. And then when it arrived it was not so warm.

Also we're not regulars so we actually didn't enjoy the "familiarity" of the servers.

We'll try this place again for dinner so this review may change soon...
author: Art C.

description: One of my favorite places to eat for a nice dinner in San Francisco. If I have people coming to SF to visit I always take them here and they are never disappointed. DELICIOUS french food that is affordable. I love the quaint atmosphere. Always just a wonderful experience.
author: Sara C.

description:
My bf's parents had dinner here and highly recommended it, so we checked it out for brunch. My bf was initially disappointed because he realized that the dish his mom had told us was so exceptional isn't on the brunch menu, but just means we'll have to visit again for dinner!

The cafe was small and fairly full but somehow maintaining an airy feel, and we were seated outside immediately with no reservation (on a Saturday morning). No reservation necessary+walking distance from our friend's place in the Presidio=winning combo! The fixtures and decor are minimal but charming. The service was friendly and helpful.

The coffee was as delicious as I've come to expect from French cafes, and the champagne to oj ratio on the mimosas was perfect. I had the croque madame which came with salad. The salad was also what I'd expect of a french cafe- simple and refreshing. The croque was generously sized with perfectly toasty cheese.

I'd recommend Baker Street Bistro to anyone seeking an delicious French-cafe style meal. Next time I'd like to try their specialty Pain Perdu or that dinner bf's mom was raving about!
author: Hannah S.

description:
Baker Street Bistro is delightful! I went for lunch and had the mussels with fries, and my husband had the seafood pasta special. Both were excellent (although I must say I was a little jealous of my husband's special), and the service was very attentive. Wine selection was not extensive but solid. The house Sancerre is everything you could want out of a Sancerre.

The vibe is very neighborhood-y / family-owned -- it's kind of tucked away in the Marina / Presidio area on a quiet street. It almost feels as if you've been invited to somebody's kitchen in a very good way. There is a quaint outdoor seating area out front, and the inside of the restaurant was very cozy. 

It's neither cheap nor expensive. You might be surprised when you get the bill, until you suddenly realize every bite was worth it.
author: Tini T.

description: A friend read a great review of this place and said we had to try it. Perfect location for people driving in from Marin. Charming decor. Cozy seating indoors or out. (We sat inside. Nice temp.) Salmon was stellar. I will absolutely go back.
author: Phoebe W.

description:
This is a very cute restaurant in a beautiful area of San Francisco. The interior is nicely designed and there is a good view of the kitchen staff without it being too loud.

The staff is very professional and service was exceptional.

I had a charcuterie plate to start. It was excellent with five different meats, pickles, and onions. It went great with their complimentary bread. My favorite was the pate. The server also gave me some mustard, which was a nice touch.

I then had the seafood stew. This was alright, but far from excellent. The soup was bland. I think that if they used more salt and some sort of acidity it would make the soup much better. I also felt the single scallop, although large, should have been seared before being put in the soup.

Overall a nice restaurant with great ambiance and great service. I won't let one bad dish ruin my opinion of somewhere that seemed to know what they were doing.

Would be a great place for a date, it is within walking distance of San Francisco's Palace of the Fine Arts. This means you can do some sight seeing and stop in for a nice dinner.
author: Joseph N.

description: French food at its best! Of he party of four 3 of us have been to France and one of us have lived there. The appetizers, main course and dessert were fantastic. The wine was also excellent. The ambiance and service was very good. At the end of the meal we were figuring out when to come back.
author: Kevin l.

description:
Had a great brunch meal! 
As soon as my friends and I  walked in  we  felt  welcome 
I would totally recommend this place.
author: Michelle C.

description: Teaches me to trust a 4 star reading at face value. The word that sums it up for me is "lazy". A lazy attempt at French cuisine. The French are perfectionists and to see such lazy take on fine dining and a chip on the shoulder customer service, I was disappointed considering the local competition. Tuna nicoise from a can? Tasteless burger? Salmon tartare inspired by Denny's potato salad? No bread for the table? Never again.
author: SixFour A.

description:
The eggs Copenhagen were delicious and came with a salad and potatoes. The potatoes were hard and chewy. They tasted like they were out for a long time and stale before they served them to us.

The French toast is a good deal and came as a pretty display. We recommend this place for a cute brunch.
author: Mary S.

description: This is a new spot I really liked the Food is actually awesome and down right good, Not to many places I've been and really liked the food there Desert was also perfect , Cant wait to go back again
author: Jerr B.

description:
2.5 STARS

We've ALL seen it (though may not admit it)...

One sibling is the epitome of hotness exuding both sex appeal and beauty from head-to-toe. Even with no make-up, she can make head turns faster than  Wile E. Coyote. Then, you have the other sibling who is to nicely put it "unfortunate looking". With her make-up skills, she ends up looking like Mimi Bobeck from The Drew Carey show. I totally feel for her as I've probably been mistaken for a tranny with my quad layer caked on make-up, tattooed eyebrows, and triple stacked whore lashes mid-day. Sadly, not everyone can be as fortunate. 

Baker Street Bistro IS that "unfortunate" sibling. One of my most memorable meals last year was at its sister restaurant, Bistro Central Parc (my review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/bistro-central-parc-san-francisco#hrid:8iXzFqkMP-OUolQ737sZkg). There, the food was just as amazing as the service which was a complete opposite from my experience at Baker Street Bistro.

F O O D
Needing to feed my foie gras addiction before the upcoming ban in 10 days, I dragged Mr. NSS here because they had three featured foie gras dishes which is the only reason I choose Baker Street Bistro for dinner. 

*Escargot Bourguignon in Garlic & Parsley Sauce ($10.50) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xc9iz3CT9v133LFdjhOZcQ?select=9APlC6s9R3UCiV3iYZCP-A#V8MQpBbNqjwetBABV2va_A
The best part of our meal, the escargot was tenderly soft with a tantalizing garlicky herbaceousness.
 
*Pan Seared Foie Gras & Smoked Duck Breast w/ Pine Nuts & Duck Gizzard Confit Salad ($16.50) - 3.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xc9iz3CT9v133LFdjhOZcQ?select=9APlC6s9R3UCiV3iYZCP-A#TYWWiz3J2mPo91QQWMd9uw
Surprisingly, the smoked duck breast was the winner in the dish. It was rich and tender with just the right amount of smoky flavor to awaken my taste buds. The foie gras tasted like almost like regular liver and lacked the quintessential rich decadence.    

*Tournedos Rossini: Pan Seared Beef Tenderloin Topped w/ Pan Seared Foie Gras ($29) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xc9iz3CT9v133LFdjhOZcQ?select=9APlC6s9R3UCiV3iYZCP-A#ZLuekYfJ7-0-WebCba8RiA
The Tournedos Rossini was a disappointment both in quality and execution. The bland beef tenderloin was difficult to cut and had tons of fibrous connective tissue having not been broken down making the steak extra chewy (at least my mouth got a work out). The lack of richness from the foie gras and the watery demi-glace made this dish utterly disappointing. 

Poor Mr. NSS's dish looked like a reduced fat dinner plate which he didn't like. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xc9iz3CT9v133LFdjhOZcQ?select=9APlC6s9R3UCiV3iYZCP-A#gLaYkZwsOkUb87v5wmydeQ

S E R V I C E
Contrived friendliness with a complete lack of attentiveness is not what I expected from a seemingly charming neighborhood restaurant especially after having received such warm, genuine, and attentive service from its sister restaurant, Bistro Central Parc. Mr. NSS had to go inside to ask for the bill and go back inside to pay for it. A bit inexcusable. 

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Parisian bistro meets French country nook with crisp white linen tables, outdoor patio seating, yellow hued walls, and rustic wooden furnishings. Seating is tight and meant for small parties no more than four. 

P A R K I N G
Moderate to difficult street parking. 

With just less than 10 days before the foie gras ban, Baker Street Bistro is not a place I would recommend to indulge in your foie gras' desires. When you bite into foie gras, a burst of luxurious richness should coat every crevice of your mouth and have you grinning from ear-to-ear. It should make your toes curl and your eyes roll back into your head. The foie gras at Baker Street Bistro was like boring, mediocre, and mundane sex. *yawn* If you want mind-blowing "sex", please do yourself a favor and go to La Folie or Alexander's Steakhouse before the ban.

Unless you like boring, mediocre, and mundane "sex" than by all means. To each their own...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
We all know that brunch in Saturday or Sunday in SF can be a complete nightmare. Long waits, crowded spaces, disappointing food... Well, none of that stuff is an issue at Baker Street Bistro -- in fact, I found it to be quite the opposite, and was completely smitten with this adorable little eatery. 

Patina-ed and cozy, Baker Street Bistro has a very European air amplified by the charming and very French host/server. The seating spills into a lovely little section on the sidewalk, and large windows keep the indoor space well-lit and airy. 

The menu reads like a brunch/French hybrid -- plenty of Benedicts, Croque Madame, a charcuterie plate and eggs every which way. Not to be missed? Their refreshing mimosas and super-strong black coffee. 

I'd happily brunch here again, and in fact would't miss coming back for dinner, either. Baker Street Bistro looks like it's been here for 100 years easily, and I mean that in the best way possible -- it's absolutely charming!
author: Hilary H.

description:
Went here last night with a friend, and I guess it was okay? It was very French, and by very French I mean that the servers will pretty much ignore your existence, even when you are trying really hard to flag them down, possibly because they are conducting an elaborate experiment on the Doppler effect and want to know what your voice sounds like as they pass by you and keep right on going. 

Anyway. I had the boeuf bourguignon and my friend had the steak tartare. My stew was good, but it didn't really surpass the label of plain old beef stew. My friend was not particularly effusive about the tartare. 

We split the profiteroles for dessert, which were--again--nice but nothing special. It was our second choice because they were out of creme brulee. Actually, they were out of quite a few things, so perhaps our experience suffered from being there later on a Thursday night. Still, I've had much, much better French food in the Bay Area.
author: Kim K.

description: Excellent simple French food in a classic bistro setting. Brunch is delicious. The fresh fruit was surprisingly interesting and the soup du jour was as good a cauliflower as you'll ever get.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Hmm.. I was in the bay area and we decided to stop here for brunch. This place is a nice little joint if you're in the area and looking for a quick fix, but I wouldn't go out of the way to try this place.

I ordered two poached eggs with spinach and my sister got two poached eggs with salmon. Both were very mediocre, especially for the price. They come with a little salad though, which was nice. Sadly, service was not good. When our server put down the food, I watched his finger touch my dad's egg... gross. I appreciate the cozy, family-owned vibe though!

If I'm ever in the area again, I'll honestly try another place since there are so many cool brunch places in SF.
author: Connie M.

description:
Another brunch review:

I love their outdoor patio seating, although their seats are pretty uncomfortable.

I wanted to go beyond my usual benedict and croque madame, so I ventured to try the mussels with cream, as recommended by the waiter. It was pretty good, and I might get it again, but it was over $20. Ouch. That's alot to spend on an entree at brunch.

I also tasted the NY Strip Steak, which had a great flavor but was extremely tough. I could tell simply by looking that the cut of the meat was poor, but the flavors are all there. Again, $20 for steak and eggs is steep for the quality.

The Croque Madame was better than I remember, although the best part really is the crust because of the crunchiness. The center is overwhelmingly creamy and cheesy.

Perhaps this may be a better spot for dinner.
author: Jess C.

description:
Solid five stars here. The food was excellent. The service was fast and friendly.  The sun was out so the patio was perfect.

I had the eggs with ratatouille and salad with orange juice everything was tasty!
author: Moe O.

description:
Lovely little spot.

We just finished a short hike in the Presidio Park when we decided to go for lunch and then come back to enjoy the park (it was a lovely sunny day, so we had no intentions on going back home just yet).

Parking was very easy. Close to the park. Delicious food.

It was so nice to sit outside and enjoy the great and friendly service!! Was a perfect spot for a perfect day.

I wish it was sunny every day! Definitely worth checking out if you are in the area.
author: Maggie J.

description:
I'm giving this 4 stars for the service, speed I received my order, quantity of food, and location. But the taste is the only reason I'm marking this down by one star; it just didn't hit me the way I was hoping it would. Is it good enough to eat? Absolutely! Still, could've have been a LITTLE bit better.

We arrived at a good time Sunday morning, so didn't have to wait. We chose to sit outside because the weather was PERFECT, and I'm a bit surprised so many people were sitting inside. (Then again, they were all white people. No offense, but we know how the sun feels about you guys.) The waiter gave us a few minutes to look over the menu, and from the time he took our order to the time our food was served: 10 minutes tops.

I went with the eggs benedict with salmon, which was good. But they have to do something with that hollandaise; something is missing from it, and that just didn't agree with my taste buds. Sorry.

But I still think this is the kind of place I'd visit regularly if I lived in the area. It's got a nice feel to it and is in a great location just off the main road on a side street. If I had another opportunity I would try something a little more "French" from the menu.
author: John H.

description: I was so fortunate to get a reservation here on New Year's Eve. We brought a bottle of wine and enjoyed it with the foie gras, muscles proquette with fries  and the pork chop. All delicious but the muscles were some of the best I've tasted. The sauce was so good! The service was great.
author: Nathan S.

description: The best French Onion Soup I've ever had........the whole meal was great, but damn that was some good soup. The service was awesome as well......
author: Troy H.

description: Had a fabulous brunch here after the Great Santa Run! My friend and I got the croque madame sandwich and an eggs benedict and shared both. We both got coffee and they brought steamed milk to put in it! Service was good, food was delicious, would definitely come back if in the neighborhood again!
author: Lora E.

description:
Boy have I missed a decent brunch! This place is super cute and there was adequate parking right out front. The service isn't the greatest (they're nice to regulars, just not overly amicable to us mere tourists).
We ate based exactly on the three recommendations the server gave us. The croque Madame was mine and it was SO good! I only wish I could stomach it all. The girl had the French toast which she says was the lightest and fluffiest she's ever had. Not to mention the presentation was adorable! Our friend had the salmon Benedict and it was delicious! I'd go back for the food, for sure. Maybe I caught them during a big rush, but the servers just need a little push to be slightly nicer.
author: Janive S.

description:
