Amazing, so fun for my little girl she loved the French toast. We had the mussels and fish stew both great choices. 
The employees were so sweet to all of the kids, they even gave her flowers! Will definitely be back.
author: Amy T.

description:
Took my mama here for our xmas eve dinner. The food was soo good! The service was excellent! It wasn't loud and chaotic like other of the restaurants we've been to in the past. It's a teeny tiny little hole in the wall place, but don't let that scare you away. It's almost like dining in Paris! 
I'll be back, for sure!
author: Joanna H.

description:
Came here last Friday night and boy does it get busy!

Walked in with no reservation at about 6:30pm. Wrong way to go, always make a reservation, luckily for my boyfriend and I, they set up a table next to the counter for us because they didn't want to shove us into the cold.

I ordered the foie gras and the white wine mussels, boyfriend ordered the L'orange and escargot.

The foie gras was the best part of my whole meal, the white wine mussels were meh, each time I picked out the meat of the mussel and bit into it, the shells of the mussels were inside. YUCK, the taste of the mussels weren't something to rave about either. Babe's escargot was subpar and had a weird taste to it. I liked the escargot at ChouChou tho, the truffle oil really masked the dirty taste of escargot. The l'orange was also subpar, too much citrus flavor that did not enhance the plate.

Overall, 4 stars for service but 3-3.5 for the food.

Friendly reminder... MAKE SURE YOU MAKE RESERVATIONS.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Oh heavens, what a bad experience. I have not been on Yelp for quite some time but this dining experience got me livid enough to go back on and write this review. Living in the city and looking for a good French food experience to try for dinner (and seeing the reviews), we thought perhaps we could not go wrong with trying 'Baker Street Bistro'.

Along with my dining partner, we were squeezed into a table for two that even Munchkins could not feel comfortable fitting in. After being given menus, it took forever for the server to return to the table to take our order. So, let's cut to the chase...

The French onion Soup was tasteless. Each escargot was literally the size of a pea (yes, a pea), and even with the garlic butter sauce their taste was pitiful.  My friend had the risotto and gave it a  5/10. We both had ordered a glass of wine before the meal  and not once did the server come by to offer a refill - I sadly had to try and flag her down.

I just wanted to get the check and leave.

Yelpers: Spend your hard earned money elsewhere.
author: Bobby J.

description: definitely terrible service. server Looks unhappy and without patience. Ignore our request for times. Leave us at seats even we ask for service. Treat us randomly maybe because of automatically 20% tips. Dropped water on my bag with my phone,charging baby and purse on it while I went to restroom. Didn't try to dry my bag first. Very Interesting. The owner should hire more  server.
author: Roski L.

description: Came here for brunch. Service was painfully slow. Ordered the oeuf  ratatouille and it was just okay. Some items on menu was pricey for a small bistro.
author: Philip T.

description:
A little bit of Paris right in San Francisco!  Sat outside on a beautiful Sunday afternoon after a morning of walking for the JL House Tours.  

Shared Oeufs Benedict and the cream based (rather than white wine based) mussels.  Giant bowl of delicious mussels with perfectly crispy fries.  Service was excellent!
author: Kathleen W.

description:
The food was okay but the service was incredibly slow. I walked in to get a table and the server asked me to go back outside! The only time she seemed anxious to come to our table was when she was delivering the check. The place wasn't even busy... (My review excludes the busboy who was very nice.)

I had the mussels Provencale and it was great. However, it came with the side order of fries even though I didn't order it. The smoked salmon in my friends eggs Benedict was superb. Potatoes could have been more interesting. 

Classic case of good food but subpar service.
author: Allison S.

description: Great lunch here! Had the mixed green salad with walnut crusted goat cheese, and chicken. Lovely and quaint restaurant and can't wait to come back to try the mussels!
author: Brooke H.

description:
Three and a half stars, on the three side for my particular review. Close though.

Saw this place on "Check Please!" and had to "check" it out.  Got a nice window seat with pillows which was really spacious and comfy.  Ordered a bottle of the best rose they had.  He offered for me to taste it and I said to just pour and he made me feel like a turd for not tasting the wine.  It was a fifty dollar bottle do we really have to go through with this?  Oh how the French can unknowingly make us feel like the uncultured animals that we are lol.  He was cool but there you have it.  My mom is a French native and I have been to France and Paris more times than I can remember so our "Parisian Style" server was exactly that to the T.
After the wine came he fired all of our app's and loaded up our table like it was a Chinese food restaurant.  It worked out well since two of our app's were molten straight from the broiler but it was his call to bring out four dishes all at once.  

We had four app's and I had no problem finishing my steak frite salad.

The goat cheese salad had a great vinaigrette and diced tomato garnish.  It was good.  The goat cheese was bread crusted and deep fried in their frier. Portion was good to big.

The half dozen oysters were sweet and delicious.  Served on a bed of Ice with lemon and a mild mignonette.  Sweet small tasty fresh oysters shucked with no shell broken into the meat.

My wife loved the escargot.  I thought it was good too.  I noticed that they use tarragon in the butter which I was ok with but IMO is too sweet for escargot.  I still had no problem eating this buttery delicious dish.  

The onion soup was perfect.  Not too much crouton inside, cheese all over the bowl and toasted nicely.  Perfect gratin.  Excellent savoir.  Lots of broth.  Not too many onions.  Overflowing and spilling all over the soup charger when you crack into it.  Best balance of onion soup ingredients in a bowl in SF for sure.  Not like a chowder like often results even when I make the stuff.  

My wife had the mussels and the tarragon was completely blowing the dish away. Cream in mussels is already pushing it for me but the tarragon was a deal breaker for me at this point.  No mussel envy as I ate my entire steak frite salad.  I think even the compound butter on my steak had tarragon but it was not killing the steak which I happily ate up with a side of french mustard.  I love steak frite salad.  I think it is one of my favorites.  The steak here was a bit on the smaller side no more than 8oz. for sure.  Trimmed more than I like but it was good.  Excellent Frites.  Good salad.

My wife loves dessert so she ordered one for each of us.... I ordered a Chimay and they brought and poured me a Duvel.  No complaints from me but, heyo?

The creme brulee was good to excellent.  Vanilla beans on the bottom and all.  Snappy and not too eggy with a strawberry garnish.  

The Chocolate mousse was excellent.  I took one bite of it and the whole meal pretty much kicked in and I was KO'ed for the night.  I slept so good after this meal.  Better than I had in a long time.  That says a lot.  I will be back for sure to try their brunch maybe.  The photos of the Steak with a slice of foie look incredible.  

With tip we easily spent over $200 eating like royalty.  

I will be back for the $22 prix fix chefs choice menu for sure as well.  Good value I would have to think for this level of food.
author: Johnny B.

description:
So, Yelped brunch and stumbled upon this little Bistro, hidden by Chestnut area. Really hidden, thanks to y'all Yelpers I found my favorite little French Bistro in I left my heart in San Francisco. 

We sat outside not minding the light chill or wispy mist sometimes drops of rain would gently tap the canopy above our wobbly table, just like in France. 

Evian to start out with, followed by: 

Oeufs Baker Street Bistro (Dave's favorite) Who is Dave? 
and why does he get his name on as HIS 
favorite? :)  May I suggest changing to  " Sugar and Spice's" favorite! ;)

If I were an Oeufs, I would have found my soul-mate Baker street Bistro. 
Ratatouille, mild yet flavorful marinara sauce with grilled bell peppers, a little aubergines added perhaps, served over 2 perfectly poached eggs set in the center of 2 halved English muffin, which have been drizzled with ratatouille.  Savoring every bite.........................yummmmmyyyyyyy

I can brunch here every Sunday! 

Brunching while watching the working girls go by.... should be a song.
author: Michelle A.

description: I was going to try to have breakfast at Home Plate but wasn't willing to wait for 45 mins for a table. Found this little place near the Presidio and I love it. Quaint little bistro with outdoor sitting. Love the decor loved my breakfast. My server was great. The menu is very simple but after having my breakfast I'm sure the rest is great as well. Definitely will come back to try the rest of it
author: Jack B.

description: Worst customer service ever! Even though Yelp said they are open we arrived 1o minutes earlier than their closing. Times with two little kids completely hungry & they refused to serve us saying Mitch was close 5 minutes b4!!!! Really????!!!! & we have dined there b4 & the food is just ok!!! Definitely not going back!!!!
author: Fariba R.

description:
It was my first time trying this place yesterday. Here's what we've tried so far:

1.  1/2 Dozen Escargot (Decent)
2.  1/2 Dozen Oysters (Great)
3. Foie Gras (Great)
4. Lamb Chops (The meat was cooked perfectly but lacking flavors/spices) 
5. Lamb Stew (The meat was sooo tender and soft, just needed a little more salt, which was an easy fix)

I would come back to try their brunch menu and their duck leg for dinner. Aside for their food lacking a little flavor/spice/salt, their customer service were superb.
author: Rose L.

description:
Today was the 5th time I came to this restaurant to have their famous Bourride Provençal (fish stew). I was dreaming of having it, but the dream turned into a nightmare. It was awful! It's supposed to be made in a lobster broth, but that wasn't present. It was tasteless and the mussels were hard and with a bad smell (I hope I won't get sick). Obviously the chef wasn't in tonight. There was no presentation, just a glob of liquid and seafood. The table beside me received a salmon that was overcooked. 
They were kind enough to take the Bourride off the bill, but that wasn't the point. Am I going to try it again? I don't know.
So beware, make sure the chef is in when you decide to go to this restaurant.
author: Diana N.

description: Terrible service - makes you feel like you are truly in France. Food is fine, not great.
author: Rose S.

description: We really wanted to love this place.  From the time we walked in, it made such a warm impression: such a cozy and causal, family-style bistro where the staff welcomes you with a smile.  In terms of service and ambience, it was definitely 4 stars but in terms of food, it was more like 2.  Everything we had from the French onion soup and goat cheese salad to the lamb chops were a disappointment, just bland and unimpressive.  Not worth returning, just too much below par but because of the terrific service, I have to round out my rating to 3 stars.
author: Saminda W.

description: Showed up at 2:13pm for lunch and were turned away because they were closing at 2:30.   Two hungry kids in tow.   Not my idea of good service.   You shouldn't have posted hours if you're going to turn people away
author: Bree C.

description: Menu designed by Frenchman, executed by a Central American.  Out of party of 4, 2 of us sent our main courses back.  Excellent server totally understood and sympathized.  She is only reason I am giving 2 stars instead of 1.  None of us will ever go back.
author: Aloysius D.

description: Wonderful local Authentic French bistro. Great food prepared and presented with care. Nice wine list and great service make this a spot worth checking out while in SF
author: Steve B.

description: ATTITUDE! ATTITUDE!  ATTITUDE!  Who wants to walk into a restaurant and be approached by someone who could care less that you are patronizing them?  NO ONE.  The waiter with the big nose needs to go find work not working with the public.  We were seated at a table that had a folding chair card table chair that was brought in at a second thought and was uncomfortable .  If you like a pretentious crowd that think they are getting a "a good dinning experience," then this place is for YOU! It was a joke and obviously people are gullible  enough to accept 2nd rate food, service and a shabby environment for prices that are NOT CHEAP.     The food was OK, but forgettable.   I have had much better, for less at other French restaurants.  The place is tacky and dirty.   Paint pealing and base boars scrapped up.   There is tension with the staff, and you can tell they are not pleased to be working there.  We had reservations a week in advance and the place had many available tables, but they chose to put us in a table by the service station?  When asked to sit somewhere else the guy with the big nose got indignant and was not very accommodating or respectful to our request.  That is how you treat a customer?  Sorry, there were many options, but the guy chose to be nasty.   We were served by three different people?  And the person who came to the table with our food, had to ASK US WHO HAD WHAT?   Overall, this place was a nightmare.  NEVER AGAIN!  STAY AWAY unless you want pretentious attitude,  and SO SO food in a dirty tacky place filled with people who are ripping you off.  Oh, Yeah, The guy that was our waiter is "pictured" LOOK AT PIC POSTS)  AS CHEF?????  HMMMMM?   WHAT IS THAT ALL ABOUT?  BY THE WAY HE LEFT AT PRIME TIME SEATING, NEVER SAYING A WORD TO US????  WAITER??? CHEF????  WHO WAS HE?  BUT AVOID THIS PLACE IF YOU DO NOT WANT TO GET ATTITUDE AND SO, SO,  FOOD....WITH A NOT SO WORTH IT TAB!
author: Tom S.

description:
We went there for a birthday and were really, really impressed by this little place. I started with the salmon tartare and then had the steak tartare, and my boyfriend had the onion soup and the duck confit. We finished with the creme brulee, which was easily the best I've had. All around, the food was amazing, and the wine list had a great variety of french wines by the glass, half bottle, and bottle. Plus, it was easy to snag a reservation on OpenTable! 

You must check this place out! We'll definitely be back.
author: Molly P.

description:
This review is for brunch only. 2.5 stars but rounding down due to the service.

My friend called ahead to make reservations since we had a party of 7, but they apparently don't take reservations for Saturday. They did say we shouldn't have a problem, and we were seated right away at noon. It was busy, but they have outdoor seating available as well do it didn't seem like people had to wait long to be seated. However, the service once we were sat was a different story. It took them over half an hour to take our order, and although we were chatting and catching up with each other, there wasn't much of an opportunity to flag anyone down. I was also missing a place setting, and had to ask a couple of times before someone brought me a knife and fork. After we finally ordered, the drinks took at least ten mintues before arriving, and the food took about 20 minutes after that. The dishes I tried were:

-Oeufs Copenhague (Smoked Salmon, Poached Eggs, English Muffin, Hollandaise Sauce, $13.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baker-street-bistro-san-francisco?select=Y9nn31cJsirVhLhB36xd7Q#RjFVAY2fWo08QbcVIH8FEQ): Pretty good but not amazing. The smoked salmon got lost underneath the hollandaise, but the english muffin was soft and fluffy. I enjoyed the potatoes, but not all of them were cooked enough and/or crispy enough.
 -Steak à Cheval (Steak & Egg, $24, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baker-street-bistro-san-francisco?select=Y9nn31cJsirVhLhB36xd7Q#_9kQsoDXUu_n9xBbjCeb7w): This dish is priced as $18.50 on the website, but I'm pretty the price was increased $24. For $24, I wouldn't recommend this dish. The cut of steak wasn't quality, and it was chewy and gristley. Not recommended.
-Pain Perdu (Two Slices of Cinnamon French Toast, Fresh Fruit, Strawberry Coulis & Crème Fraîche, $11.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baker-street-bistro-san-francisco?select=Y9nn31cJsirVhLhB36xd7Q#Y9nn31cJsirVhLhB36xd7Q): Listed as "A brunch favorite" on the menu, I was very underwhelmed by their version of French toast. Again, it was good, but not amazing. However, the presentation was nice, with the strawberry coulis in heart shapes on the creme fraiche. They needed a bit more sauce though, since the pain perdu was on the dry side. 
-Moules Provençale (Mussels, White Wine, Shallots, Parsley, Tomato & Pesto, $19, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baker-street-bistro-san-francisco?select=Y9nn31cJsirVhLhB36xd7Q#AMbv2hk1gN0_vq_6NQAqRw):
Listed as the "Best mussels in town!" on their menu, this I would believe. They gave you a HUGE bowl of mussels, and it was a great dish to share! I also really enjoyed their white wine sauce.

Aside from the slow and lackluster service, the food overall was on the disappointing side. It seemed like the chef needed a little more help during the lunch rush since it didn't seem like he had any help in the kitchen, which was a semi-open concept. It took way too long for our food to arrive, and I wouldn't recommend dining here if you're in a rush. I wouldn't return here for lunch, but would give it a second chance for dinner provided the servers are different! Parking can also be tough in this area.
author: Amy D.

description:
We expected some phenomenal french food, but I think they fell short. The chicken way too overcooked. However the sauces on the salmon and chicken were amazing.

Some really good collection with regards to wine, but nothing here will make me go-back.
author: Akshaya M.

description: The Brunch menu is small but they do everything on the menu right. Love the eggs bene and they have the best French Fries in the city.
author: Robert L.

description:
Just got back from dinner there for our 21st Anniversary and it is now my favorite place in San Francisco. First time but will probably be back every week even though I live nowhere near.
Small quaint bistro, excellent service (Saturday night of July 4th week-end), no trouble parking and best of all: really good food. We had a bottle of Mourvedre, onion soup, salade du sud-ouest, duck confit, steak tartare, the pear tart and a shared glass of Banyuls. All of it excellent and reasonably priced! It was like being back home in France:)
author: Francoise F.

description:
This quaint little place was literally right next to my hotel, it must have been fate right?  The weather was gorgeous that morning and perfect for their outdoor patio seating.  We were the only people there at the time as it had just opened for the day so their service was fairly quick and the hostess was very friendly and attentive.   

I naturally gravitate towards any smoked salmon+poached eggs combo and their Oeufs Copenhague was just what I had in mind. Their home fries were a nice addition to the meal along with the mixed greens. I wish I tried more off their menu but for a no-fuss breakfast early in the morning, this was a lovely place.
author: Alice N.

description:
Thank you Check Please!

My wife & I visited Baker Street last night. We're always on the hunt for a good restaurant that's convenient for theater night. We live in Sonoma County and come down at least once every 4 to 6 weeks to go to ACT on Geary. Finding a place that is easily accessible with good parking options is a must. What's great about this location is that it's just off of Lombard after we cross the bridge, giving us a predictable amount of drive time to the theater afterwards.

We didn't make reservations and came early for a 5:45 dinner to make a 7:00pm show. We were warmly greeted by the chef/owner (in French) and I felt immediately at home in a Paris café.

Although tempted to order the Prix Fixe menu, my wife ordered the Foie Gras entrée and Salmon plat, while I ordered the French Onion for my entrée and the special of Cassoulet Toulousain (I really love Duck Confit) for my main course. We also both enjoyed some French wines by the glass with each of our meals. The food was exactly what we expected - simply delicious!

Service was very un-Paris-like, being quick and efficient, including getting our bill at the end. I say this in tongue & cheek, because we had a limited amount of time and a play to go to. We never felt rushed throughout, the food was excellent and what we expected; a great start to a fun evening.

Merci Beaucoup - I can't wait to return to order other items from the menu, including some Foie Gras for myself. This will definitely be in our dinner rotation from now on, please don't change a thing!
author: Jon P.

description: Really mediocre French food. Beef bourgignon, mussels and steak tartare were just not tasty. Although big portions. Good fries. Ile flotante too heavy. Great service and very cute though.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Heard about this place from Check Please! Bay Area. Came here on a Saturday night around 7:30pm, and it was packed. We did have a reservation for 8pm, but we thought we could try getting in early. Initially, I thought the service was bad because when we walked in, no one greeted us for a few minutes and the busboy kept bumping into me. Granted, it was busy, but i would have liked an acknowledgement. We were able to get a table in about 10 min, as many of the tables were finishing up. I guess it's best to come at 8pm, as i saw many of the tables stayed empty.

The menu was simple and not overwhelming. The decor was rustic, but i didn't think it was that romantic. Also, it was too loud for it to be romantic.

What we ordered: 
~Raw salmon: I thought this was going to be like a sashimi or ceviche, but it was mixed in a creamy dressing. Nonetheless, it was wonderful!
~Grilled lamb chops: The potato gratin was so yummy. It was a like a mashed potato with a perfectly seared top of parmesan cheese. The lamb chops were cooked to medium rare perfection.
~Traditional seafood stew cooked in lobster broth with squid, shrimp, mussels, salmon, fennel, leeks, tomato, pesto, garlic, served with aioli toast: LOVED this, very seafoody (in a good way) with generous portions.
~Creme Brulee: This was the deciding factor. I love creme brulee, so i'm a bit of a snob. This was perfectly creamy, not too sweet. The sugar top was thick enough so that it didn't just fall apart. wonderful!
~Cappuccino: I didn't try this, but my husband liked it
bill came out to about $90 before tip.

Pros: generous portions, cute place, every item we ordered tasted awesome, casual... despite the cons below, I will be coming back!

Cons: expensive, horrible parking, off with the service that day, bread that we got before the meal was hard and cold, loud, not romantic
author: Nancy F.

description: Based on yelp review, I took my mom here for sunday dinner yesterday.  We had  Salade de Chèvre Chaudand, Bourride Provençale, Traditionnel Boeuf Bourguignon accompanied by mascato wine.  It was delicious!    We are certainly coming back here.  The service was great.
author: Sona K.

description:
Check Please! got it WRONG!

I like many of you watched last night's episode and before the segment was over I booked a reservation for tonight based on the rave reviews. 

Well we just returned and to sum it up in two words: Overpriced and Underwhelming.

Escargot was bland. Onion Soup again bland. 

Cassoulet was boring and again lacked a punch - lacked the consistency of a cassoulet and was more of a soup (and not even in the same hemisphere as the ones I had in Paris). Overpriced

Beef Bourguignon was again more soupy with a HEAVY taste of red wine that was less than a heavier consistency we have been used to. Overpriced

Service was wonderful, atmosphere great and I am sure Price Fixe is a value but again the food underwhelming. I have found higher quality French food at better prices at Garcon on Valencia.
author: C K.

description: Authentic Parisian bistro.  We were sad they were out of beef  bourguignon, loved the duck confit, but found the duck  l'orange, good but not quite the smooth complexity we were looking for. The value to flavor and portioning was excellent, right along with the service!
author: Greg F.

description: This place is charming, service was excellent, food was delicious and decent prices !  Very happy we found it !
author: Mellissa H.

description: In San Francisco on business I checked Yelp for dinner and found Baker Street Bistro nearby. I ordered the prix fixe special. On this particular evening the special was essentially shepherd's pie -- ground beef in an herb-flavored gravy all hidden under mashed potatoes. In other words, not fancy. But with first-rate execution. Highly recommended.
author: Chris K.

description:
I've had three outstanding dinners at Baker Street Bistro over the last few years, and my latest experience was every bit as good as the first.  This is classic French bistro fare that is consistent and tasty, and a place I know the missus will enjoy anytime. Gold stars all around.

Food:
I've enjoyed the Onion soup, Moules Poulette, Escargots, Charcuterie Plate, Navarin d'Agneau (lamb stew), Tournedos (beef tenderloin), grilled lamb chops, and smoked duck breast salad. My favorites are the charcuterie plate, the grilled lamb chops, and the smoked duck breast salad. One talented chef cranks out all of these dishes and more, night after night, with precision and care.  Perfectly-balanced dishes with loads of flavor.  We usually start with champagne and move on down the wine list which includes some nice chardonnays and Bordeaux. 

Service:
Always excellent, including the time we had to wait an extra 30 minutes even though we had a reservation, because we were given complimentary glasses of wine and thanked for our patience.  The servers give great recommendations in case you aren't sure what will work with your choices, so no need to fear the wine list.  Really great service.

Vibe:
Eat-and-drink-the-night-away-chic.  Time seems to stop when we go to Baker Street, and all I want to do is order yet another bottle of wine and another charcuterie plate.  Outdoor seating is great on a sunny day, with heaters perfect for chilly nights. Dress up if you like, or not; it doesn't really matter.

Family-friendly:
Seulement si les enfants adorent la cuisine Francaise.  But if they aren't into French food, either bring them for brunch or just leave them at home and save Baker Street for date night.

Summary:
Baker Street is one of a few restaurants that has restored my faith in French Bistro fare, and for that I am thankful.  I always leave happy, and I want to come back. Which I will do again and again.
author: Aneesh B.

description: After following the reviews for two years and finally being in the area, I wanted so much to love this place.  Service was welcoming, attentive and accommodating since we didn't have a reservation.  Repeat faithful customers evident through out the evening.  But we found the food underwhelming, bland or unusual combination of flavors.  The seared foie gras wonderfully presented but lacked the customary rich buttery taste.  The cassoulet with duck leg confit was made with an unusually sweet tomato sauce and the duck overly dry.  However, the sausage and a preserved ham was tasty.  The French onion soup was the saving grace of the night.  Tasty broth, lovely melted cheese, and croutons well done garnish.  The pan seared duck breast lovely presented but again lacking flavor or crispy skin.  Given the high reviews we may have ordered the wrong entrées such as the many orders of mussels we saw.  Perhaps next time.
author: Julia S.

description: Great brunch on a Sunday morning. The coffee was perfect. The hollendaise was just right.
author: Bee P.

description:
Kind of an old fashioned French place with consistent food. If you order steak rare it will come rare. French onion soup is really good, and a pretty good wine selection. 
Service is always lovely.  I adore the creme brûlée- not too eggy.
No hipsters in sight. 
You could have a meal at Chez Papa that's about the same price, with slightly better food, but not the same kind of experience. I'm giving Baker St. four stars because it offers really nice, relaxed dining....Place to go to have dinner, a conversation, and linger over coffee/dessert without  pressure to give up your table.
author: El B.

description:
Very nice people, very nice food. I had the steak tartare (I'm a big fan of tartare, so I usually am a little picky). Well, It was really good. This place serves real every day French food, and it's a pleasure. 

Source: I'm French.
author: Antoine M.

description:
English Review : first time at the Baker Street bistro :) it was amazing ! 
The food was delicious we rediscover our French tastes with the moules Paulette and the confit de canard ! Delicious ... 
The atmosphere is very friendly. We went for our anniversary and they put a candle on our dessert, so kind ! 
The waitress was adorable !
In conclusion it's the perfect restaurant of your are a French cuisine lover ! 
Bring your friends they gonna love it ! 
Ambiance is casual :) 
Outside table ! 

Revue Française : français en manque de bonne cuisine de notre terroir, nous recherchons une bonne adresse a prix raisonnable et dans une atmosphère not too fancy ! Au Baker street bistro, nous avons trouver une cuisine authentique et sincère ! 
Les propriétaires sont français et sont très sympathique ! 
C'est un restaurant a faire découvrir a nos amis américains :) 
Le petit plus : réservation téléphonique et service en français si le cœur vous en dit ! 
Vous pouvez profiter de la terrasse :)
author: Laura B.

description:
I called ahead and told them this was a first date.  Scored the window seat.  Very romantic.  Service is excellent; attentive but no pressure.  I was surprised to see foie gras on the menu as it was banned in SFO for awhile; seared to perfection.  Scallops and Salmon dishes were perfectly prepared.  Evey my Napa Chardonnay bias was neutralized by an exceptional Puligny-Montrachet, Louis Latour Chartonnay from France.

Great place to eat well and fall in love while taking a walk through the Presidio in the evening fog.
author: Barry G.

description:
I was excited to brunch at Baker St. Bistro, a cute little neighborhood place with outdoor seating, a French proprietor, a simple yet delicious brunch menu, and some great company to enjoy my first meal in SF.  The menu consists of a variety of 5 eggs benedict, the croque monsieur or croque madame, a variety of salads and a few entree plates of mussels and a few other options.

We get quickly sat and handed our menus. We wait, we wait a little bit more, we still wait a little bit more (but, all this was somewhat  ok since conversation was flowing and we were having fun albeit being thirsty).  We put in our orders.  The food came out pretty fast. The fruit plate ($9) was fresh and good but teeny tiny and I wasn't impressed.  The boyfriend ordered the croque madame, boasting this may be the best croque madame he has ever had although he pretty much says that daily about almost anything that is really good. Regardless, it was a damn good croque. 
 
My eggs benedict were regular; nothing different or amazing but, the kicker were the potatoes that came with the dish. These potatoes were flavorful yet, they were cold and hard almost inedible (although I did eat them, since I eat everything that is put in front of my face clearly). These babies definitely seemed as if they were sitting around in the back for an hour or so. The coffee was nothing amazing and it took the waitress or bus boy about 30 minutes to come by and actually refill those mugs.  We waited for what seemed to be a lifetime for our check and I finally just went up to the proprietor (who seemed to be the only waitress) and gave her my credit card. I seriously think there was one waitress/hostess and one busser for this busy somewhat largish restaurant.  The service faltered.

Overall the food was at about a 3.5 type meal (I typically round up) but, the service brought this meal down to a solid 3 stars.  I'm a visitor to this delicious city so I have way too many other places to try than to come back to this place again.  Sorry Baker St Bistro, I will not be back not even for that delicious croque madame.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
One of the best French restaurant in SF. I had the warm Goat cheese salad and mussels for entree and the duck leg confit for my main course. One of my friends got the baked snails and it was very good!

The goat cheese salad was very good. It had ward fried goat cheese on top of the salad. The mussels were ok, I wan't impressed. But the confit duck leg was AMAZING!
author: Siavash N.

description:
Came here for the first time specifically for the french toast. What's different here is that they add a berry coulis with creme fraiche in addition to the syrup, which is delicious to dip! Plus a generous pile of cut fruit. Ask for the syrup on the side, though; mine felt drenched. 

There's cute outdoor seating that we would try on a warmer day.
author: Susan H.

description: Fabulous place on Bakers street. Hike in presidio on Lyons steps. Then kick back and enjoy the bistro. Good service and easy parking during lunch.
author: Krish C.

description:
This place is so quintessentially San Francisco. Good thing you get to make reservations here otherwise we would never have gotten seated. 

As you can probably tell from the other reviews, the food is pretty amazing. I got the Oeufs Benedicte (Canadian Bacon, poached eggs, English Muffin, Hollandaise sauce) and Alex A. got the Croque Monsieur (Ham & melted Swiss cheese in toasted pain de mie with béchamel sauce). They were both amazingggg. If you don't like cheese, though, stay away from the Croque Monsieur and the Croque Madame.

For dessert, we got to try the Tarte Tartin à la Poire (Warm pear tart, strawberry coulis) and Crème Brulée with our cousins. The desserts were pretty huge, especially the Crème Brulée. It was so yummy, but I recommend sharing it with your party.  

One thing - The service was adequate, but not very good. They were very accommodating with the baby in our party, but they took forever to get us our dessert menu and check.
author: Jamie C.

description: I made a reservation via opentable for Baker Street Bistro for 4 of us. 20 min before our reservation (on a Friday night) they call to cancel our reservation. They said it was opentable's fault. Now we have nowhere to go, everywhere is booked. Thanks.
author: Brooke S.

description: Finally a French restaurant that doesn't empty your wallet and isn't pretentious.  We split the escargot starter and seafood stew.  Both were done to perfection.  Highly recommend this place.
author: Judy C.

description: Solid neighborhood find. I came across this place when I had a craving for brunch food, but didn't want to wait massive lines. I ordered the French Toast, my husband got the Croque Monsieur. The Croque Monsieur was definitely the way to go!
author: Joyce C.

description: This place is awesome where waitress is very friendly and greets you in french. Food was great and a lot. Love this place and would go back again.
author: Luby S.

description:
Two outstanding orders of the Moules were the highlight here. They were small and sweet with great sauces and the frites were wonderful. The serving size was very generous.

We found a few of the side items to be rather bland and uninspiring. A glass of wine had an 'open-too-long' flat taste to it and the coffee was simply a half-notch above Folger's.

I would not categorize this place as an outstanding value (except for a $20 prix-fixe menu during the week), however it is worth the ticket.

All-in-all a nice experience and we will certainly be back.
author: George S.

description: Great neighborhood bistro where you'd feel comfortable dining alone.  If you get seated inside, it almost feels like you are in Montmartre in France.    Without any fancy stuff, this places offers the most 'French' experience you can have in the city.
author: Peaceful S.

description:
2.5 stars. Lovely little spot, great ambiance, cute neighborhood. From the first moment you walk in, the one waiter/hostess/owner? sets the tone with an aggressive "Can I help you?" as if you've pig-headedly wandered into her home. 

For brunch, the menu is so petite that what is there better be spectacular- your choices: pain perdu (french toast), mussles, eggs benedict (and variations), salad or croque monsieur (ham/swiss sandwich). 

We had: The eggs benedict and the croque monsieur. 

Our friends had the eggs florentine and the french toast, so we pretty much had the menu covered (my sandwich came with a salad). 

The sandwich was good but nothing to write home about. Ham, melted swiss, butter and fresh bread. The salad was a small bunch of greens with a non-descript almost un-tasteable dressing. 

The french toast was apparently decently good, but my friend couldn't stop talking about how disappointing it was to have fancy, expensive french toast without real maple syrup.

The menfolk seemed contented with their eggs.

The french fries *were* spectacular, but that was about all that was. The coffee was strong and flavorful as well.

However, it got quite crowded for a small joint, and apparently the do-it-yourselfer owner/manager doesn't want to pay for another waiter. So there was a lot of waiting on our part, and not a lot of good service on hers. Mostly it was intermittent "I'll get there when I get there" interactions with her, and 30 minutes of empty coffee cups, 50 minutes before our food came sortof experience.

And the place isn't cheap.

Wouldn't recommend.
author: Nadia H.

description:
I had a terrible experience here - the only thing that saved this joint from one (or no) stars was a friendly and attentive wait staff,

Where to begin?  Well, let's start not with the food but with the ambiance, a funky "Paris-bistro" decor marred only by the unwillingness of the oh-so-trendy couple who were unwilling to even suggest to their bratty hooligan 8-year old that he restrain himself. "Isn't he cute, climbing the bar and spilling the drinks?"  "Isn't he precocious, opening the door with the handicapped push-plate - and keeping it open so all that nice, cool fog could come into the restaurant?"  Until my wife yelled at the little monster to close the door!  Some people have no courtesy.  Or common sense.  Of course, when they (finally) left they were replaced by a group of millennials who were unbelievably loud - I'm sure there were a few in Burlingame that didn't hear them.

It would have helped if the restaurant staff politely suggested that such behavior could, just possibly, interfere with the other guests' enjoyment of the premises but maybe that's a bridge too far.

So, let's get on to the food.  I had the boeuf bourguignon.  It's a dish I've made dozens of times and enjoyed in bistros all over the world.  Not here.  First of all, the beef was tough and flavorless, sure signs of it having sat on the stove, simmering, for the better part of hours.  The dish tasted strongly of celery and undercooked wine, which tells me the chef doesn't have a clue about how and when to add his aromatics.  It was as insipid a dish as I've ever had, an effort that my children could easily surpass.

I'd love to tell you that my wife's scallops were better but I'd be lying if I did.  She was presented with a beautiful plate but the scallops were brutally overcooked.  What flavor was left was sharp and astringent, with a tough and unforgiving texture. They were presented on a puree of potatoes and broccoli, which I thought was a rather odd combo for scallops - and it didn't work.

The only dish at the table was our dinner companion's steak frittes - it's pretty hard to screw that up.  And, no, we didn't accept the dessert offerings.

I dined here maybe 20 years ago and remembered it as being half decent.  Today, I'd cut that 50% by 90%.  Not Recommended.
author: robert l.

description:
I love this place. A bit of a cliche to say this, I know, but it takes me back to sitting at a cafe on Rue Cler in Paris, sipping wine and watching the world go by. On those fabled sunny SF days, you have to sit outside on "la terrasse."

Order some eggs benedict, croque madame, duck, or short rib. Everything will be cooked true to classic French style -- in lots and lots of butter. The meat will always be tender and the eggs perfectly poached (there's something to be said about a place that can poach eggs properly...) And yet it's an unpretentious place. You won't find any "new-French" or fusion dishes here. It's just classic bistro fare, nothing more, nothing less. Like a Parisian girl, Baker Bistro doesn't worry about being stylish because she knows she already is. 

"Mangez bien, riez souvent, aimez beaucoup."
author: Cathy S.

description: After a trip to the North Bay we got back into the city and wanted a spot for brunch so we stopped at Baker Street Bistro.  It was a great day so we couldn't get a seat outside but there was plenty of room inside.  They didn't have any highchairs so we had to have our son sit on the bench but it was fine and he did well (although he did leave quite a bit of crumbs).  I ordered the smoked salmon and poached eggs.  It was pretty good but nothing I haven't had before.  My wife got the french toast and felt the same way...good but not great.
author: Blake B.

description: After years of walking by this bistro, I decided to give it try. It's Sunday and cold, what better a night to have delicious French food. For a small neighborhood spot, it gives larger more established places a run for their money. The wine list is fantastic and in addition to the menu, the waiter advised us of 6 specials of the evening. From the onion tart to the chocolate dessert, everything tasted fantastic. Priced well considering the quality and attention that goes into each entree, a new must go to favorite.
author: Thomas B.

description:
Been here twice now and I crack up everytime. (will explain shortly)

First of all this is one of the closest restaurant to Palace of Fine Arts / Exploratorium.  So if you are looking for a place to dine before an evening show / event, definitely check it out.  You can park around here, eat then walk over to Palace of Fine arts / Exploratorium quite easily.

Cute french restaurant with real French server (not sure if he's the owner?)

Their early dinner pre fixe menu (for $18.50) is a REAL BARGAIN.

Four of us went and we all decided to have the prefixe menu.  

Baguette & butter. Your standard fare. 

Soup of the day: Cauliflower soup.  A little spicy and a little bland but not bad.

Main: Pork chop with white beans.  Nothing spectacular but not bad either.  It was cooked just right.  Oh and it came with a side of salad. 

Dessert: Chocolate Mouse cake with cream and strawberries.  How can you ever go wrong with chocolate?

The portions were JUST RIGHT for a pre fixe menu.  Their non pre-fixe entrees looked a lot bigger - but with 3 courses we really didn't need any more food than what was given to us. 

Now for the fun part.  If you like medium to sweet white wine, be sure to ask "What are your sweeter wines?".  He'll say "We have no sweet wines".  (last time I went with some girlfriends he elaborated and said that only dessert wines are supposed to be sweet - with a face that could be interpreted as "you ignorant americans" haha)  

Basically if you like your white wine sweet / medium - you are out of luck.  So unless you want to be told no, don't bother asknig.  OR ask the question, just to hear his response above. It's actually pretty funny.
author: Sujan H.

description: Love this place. It is great French fare that hits the spot. Great for brunch as well. Attentive service. It is not fancy French, and does not try to be. Rather it is what would expect in any good French brasserie or...bistrot!
author: Christophe B.

description:
Home away from home. My favorite brunch go to in SF. The staff is friendly as can be. Atmosphere is chill
With outdoor indoor options. Menu always appeals to all the senses. Enjoy your coffee and indulge!
author: Shannon P.

description: I came here for dinner on Valentine's Day cuz I saw good reviews on Yelp. I ordered the steak and my gf got the lamb chops. The food was okay. With the price u paying, u can go somewhere else to get better steak. Price wasn't that expensive. Service wasn't great. I asked for ketchup for my fries and they didn't even bring it to me. They didn't even come back and ask if everything was okay. The shady part was that they charged me 20% gratuity automatically. Charging 20% gratuity for poor service and a party of 2? U gotta be fckng kidding me. Good thing I work at a restaurant too so I checked the bill. And they didn't even tell me that the gratuity was in there. When restaurants charge u gratuity automatically, it usually a group of 6 or more, but again all restaurants are different. But what they suppose to do is to tell the guests that he gratuity are included. And it usually 15% or 18%. It was really shady of them charging 20% gratuity. I will not come back here again.
author: H R M.

description:
It was fine, but I won't be back. My fiance and I went here because we were going to a show at the palace of fine arts theater nearby, and we wanted a place to eat dinner within walking distance. we arrived at 5:30pm on a saturday and the place was empty - which is understandable that early, but even by 6:30/7 when we left the crowd hadn't picked up (only 2 more parties of 2 came in), so it seems like perhaps others feel similarly underwhelmed by this place.

Waiter was nice enough, he was French, which helped make the bistro experience a bit more authentic. But the menu wasn't that impressive, and neither was my risotto. I'm Italian so I'm used to my risotto as more of a heartier dish, but this was almost like a soup - I've never been served risotto with a spoon, but again, that could just be my culinary ignorance as I'm used to Italian style risotto. That aside, I just wasn't that impressed by the flavors, and the temperature was so hot that I burned my tongue on the first bite, and couldn't really taste much after that.

I didn't dislike this place enough to say "stay away," but I also won't be recommending it or going back. I also think it should have "$$$" dollar signs on Yelp instead of $$, the entrees are pretty pricey, considering half of their menu are "specials of the day" which range from mid $20s-30s.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Dreadful, phony food. Definitely in the top 10 worst meals I have ever experienced. The mashed potatoes seemed like the flakes you add water to, and the chocolate moose was definitely the Jello type product.
author: james b.

description: Fabulous brunch and delicious Croque Madame! No problem getting a table for two on a Sunday afternoon. Service was good. Seating is a bit tight in that you could easily take something off your neighbor's plate. Maybe that's not a bad thing considering the quality of the food. Would love to go back and already know what I'll have...
author: Elizabeth Q.

description:
Celebrate wedding anniversary at the Bistro and was very pleased.

The Onion Soup is the best I've ever had! Umame without over doing the salt- perfect.

Duck confit was delicious. 

Excellent recommendation on the wine.
author: Johnny P.

description:
This is a charming bistro on a charming street. Located at the doorstep of the Presidio, this quiet spot is situated away from the rest of the Marina madness. No obnoxious brunch crowd trying to impress other obnoxious people. This is a bistro for neighborhood families.

I've only had brunch there, but I think that's a good way to judge a restaurant. The eggs in the Eggs Benedict were cooked perfectly. The english muffin was toasty and crisp. My only complaint was the hollandaise was a little on the thin side and almost separating. 

The potatoes are definitely a dissapointment. I would have preferred meatier potatoes with the brown edges that you'd expect with roasted potatoes. At the very least, you expect it to be seasoned with salt and cracked pepper. 
A little bit of dried herbs doesn't cut it. At the $15 price point, I expect more from a breakfast dish. 

The service is friendly and speedy. Although the French guy (owner?) could be friendlier. The decor looks like it hasn't been changed for 30 years. They have a bedsheet covering the bathroom window. There's no wait on weekends so that's a plus, but maybe there's a reason for that. 

If the owners just cared a little bit more, this place could be amazing. But they let important details slip by and that makes it a so-so place. But I will come back to try their lunch and dinner. Maybe that's where they shine.
author: William B.

description: The mussels were perfect.  Plump and not the least but over cooked.  There was a ton of them in the bowl too. Could really go for some now. Mmmmm.
author: Alison H.

description:
We came across Baker Street Bistro after an intense duck watching session at the nearby Palace of Fine Arts.  Ran in with less than 30 mins before they were set to close brunch, but the staff was more than happy to take us in.

I shared a ham and melted swiss baguette sandwich that was simple and clean tasting.  Even with the melted cheese there wasn't grease or oil dripping out or soaking the bread.  The other part of my meal was a bowl of granola and yogurt topped with a load of fruit.  (Tasted even better being the first healthy thing I had eaten in three days.)

The whole experience was perfect for a Sunday brunch on the run, and if I lived nearby I'd be back in a heartbeat.
author: Cory M.

description: We stopped here for breakfast and were very impressed.  It's small and we got there just in time to avoid the rush.  We both ordered the French Toast and it was AMAZING.  Probably the best I've ever had.  So glad we stopped in, and I will be going back!
author: Kristy C.

description: 5 Stars only for their Croque Madame and Monseiur. Baker Street Bistro makes such a great Croque Monseiur with bechamel sauce and toasted cheese.
author: Vhalerie L.

description: Very busy and popular bistro, escargots were ok. Coquille st joques were not  edible ,everyone else in the place seems happy
author: Paul G.

description: Delicious French bistro - they have the classic brunch foods but also a lot of cool twists on the classic egg dishes. Got the Croque Madame, which was delicious but huge and not for the faint hearted. My friend got a really cool salad, and there was definitely a lot I would want to try next time. All in all a nice stop close to the presidio for anybody in the area!
author: Rachel F.

description: Excellent  food, service, and reasonably priced. Beautiful day to sit outside. The Chocolate mouse was to die for.  Although the the tables were slanted due to the sidewalk, it just added to the ambiance. I would definitely recommend it.
author: Michelle M.

description: Service is really slow. I waited for an hour to get the food. Whats worse, they over charged me for the tips. Remember to check your credit card statement! I will give zero star if I am able to.
author: Peter L.

description: We came from Benicia because Check, please! gave this place such a glowing review.  The decore was quaint and had atmosphere.  The service was attentive but - the food!  It should be the star of the bistro but I found it lacking.  Maybe the real cook works a fabulous dinner but our lunch was nothing to write home about.  The snails were less than mediocre because even though they were very oily, you couldn't find a buttery taste and the garlic was missing.  My friend liked her dish of duck confitte (the potatoes were better than the duck) but my fish stew was almost lukewarm and had dried parsley swimming on top.  It seemed that they warmed up last nigth's stew. So bland.  The two tiny roasted pieces of bread were the freshest and tastiest part of the meal.  At this price, it would have been nice to get spoiled by fresh parsley!  Well, so much for the glowing reviews of Check, please.
author: Brigitte K.

description:
The cute atmosphere alone should warrant a decent review, really, it's an adorable French Bistro. Having lived in France at one point, it was a nice reminder of the style, cuisine, and language (yes, I got to speak french with our waitress :)

All in all I'd say this place was between ok and good. To drink, we had the house Cote de Rhone. Smooth and simple, it was ok. For an appetizer, we shared a crocket of french onion soup. Again, ok. The swiss was a bit overpowering, the crouton insubstantial, but the broth was good. Also, it was quite small. I don't think I would order it again.

For our meal I went for the Salmon special which was served over spinach and a carrot puree and the boy got the NY steak. Mine was quite good. The salmon perfectly cooked, and paired well with the spinach and carrot puree, though I'd say the puree was a bit sweeter than I cared for. The NY steak was pretty standard. He asked for it medium rare, but it came out a little more medium with moments of medium rare. Too much gristle for my liking, but he was satisfied. Also, as any good NY steak should, it came with french fries, which kept him happy.

The desert menu didn't really impress and I thought it was a bit pricey, so we skipped it.

Overall a nice experience, but for the price, and lack of bang, likely not a place I'll go running back to.
author: Krista S.

description: Came here for brunch here recently. Had the ratatouille benedict and tasted the soup du jour and the French toast. The benedict was very nice - sometimes I find people make ratatouille too strongly "herbed" (rosemary/thyme), but this was perfectly seasoned and worked well with the eggs. The hollandaise sauce was nice too. The soup was fine, nothing of note. The French toast had a very nice texture - crispy and chewy on the outside and soft but not mushy on the inside. The slices were not really thick cut, so it was nice to eat.
author: Manjesh N.

description: This is a nice neighborhood French restaurant. The food is very well prepared and tasted very good. I'll definitely be back to this place. Delicieuse!
author: Kochia S.

description:
I come here on Sundays for their brunch and their french toast is to die for. Their omelets are also so freaking amazing. 

I highly recommend coming to this place for brunch and trying either of those items!

It is a little bit pricy compared to other brunch places, but well worth it!
author: Robert R.

description:
Tucked in a less traveled corner of Cow Hollow flanked by dive bars like Liverpool Lil's and Final Final, Baker Street Bistro is a véritable restaurant de voisinage (true neighborhood restaurant).

Since 1991, Baker Street Bistro has been turning out classic French bistro food.  Nothing fancy.  Nothing imaginative.  Nothing over-the-top.  Just simple, solid meals to the delight of Francophiles throughout The City.

Topped with rich, pan-seared foie gras and flavorful smoked duck breast, the salade du sud-ouest ($14.50) makes a simple bed of mixed greens with pine nuts sing.  Unfortunately, the chef was heavy-handed with both sesame oil and capers, overpowering the delicate flavor of the tuna in the tartare de thon (tuna tartare, $14.50).

The classic moules Provençale (mussels with white wine, shallots, parsley, tomato, and pesto, $16.50) was delicious, while the accompanying frites (fries) lacked the correct hint of golden brown, indicating slight under cooking.  Drizzled with a rich carrot and ginger wine reduction, the poulet sauté (sautéed chicken breast, $16.50) was moist and tasty, but the vegetables and mashed potato sides were nothing special.

The reasonably priced wine list is almost exclusively comprised of European selections.  A warning, however:  many wines are stored in the overly warm dining room, both making the temperature at which they are served too high and potentially jeopardizing their freshness.

Service is typically French--a little brusque, slightly hurried, and not all that friendly.  In other words, authentic.

Sure, one can find more innovation, a higher level of execution, and better service at other French bistros in the City (Chapeau!, for example), but this higher level of establishment comes with a steeper price tag.  For The City, Baker Street Bistro is a value, offering mostly well prepared food at reasonable prices.
author: CJ G.

description: The food is probably a 4.3 stars if I have to reserve the 5 star for a Michelin. They get a 5 because for a little neighborhood bistro they nail it. It's always good, warm, inviting, it's trustworthy like your favorite blanket. It doesn't pretend it's something it's not and it's great.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Quaint, cozy French spot in the Marina. Seems we covered anatidae anatomy 101: I had the seared foie gras (this was pre-ban), and my friends had the duck breast and duck confit. Lot of bird parts on the table!

No one seemed particularly impressed with their dish but me. We all agreed the duck breast lacked flavor and the confit was just average. The foie gras was, by far, the best item on the table. It wasn't served with the prettiest presentation (a bit on the oily-looking side), but it was cooked perfectly and had a gorgeous, rich flavor. I really didn't wanna share, but everyone kept reaching for my beloved soon-to-be-banned delicacy. It was served with apple compote and grapes. Even my fiercely anti-foie-gras/animal rights enthusiast friend dared to have a bite after I reminded her that "her people" have won the war (for now) - and she admitted it was delicious.

Overall, it was a pleasant experience to dine here. Service was alright and parking was easy to find. The food could use a little work.
author: Thy N.

description:
Absolutely loved this little place in the Marina!  There is outdoor seating as well as a modest amount of indoor seating.  There were 7 of us so we sat inside.  They don't take reservations for groups under 10, so it was a bit tricky, but it worked out just fine.

The items ordered:  eggs benedict, a ham and cheese croque, another ham and cheese on a baguette, the charcuterie plate, cheese plate and a bowl of fruit.

The benedicts were absolutely perfect.  Sauce was quite possibly the best I've ever had - hint of lemon, not too buttery. Eggs were poached to perfection.  The breakfast potatoes were quite tasty.

The charcuterie plate: various cured meats and a duck liver pate.  I couldn't stop eating the pate, and the whole plate was devoured by several of us.  There was plenty for 4 people to share.

I had very little of the cheese plate, so couldn't really speak much for that, though it did look lovely.

The croque sandwich was decadent beyond belief.  I only had 1 bite, but it was unctuous and cheesy and tasty.  The ham was sliced very thinly and I would have liked a bit more of it.

My daughter ordered the bowl of fruit.  It as the largest most beautiful array of fruit I have ever seen in a restaurant.  A wide variety of very fresh fruits.

Apparently there was no server/busboy that day so the owner (?) was dashing around wearing his stress on his sleeve.  It was unnerving and a little sad, and I say that sympathetically.  I caught his eye as he came storming in from the outside with plates in his hand.  I was sitting in such a way that could easily have been mistaken for trying to get his attention, so as he approached, he looked at me, hesitated and was about to ask if I needed anything.  I just smiled and said, "No - we're all fine."  A while later, he came back to ask if everything was ok, and my friend and I told him everything was wonderful, but that we thought he should take a moment to breathe...  He was gracious and totally got what we were saying.  While he was trying so hard to please everyone, he lost sight of the fact that he can only do one thing at a time, and no one was in a hurry to go anywhere.  At least, that was my take.  Slow down, breathe, and know it'll all get done! 

Another note:  Our usual breakfast joint in the Marina is Home Plate.  I managed to sway my husband to try a new place, and I'm SO glad to say that he loved it so much he wouldn't hesitate to go back.  Ain't nothin' wrong w/ HP, but it's just nice to have an alternative every once in a while!
author: Stephanie V.

description:
We had a party of 6 so we decided to make reservations which was a good idea because this place is small. We knew we were going to be a bit late so we called later on to move our reservations another 30 minutes. The restaurant gave us no issues with that request. No one sat outside because it was a really cold night. The place got pretty packed during our dinner.

My friend who has came to this place before told me that the menu looked quite different from the last time. Perhaps, they keep some of the stuff on the menu on all the time where as some entrees' they keep changing around.

The place is small but very cozy. The bathroom is only a onsy but it felt even that was nicely decorated. The staff was friendly.

I originally wanted the sea scallops but they ran out so the server recommended the sea bass dish which turned out really good. My friend knew I wasn't going to be full so she gave me some of her mussels and french fries which was also very delish. If you decide to get the mussels, make sure you get the fries too (it's optional for an extra $2 I think). Dip or soak the fries in the mussel sauce. Soooo good!

I think everyone was pretty satisfied with their food. We had a bottle of Pinot Grigio to compliment our dinner which was a good call. By the time, we were done with our main course we didn't have any room for dessert even though I was craving the Creme' Brulee. Had to pass because I couldn't down anything else. Also, I forgot to mention that the dinner roll was pretty good/fresh as well.

I would definitely come back here. It worked out for a party of 6 but I think this would be a good place to bring a date. It's not so loud and crazy, it's cozy, and not too too expensive.

The only issue I had with this place was that the parking sucks. You have to look for street parking. The restaurant is located in a neighborhood of houses, so parking here is pretty hard to find. We had to park about 3 blocks away up the hill.
author: Smitcha B.

description: Went here on a whim because it was close to a show I was attending. We were seated quickly, fed quickly, and it was pretty great. Genuine French menu, genuine French staff, genuine French food. I enjoyed the steak tartare (it was huge) and would love for this to be in my neighborhood, I'd eat here frequently.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I came here for a business dinner with a group of seven and had a wonderful meal. As many other Yelper's have said, this is a small, quaint, cozy place with very good french food, desserts and wines. 

I started with a goat cheese salad and freshly made bread. For my entree I had one of the specials - wild halibut with black truffles and zucchini.  It was cooked and seasoned perfectly. For dessert, chocolate mousse. It was rich, but not too heavy. 

I didn't pay for dinner, but I thought their prices were reasonable. The service was excellent and came with a french accent at no extra charge.
author: Keith D.

description: Sweet mother of pearl!  This was with the trip! The Ile Flottante.  Meringue floating in crème anglaise.  To die for!  With the price of admission!
author: Stephen P.

description: It seems like a great place, the service was great, but if you're vegan like I am, there's literally nothing to eat but the fruit cup. No non-dairy creamer, and even the salad dressing has cream.
author: Kristen H.

description: As a pescetarian, I often find French food difficult, but friends suggested we meet here.  Our space (for 5) was cozy but not uncomfortable - it's not a big place overall.  Service was impeccable - punctual but not hurried, and exceptionally friendly and helpful with recommendations, etc.  Tomato/basil soup was excellent, as was the main dish with scallops.  Nephew had fries, they were good too.  Two at our table had dessert and were happy with it.  Good experience overall.
author: Katie K.

description: Typical place where they put form over content.  Unmemorable brunch food, but with a memorable price tag. Cut outside area
author: Michal C.

description: Oh no! Service is terrible so far and we haven't even been seated yet... And it gets worse. We were treated with no consideration at all. All night. Food was mediocre. And it was a completely different experience from any we've ever had in the past fifteen years we've been visiting. Heartbreaking.
author: Kristina R.

description:
good service. Loved the french onion soup and Bordeaux.
Loved the Foie Gras.
author: g s.

description:
I met some friends here for my birthday brunch.  Hands down, the best food with no wait you can get in that area. 

My friends ran a little late so I asked to sit inside.  They had no problem with it.  I was a little surprised since I think I snagged the last 4 top.  My friends underestimated how late they'd be, so I saw a few tables clean out.  That said, they were kind to me and happily served me a mimosa while I waited.

The food is your basic French fare, but the food was absolutely delicious.  Due to the comments here, I got the French toast.  It was delicious.  When a restaurant doesn't serve it with syrup on the side, you know they've got the recipe down and exactly how much would be too much.  

My friends got a few scrambles and they both thought it was fresh and just the perfect amount.

The service was also great.  French accents WITHOUT the pretension is always welcome.  The host was kind, charismatic, and had a great smile.

Thanks for this and I'll be coming again real soon!  My new brunch place!
author: Andy S.

description: Absolutely love this place. Whenever I feel the need for classic French food served in a warm inviting place, this is where I turn. Danel (the owner and Exec Chef) brought his skill all the way from Biarritz, France to this cozy setting in Cow Hollow. He's a gem of a person and has passion for his craft. The staff has been there for many years and they know the menu up and down -- take their suggestions and you won't be disappointed. Brunch is a treat, but I really like how the place mellows out in the evening. Sitting inside or on the sidewalk, you'll feel like you've been whisked away to a bistro in Paris (minus the smoking - LOL) that only locals know about.
author: David M.

description:
Overpriced Average Food, Bad Service.

My husband and I decided to take my mom (&dad) to this place for Mother's Day brunch. My husband had Sandwich de Baguette (basically overpriced ham sandwich with some greens). The waiter gave my dad's order to me and my mom's order to my dad and my mom ended up with my plate. Our orders were similar, but not the same, so we had hoped the waiter will know which one goes where when he dropped them off. After the food was dropped off at the table, the waiter didn't bother to check if he got our orders correctly. We no longer saw him at all during the rest of the dining hour.

So, at the end, my husband went to pay the bill. He decided to not tip for the food and service that was below our expectation. The waiter then asked my husband if there was anything wrong and he told the waiter that the food was not good. My dad also told the waiter that he mixed up our orders. The waiter told my dad "Don't Come Back". My first thought was to get in front of this little man and tell him how un-professional he was, but decided to be a bigger person and write the review here instead. Needless to say, we will NEVER go back to this place. I've shared the story with some of my colleagues today too. 

We took my mom to a nice place with good food and service for dinner to make up for the bad experience at this place.
author: A R.

description:
Horrible experience in this restaurant. I agree 100% one of the reviewer's review: " service is horrible, nerve go back again ". This morning my husband took me to this small restaurant for brunch before we head to the beach. What French restaurant means ? If it is not fancy, at least cozy warm place, right ? No ! It locates right next to several big trash dumpster. 
The restaurant is not busy early this morning, only one customer at outdoor table, three customers inside. One African American with French accent behind the counter took her time to finish her drink from a big paper cup while we sat waiting for her come to us to take our order. Guess what? The server finally put down her drink cup, took a paper wiping her mouth and came to our table taking our orders without washing her hands. While we waited for our food, I watched her picked up something from the floor. I am a nurse, I cannot tolerate poor hygiene of restaurant staffs. But I did not say anything just because I don't want to ruin a good day and good mood. I just wish she is not the one serve the food. Unfortunately, this woman served our food. We ordered three dishes. Pain Perdue, eggs Benedict and mussels. Mussels tastes ok, pain Perdue looks pretty so I want to save for the last. I started to eat eggs Benedict. I found the salad is not fresh at all. 1/3 of salad of the dish is yellow, half yellow even black leaves. Obviously the salad has been a few days old. Just like you buy a big box of salad from Costco, you can't finish them all in one or two days. A few days later, you find the mixed salad go bad, you either throw them away, or at least you pick out the rotten salad, rewash the remaining one still can eat. So I picked out some yellow and rotten salad to the empty plate. I showed the salad to that server and said: " this salad is not fresh." She took the plate back to kitchen then she come back challenged me: " you said this salad not fresh ? The yellow leaves just young one " I told her that I eat salad everyday and I know what is fresh and what is not fresh. She started to argue with me with very bad attitude. My God ! Where in the world a restaurant server argued with a customer who complained the salad not fresh with obvious evidence! I asked her if she is owner or not. She said she is not. I asked her who is the chief and I want to talk to the chief instead of her. She told me the chief is not in the restaurant now. Our food were served 10 minutes ago, now the chief is not in the restaurant now ? I am very upset about her rude attitude and lie. She asked me what about the rest of salad and other food on that plate. She did not even offer exchange a plate with fresh salad. Of course, I told her that I will not eat that plate with rotten salad. She went back to kitchen and came out yelled at us with angry voice: " all the dishes is on house. Thankful for coming." Wow, she wanted us to leave. I told her that we would never come back again. She got mad like a crazy dog. She pushed the door open and yelled to us: "out, out. " basically, that server with a bad attitude instead of with a smile, that server argued with customer instead of apologizing for the bad food, that server with poor hygiene instead of wearing clean uniform and good hygiene ruined our holiday weekend. We ordered 3 plates of food and only ate half of mussels and we got kicked out. What a awful, horrible experience ! Nerve ever go back again!
Also, I noted that the restaurant' s breads and butters are just placed on a small short table along the narrow hallway close to the restroom. I can understand and accept the food table placed in the narrow hallway because of limited space, but at least use a cloth to cover the bread.
author: Yanhua L.

description: Best breakfast in the area.  Had an egg scramble with mushrooms, onions, spinach and goat cheese. Yum!
author: Kelly I.

description:
What can I say? (Qu'est-ce que je peux dire?) 

Baker Street Bistro makes the best Pain Perdu (that is Frenchified Toast to us 'mericans) I have ever had. The bread is never soggy or overcooked. It is served with an orange-infused maple syrup, and if that weren't enough, there is a small pool of crème fraîche with a strawberry coulis swirled throughout it (well, usually; today they forgot the strawberry coulis, but who cares, it is still better than anything you can get anywhere else in the City... possibly in all of the U.S. of A. even).

They have other "Brunch" items from which to choose, too; however, if you are going there for the very first time, skip the menu and just order their Pain Perdu supérieure.

If you would like to read a little more detailed take on my breakfast this morning, click on my profile and check out my stupid little breakfastary 'blog.

Bon appétit!
author: Brian M.

description:
It is hard to find a French restaurant that tastes like home and I had high hopes after reading the reviews. 

The "a-ok" rating is fair in my opinion. We had the goat cheese salad, flat iron steak and fries, oeufs meurette, Bourride Provençale.

It was good, definitely but overall underwhelming, a bit "flat". However, we had a great time there, service was great, warm and welcoming people. The restaurant has a very nice atmosphere of french bistro.

We will give it another try!
author: Meryl C.

description:
This place is great!  Very romantic place.  My husband and I were at our favorite dentists office last week and were starving by the time we got out.  She suggested stopping by Baker Street Bistro for mussels and Fries. 

This place is very quaint and romantic in a cute little street near Union.  When we stepped in, we were greeted by the chef and asked for a table of two.  The place was pretty quiet for a Wednesday evening.  I ordered the mussels and fries and my husband ordered their four course pri fixe menu which was priced affordably for under $20.  

The food was good and our waiter provided great service!  I will return whenever I'm in the area.  Loved it!
author: Christine P.

description:
Written Reviews: http://blogs.kqed.org/checkplease/2014/05/08/baker-street-bistro-reviews/

Video Reviews: http://blogs.kqed.org/checkplease/2014/05/08/baker-street-bistro-restaurant-info/
author: chris g.

description:
Mediocre food and old chintzy decor, but nice servers.
There are 4 wines offered by the glass, but for 10-11 bones per glass, pretty steep for the rather average quality.  There are certainly many better French bistro's in SF at the same price range.
author: david l.

description: Came here because of the Foie Gras and it did not dissappoint me. Yummy!! What didn't really do for me is the escargot. It wasn't that great. The french onion soup was good. Overall, service was wonderful and the food was good only a little off. Solid 4
author: Fuki D.

description: How nice to pop into a little neighborhood bistro expecting nothing only to be thoroughly charmed by everything about it! I loved the intimacy of it, the French decor, the friendly wait staff (with authentic French accents) and the delicious food beautifully presented. Had brunch there with my adult son. I had the cinnamon french toast with creme fraiche artfully decorated with strawberry sauce, and my son had the eggs benedict, which came with lovely fresh field greens. We both were in heaven! Also, as a tea drinker, I very much appreciated that my tea came in a pot of very hot water (not a mug of warm water and a tea bag). Nothing stuck up about this French restaurant; I can't wait to go back!
author: Jane H.

description: Cute little French spot.  Excellent food and ambiance.   Great date place.  I had the seafood stew and it was filled with fish and seafood.  Fantastic.  And the price was very reasonable and I eat a lot, I mean a lot!  Def a nice place and a little romantic.  Ill be back!
author: Jordan S.

description: Good for dinner, too. This is the only restaurant I have found in San Francisco that actually serves a great variety of really good French dishes, With a totaly French wine list, reasonable prices, and a very helpful waitstaff, you will not go wrong. I'll be back!
author: Cliff L.

description: Very good!  Mussels were so delicious. Creme brulee was good too. Great service. Almost felt like I was in Europe! I expected it to be a bit cheap as Yelp has two dollar signs. I would say it is about 2.5 dollar signs.
author: Lynna C.

description:
Met the wife and a friend for dinner here last night and we had a really good meal.   

Two of us got started with the Salade de Chèvre Chaud and it was excellent, with a warm walnut-encrusted patty of goat cheese.  My wife got the Salade Verte Vinaigrette and it was plain compared to ours.  

The others got the sea bass which was served in a garlicky dressing over a round patty made out of cauliflower.  SCRUMPTIOUS!   Sea bass was great, but who knew cauliflower could be so delicious?  I got the boeuf bourguignon and it was hot, tasty and filling.  Perfect for a winter evening.  

The service was French, which I love but apparently isn't for everyone.  They don't hover or bother you until you let them know you'd like something.  The food came out in a good time frame...not too fast and not too slow.  If you want to quickly scarf down a quick meal so you can get back to your busy life, then a French restaurant isn't for you.  On the other hand, if you want to enjoy a relaxing dinner with friends and converse comfortably without bullhorns, then I highly recommend Baker Street Bistro.
author: Alan F.

description:
Nice little neighborhood gem!

It's small and cozy = definitely make reservations so you're not disappointed and be prepared to rub elbows (literally) with the next table.

The service was excellent. They checked on our table numerous times to make sure our water glasses were continuously filled, asked it we needed more bread when it was down to 2 pieces and took away empty plates to make room for more food on the small tables.

I ordered the prix fix menu for $19 
- small mixed green salad - nothing special
- Beef tongue and mash potatoes - Tender and delicious! Huge portions. Highly recommended.
- fresh fruit filo dessert - yummy!

I also ordered escargots in butter. I soaked up the delicious infused butter with baguette :)

They also seated us next to the window and it was great to be so close to the outdoor without being in the cold SF evening breeze.
author: Christine T.

description:
Very uneven meal.  There was an extremely cheap four course prix fixe, but the courses were boring (spinach soup, roast pork, light salad, chocolate cake) so we opted for à la carte.  It might be good for the neighborhood, but coming from the FiDi,  I definitely wouldn't make a special trip to this place again!

Steak Tartare: A yucky tartare.  Way too tomato-y.  The waiter claimed there was no ketchup or tomato sauce involved, perhaps they just went Tabasco happy.  Despite having the traditional fixings, it was too bland and runny.
