Bourride Provençal: Very similar in style to bouillabaisse.  The toast offering was measly and missing the shredded cheese on top of the sauce.  Also, I think whole wheat was a bad choice to soak up the broth.  I didn't like how the salmon filet was in tiny chunks as opposed to a single large piece.  The shrimp were small and tough, a sign of being overcooked.  It came with some risotto on the side which tasted more like a French-style fried rice as opposed to a typical creamy risotto.  

Cod Potato Dish: Forgot the name, but it was basically shredded cod in a mashed potato base covered in cheese.  Liked that the cod was fresh as opposed to salted.  Tasty in a buttery/creamy/cheesy way, though bland otherwise. 

Lamb Stew: Not memorable.  Tender as slow cooked lamb should be, but lacking on herbs and spices.

Ile Flottante: A delicate soft meringue floating in crème anglaise.  Great contrast of an almost burnt top and fluffy/sugary egg whites underneath.  By far the highlight of the meal.
author: Adam B.

description:
The Moule Frites are pretty damn near perfect! I've eaten here several times and EVERY TIME I've gotten the MOULE FRITES (Mussels with French Fries). I get this at every French bistro I visit and this place has been by far (in this country anyway), been the best I've tasted. I've also gotten the cheese plate and salmon before as well (which were also delicious).

(Photo): http://tinyurl.com/moulefrites

POSITIVES:
- MOULE FRITES! MOULE FRITES! MOULE FRITES!!!!! (Mussel w/ Fries) I don't know how else to say it other than it is incredibly amazing. 
- Decor is cozy and comfortable 
- Owner & Chef are ACTUALLY French
- Good service & friendly staff
- Have I mentioned the Moule Frites?

NEGATIVES:
- Parking is a little inconvenient (no parking lot, just street side parking)
- Bit on the pricey side
author: Shaf O.

description:
Please, some simple rules. Do not allow reservations if you plan to make people wait. Do not say you will be right with diners, and then make them wait. Do not serve the first course, and then serve the main course more than 45 minutes later. Do not make diners leave their tables to ask staff for assistance. Do not show favoritism to diners you know - the ones you ignore may be continuing customers who now will not return. Do not serve food cool to warm, when it is supposed to be hot. Do not blame the kitchen. 

After frequenting the Baker Street Bistro since 1997, we will not go back!
author: Michael M.

description:
Nice little neighborhood restaurant. This place gets full easily. Parking can be challenging.
The mussels were good, but they were not plump juicy mussels. The onion soup was good, and very popular, I saw other tables ordered that too. 
The steak/frites were decent, huge portion of salad and fries came with the steak. 
The creme brûlée was excellent, but the pear tart was soggy. 
Excellent service. The only thing we did not like was the tables were too close to each other.
author: lovetoeat a.

description:
The mussels were really good. Couldn't stop eating them - and the portion size is generous :)
Also had the poached eggs with smoked salmon dish  - nothing special, your regular poached eggs with smoked salmon:)
author: I B.

description:
My favorite neighborhood restaurant and French bistro.  Local establishment for over 26 year and every dish is cooked to perfection.  Prices are reasonable and service is friendly.  Delightful French owner greets all the guest and knows all his regulars.  

They have lighter dishes, but these were our divine indulgences.

Soupe à l'Oignon
French Onion Soup

Escargot Bourguignon
 1/2 dozen snails in garlic & parsley butter sauce

Foie Frais Pôelé et sa Compote de Pommes
Fresh pan-seared foie-gras, apple compote, figs

Tournedos Rossini
Pan-seared beef tenderloin topped with fresh pan-seared foie-gras,
potato gratin, vegetables
author: HY L.

description: Great place! French themed, and they pulled it off. Went for brunch, I got the Eggs Benedict. Husband got the Croque Monsieur. Both were delicious.  The hostess and server were both very friendly and efficient. It was minimally crowded but it was an off hour when we went. Parking wasn't too bad, for SF. Very clean. The only bad aspect was that they didn't have a single high chair for our baby, so he had to lap the meal. But, that's a common occurrence in SF. So, they may be just catering to the area.
author: Jillian K.

description: Loved this place. Recently went there for breakfast/brunch. It's a genuine french bistro and many of the staff are fluent in french (which was a lot of fun, being that I speak a little myself). The meal was beyond delicious and they even brought my daughter a bowl of strawberries (she was being particularly picky that morning). This place was amazing. :)
author: Tim B.

description: This is a true neighborhood gem. Authentic French Bistr, even has a nice sidewalk dining area. Service and food are flawless. We enjoyed mussels, lamb, salad and several desserts:)
author: Jan J.

description:
This charming little French bistro was the perfect end to my weekend in San Francisco.  A tasty Sunday brunch before driving back to Los Angeles was exactly what I needed.  There were three of us, we had Oeufs Copenhague, Oeufs Florentine, and Pain Perdu.

Oeufs Copenhague is a smoked salmon "Eggs Benedict" with a buttery hollendaise that was intoxicating.  I regretfully did not get a bite of my friend's Oeufs Florentine, that greedy gus!  Next time for sure!

Both Oeufs dishes came with a side salad that was a nice spring mix lightly tossed with vinaigrette, and tender roasted potatoes with herbs.

The Pain Perdu (French Toast) was delicately egg battered with cinnamon sugar, maple syrup and came with creme fraiche and strawberry coulis artfully swirled on the plate for dipping and a side of fresh fruit.  We all agreed that the maple syrup could have been served on the side rather than drizzled on top, that way there was the option to choose between the different sauces available, but the combination of maple syrup and strawberry / cream was actually pretty darn delicious.

There is outdoor seating, very reminiscent to Parisian cafe, and an extremely friendly and helpful waitress.  If you want to practice your French she'll gladly oblige, or answer questions about what the dishes or just help with translation or pronunciation if you wish.  

I have to admit, the decor is a little old and funky.  Oversized Christmas ornaments, random vintage clocks and an odd wall sculpture featuring ducks.  I also spotted Julia Child's "Mastering the Art of French Cooking" among the spices in the tiny kitchen.

Baker St. Bistro is quirky but it's completely endearing.
author: Theresa M.

description: As a French national, I found the food spot on and sublime. The French toast is by far the best in town and all of the deserts are amazing. The staff is nice, polite and speaks French.
author: C B.

description:
Great lunch, but bring a blanket.  We stopped into the Baker Street Bistro at about 1:45 PM.  There were two other tables occupied.  The service was largely indifferent.  The lunch was great.

The restaurant was very cold.  When I asked about turning on a clearly evident electric heater, I was told that it wasn't working and that the entire building had no heat.  Is someone trying to lower their heating bill?  It is ridiculous to erode a decent restaurant by freezing its customers.  Buy a heater or fix the one mounted on the front of the bar.  Boo!
author: Mel C.

description:
Came for bunch.
Service is reeeeaaaallllyyy slow. 
Food was so-so (had Ouefs Baker St Bistro). 
Atmosphere is great, but blah service and food are not enough to warrant a return.
author: Judgey Von Judge O.

description: Great little gem in cow hollow. We ate outside on the patio. The Eggs Benedict with smoked salmon was light, just the right portion with a small side of olive oil roasted red potatoes and a green salad lightly dressed. Latte or cafe au lait was really good and just the right amount of foam. Our waiter was French and he was smiling, helpful, really nice even though you could see he was running around the whole time. Also first time after brunch that we don't feel "stuffed". Definitely give it a try!
author: Alexandra D.

description: We had fresh mussels, escargot, and steak tartare. All very tasty. Excellent service, too.
author: Jason S.

description: Crispy French fries and perfectly cooked mussels. I've noticed at many restaurants, mussels are often not cooked throughly enough, but this was not the case at Baker's. The broth was also nice and garlicky too. Great place to visit while in San Fran!
author: Olivia W.

description: Excellent neighborhood find.  The food and service were Devine I had the salmon special for the night along with a green salad the food was prepared perfectly crispy salmon on the outside moist and tender well flavored on a bed of sauté spinach and puréed carrot-seasoned gently to perfection.  The green salad worthy of a fine Parisian bistro.  Wine list decidedly European. Outdoor dining well heated, parking challenging. A little out of the way but well worth the effort.
author: Kathy R.

description: Pleasant little surprise.  We only visited due to Yelp's review and recommend.  Very well prepared food and pleasant service.  Price point is more than reasonable for what's delivered.  Would definitely recommend and visit, again.
author: Christopher O.

description: I recommend the Oeufs Copenhague: smoked salmon, poached egg, English Muffin, & Hollandaise sauce-$13.50
author: Xtina R.

description:
This place is "meh" defined.  Though Baker Street Bistro oozes with Parisian charm, the high prices do not justify the mediocrity of the food.  

A few friends and I found ourselves in the area on Saturday night and were able to snag a last-minute reservation.  Between us, we ordered the following:
- Scallops special
- Salmon special
- Lamb Stew
- Mussels
- An extra order of fries
- Profiteroles for dessert

My friends claimed that the lamb stew and the mussels were both very tasty.  For that, I would bump this review up to 2.5 stars, though I didn't try either of the dishes so I can't confirm.  

I ordered the scallops and my boyfriend ordered the salmon.  Having tried both of them, I am shocked that the other food was tasty.  My scallops were almost entirely devoid of flavor, and the little taste they had was fishy and unpleasant.  I had 4 scallops on my plate and I could only stomach 1.  My boyfriend's salmon was no better and the portion size was miniscule.  He finished his salmon, then ate the rest of my scallops and declared that they were much better than his salmon.  Poor soul.  

The side order of fries was very tasty.  Good thing, too, since this constituted the bulk of my meal (very healthy, I know).

The profiteroles filled with ice cream were delicious.  Very heavy, but delicious.  I recommend them for dessert.

Given the experience, our bill was entirely too high.  I think we paid $30 each, and that does not include appetizers or drinks.  Our meal definitely was not worth that much.  

I think it's safe to say that I won't be back.
author: Julie S.

description: I only ordered to to but they were friendly and very prompt. I got the Salade de Chèvre Chaud. It was a mixed green salad with a warm walnut crusted chevre and crouton with a vinaigrette. The attention to detail is something that I appreciate... they used walnut oil for the crouton which rounded out the dish with a nice nuttiness that played well with the walnut crust. I also love that this is a French Bistro staffed (or possibly owned by) with French persons! All in all delicious, and i look forward to trying more of their menu when I'm in the city.
author: Kasey K.

description: I love this place and have always have great food/service here for over 15 years.  Owners have changed, but our last visit was as fantastic as it was 20 years ago.    If you looking for a small quaint bistro with high quality food and great service, this is the place for you.
author: Dwight D.

description: This was one of the best brunches we've ever had! Croque Monsieur was bomb and the French toast was even better. Highly recommend!!
author: Callie W.

description:
For a long time, I used to think that going out to eat at a good French restaurant meant having to dress a little nicer than usual and having to double - make that triple - check your bank account.  How sad and ignorant was I in those tender, innocent days... 

My jaunts to Baker Street Bistro were often with coworkers in tow since it was one of the few good eateries within a 5 minute drive of where we worked, but from those early "professional-tinged" visits, I have grown increasingly fond of this little place.  

This is delicious, simple, everyday French food.  Not the "ooh la la fancy" French cuisine (I know, I need to curb my stereotypes), but the food you'd expect to get if you came across a crowded cafe on a run-down, hidden street in Paris on a late Thursday night.  In other words, solid, everyperson fare that's fresh and well made.   

The woman who runs the place is charming and friendly.  The atmosphere fuss-free.  The moules Provençale avec frites (Provencal style mussels with fries for you non french speaking folks out there) lovely.  And if that's not enough for you to give it a try next time you're on the Presidio side of the city, their event specials just might convince you.  Par exemple, Free Dessert Day?  All you can eat moules Provençale avec frites during Bastille Day?  The affordable prix fixe four course dinners during Xmas and NYE?  Sacrebleu!
author: Mo R.

description:
Underwhelmed by the brunch; it's kind of like every other brunch place, only out of your way to get to. 

Aside from my meal being mediocre, my friend and I were also put off by the server who asked us and two subsequent parties to move to another table on the sidewalk so a party of 4 might sit at the table we wanted. Guess what? A party of 4 never came and so the patio filled up and the next party that came along got the table. If you're going to be picky about the seating, make a sign that says 'Please wait to be seated.' 

One pro for Baker Street- since the place is far removed from the general populace, it was not that crowded for a brunch spot.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Went for a birthday dinner with a party of 4, and from the moment we walked in the door it was almost as if our waiter was offended that we were there.  I'm talking literally uncomfortable, especially since the place is a cozy dining area with maybe 12 tables indoors.

However, despite his service, this place was a great place to have dinner.  Ordered 3 appetizers and each was absolutely delicious, Escargot, French Onion Soup and Oysters.
Everyone I was with thoroughly enjoyed their meals, and for the quality of food it is actually priced relatively affordable.  ($16-$20 plates)

If I could rank the quality of food it would be 5 stars without a doubt, with the service receiving a 1 star.

Maybe the service is part of a French schtick as CJ's review a while ago mentioned, "Service is typically French--a little brusque, slightly hurried, and not all that friendly.  In other words, authentic."
author: Will H.

description: Wow. Amazing! We were staying at the Inn at the Presidio and was looking for a nice restaurant for breakfast. Craving eggs and French Toast. We found it! Best French toast my wife and I ever had! We also got the egg scramble with goat cheese, onions, tomatoes bacon and... (secret: add the home friend inside the scramble). Service was exemplary.
author: Shane P.

description:
05.07.11

Was here for brunch after nabbing some cute dresses from a sample sale.  I was definitely on a shopping high, but the wait at BSB brought it down low.

It was packed inside, so we were seated outside.  Took a few minutes for the menu and water.  Another 10 or so for the bread.  Another 20 to get our order.  I get it, it's a small restaurant, and you're not used to all this traffic.  You have one busboy and one waitress.  But...I was hungry.

What seems like an hour later (and probably was), we finally got our food.  Florentine benedict and an omelet.  Not hard, but the kitchen was obviously backed up.  We devoured the dishes in less than 15 minutes and asked for the check.

In fear of another half hour late, we dropped cash and got out of there as quickly as we can.

Definitely a different experience this second time around.

Damage for two: $30
author: Jenny L.

description: I've been to Baker Street Bistro a few times for brunch with friends. They make the best French toast I've ever had and their other brunch items are delicious. It's in a cute neighborhood where it's pleasant to sit outside and enjoy a leisurely brunch and then go for a walk.
author: Celia J.

description: This is such a gem! Classic French bistro cuisine in such a warm, friendly, cozy environment without the pretense of other places! The food is amazing; you can't help but fill your belly and warm your soul... and the staff are so wonderful! I can't wait to go back and bring more friends and family.
author: Rosalyn C.

description:
This is a great hidden little gem. The food was good and the ambiance was great. However, for a French-themed restaurant, the decor is a little unfocused and the food is only slightly French-esque.

Anyway, i had a great time here because I was with great company. However, the service was extremely slow and it was pretty hard to get the server's attention. She was nice nevertheless and obviously she was just busy. They should just hire more people during weekend brunch. 

I'll probably come back and hopefully they can redeem themselves on the service-front next time.

Note on the restroom: very clean. Though, why is there a chair in there?
author: Rylan C.

description:
I really like this place. I came here  with my mom once when I was younger and decided to go with my friends now that I live in SF.

The food was really good. I got the salmon tartare and the cassoulet, and they were both hella good. It's a bit overpriced for the regular items, but the prix fixe menu is damn good deal.

The desserts are all really good, too.

It has a "a small, intimate Parisian bistro" atmosphere, which is cool for going on a date. Unfortunately for couples having dinner that night, we were being pretty drunk and rowdy =)
author: J R.

description:
Love love LOVE this place!!! Their mussels are to die for, and their fries are yummy: hot and fresh, crispy and flavourful on the outside, nice and soft on the inside. You can sit inside or outside, no matter how cold it is, they have some nice heaters on their terrace that actually work, so you can sit outside without freezing your ass off.
Great atmosphere inside, very cozy. Friendly and efficient service, and the staff know their shit! 
Had the Côtes d'Agneau Grillées, Tomate Montrachet et Gratin Dauphinois (lamb chops), yumm. Get the Moules Poulette to share, we had plenty for 3 of us (2 big guys and me). Next time I am doing a Prix Fixe

Baker Street Bistro: I LOVE YOU!
author: Natasha C.

description: Real french food by a real french chef at a very affordable price, bistro atmosphere guaranteed!
author: Guillaume B.

description:
Recently had brunch here on a Sunday morning. There were 7 of us, but at 9.30am we had no trouble getting a nice outdoor table (that would have been difficult had we turned up any later, especially as they only take reservations for groups of 10 or more).

Service was very good and food was great. I had the french toast, and most people had the eggs benedict (which, strangely enough was served with fries.  I thought this rather odd at 9.30 in the morning!).

Water and coffee refills were good, and we never felt rushed. Another bonus to going early in the morning - parking was easy. How often do you get to say that in the City??
The only negative aspect was the dog sat at the table next to us, yes, AT the table - yuck!
author: Izzy A.

description:
Cute quaint, french style cafe

Had a simple grilled chicken ceasar salad (chicken was grilled perfectly)

Date had the duck- she was definitely a fan.
author: L V.

description:
Definitely one of the better quaint, French bistros in town. Yummy!

1) Seared Foie Gras
2) Escargot
3) Cheese Platter
4) Charcuterie Platter
5) Steak Tartare w/ Frites
5) Canard a L'Orange
6) Creme Brulee
7) Coffee

We had a huge group for dinner, and split # 1-4 together for appetizers.

1) Value alert: for less than $20, they give you a generous serving of foie gras. Yummy! Foie gras was spot on, and accompanying grapes and apple compote were also delicious.
2) Escargot - Can't go wrong with snails, butter and garlic.
3) Cheese Platter - this was kind of underwhelming - standard camembert, brie, roquefort, and a couple of other hard cheeses thrown in. Not my favorite.
4) Charcuterie - It was ok, but I wouldn't say this was my favorite either - nothing stellar to note except for the tasty pate in the middle. But again, I've had better...

BF ordered the steak tartare, and I ordered the Canard a L'orange (duck with orange sauce).

5) Steak Tartare - this was probably my favorite dish of the night. Generous portion of tartare, seasoned nicely, and the french fries were sooooooo good. I ended up eating most of the french fries.
6) Canard a L'Orange - for a dish with "orange" in its name, there was no orange flavor to the sauce. The duck was cooked nicely, and the sauce was tasty, but no orange. Sauce ran into the crispy polenta so half my polenta was soggy, and the sauteed spinach was also not impressive.

Our other friends had the salmon (two out of two agreed that the carrots served with the salmon were tastier than the salmon itself), the boeuf bourguignon (very salty), and the cassoulet (pretty good.)

Creme brulee was done well but again, nothing special.

I liked that the coffee came with a little jug of warmed milk. Nice touch.

Overall I think we will definitely come back for the steak tartare, and there were some things on the breakfast/brunch menu that looked interesting to us too.
author: Mary M.

description:
Came here with a friend for her birthday, after looking through Yelp mobile for the nearest French restaurant. Sad to say, I could care less for the place.

I understand, we're young. And yes, it must be a pain to deal with young people when you've got a room full of happy-as-clams business men and women who'll happily tip your holier-than-thou servers. But save your attitude and complain up a storm when we leave. 

We were treated with shoddy, stuck-up service, and weren't even seated promptly. The food was overpriced, in my opinion, seeing that I could have served myself a more savory meal of chicken breast and mashed potato. Sure, it was in French on the menu, but hamburger helper could've made me happier. Sad how I paid so much for a meal that I still needed to add salt and pepper to.

2 stars for the food not being terribly crappy, and an excellent taste in decoration & ambiance. But that's all that was excellent. I wouldn't come back if my meal was free.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I LOVE spot! Cute location in the Marina without the hustle bustle of Chestnut St. 

I've only yet gone here for Brunch but everything we've ordered has been delicious.

The Croque Madame is a MUST try. Also, I don't know exactly what they do here but their French Fries are just the BEST. I always get a side order of them when I come here. 

Will be coming for dinner at some point.
author: Alison M.

description:
Charming French restaurant perfect for your Saturday brunch. They do accept some reservations although their website might claim otherwise. Not very big so I'd recommend it for parties of 4 or smaller, but I did see a group of 7 waltz in without a rez and they seemed to have no trouble getting seated. 

The centerpiece of the menu, I think, is the eggs. I had a poached egg on English muffin drenched in ratatouille and a light tomato sauce. Superb! Came with a side of perfectly roasted potatoes and greens dressed in a tangy vinaigrette. My friend had a similar poached egg dish (called "Oeufs Copenhague"), only this had hollandaise and salmon. She loved it. 

The service is friendly and prompt and the coffee is dark and good. 

I believe we had 1 coffee and 1 orange juice as well. Our bill before tip was just over $30. Not bad considering both the quality and quantity of food! 

Give this spot a try, won't ya?
author: Andrew K.

description: Highly recommend. Saw it on  Check Please Bay Area. Came for my birthday. The French onion soup was great... Not salty like many other places. The salad greens were fresh with right amount of light dressing. I had duck...just right. My husband had scallops..really good. Wines are from France,.. Waitress let us taste glass of wine. Didn't need to order a bottle to taste. Had a strawberry dessert with balsamic vinegar, black pepper and ice cream... Delicious!
author: Cece D.

description: My friend and I had brunch here today and I most say it was a great find. The food was excellent. I had the eggs Benedict and my friend had the French toast. The service was excellent. I will definitely be back to try dinner or lunch.
author: Arlene D.

description: This is a cute French Bistro with a little bit of character. It has great outdoor seating, making it perfect for a Saturday morning pre-walk-in-the-park brunch. No Bloody Marys were a bit of a disappointment but the eggs were quite tasty (we tried the salmon benedict and poached eggs with ratatouille). The menu was fairly limited and the flavors were a little less adventurous than we might have liked, but overall this is a solid brunch option.
author: Casey C.

description:
Came here before a show at the Palace of Fine Arts Theater.  Pretty small place, so reservations would be a good idea.  It was a cold night and we went early, so they used brought inside the outdoor propane heater which made it pretty warm inside.  Later when more diners arrived, the collective body temperature made things comfortable and they put the propane heaters back outside for winter al fresco dining.  

Cluttered French-looking decor.  French-accented wait staff.  Felt like a bistro.

The steak was great.  The mussels in white wine were not only tasty, you got a pretty decently sized portion.  Nice sliced french bread to start.  Absolutely fabulous fries!  They were not pretentious enough to refuse my request for ketchup for my fries.  

Tough neighborhood parking.  Be prepared to walk a bit from wherever you find parking.  

Another good meal like this, and I'll be awarding a rare four stars.
author: Doctor G.

description:
So I woke up this morning and I had one thing on my mind.....Steak and Eggs.   I hoped on yelp and searched for steak and eggs along with "brunch" checked and the first review that came up was from a guy claiming the steak at Baker st Bistro was a big as his face.

Sounds perfect.   

While well out of my normal haunt, we drove to BSB and were delighted to find outdoor seating with no wait at 10am.

Win

Ordered the Steak and Eggs.   It was perfect.  Huge portions of everything.   great flavor, cooked to absolute perfection.   There are a lot of tasty things to try here.   I will definitely be back for the croque madame.

Staff was also wonderful.

BSB - You win.
author: Rick R.

description: Really friendly and professional service. Great for business lunches.  Delicious selection of seafood dishes.  Ham and cheese baguette was delectable and came with a fine salad.
author: Ali B.

description:
To add on to all the positive reviews...I LOVE this place! It's cozy and quaint. Perfect place for a mimosa on a sunny day. I came here for lunch and had the seafood stew which was delicous--a blend of saffron, seafood broth, fennel, mussels, fish of the day, and all that with a side of risotto shaped like a rice crispy :-)

I vow to come here more often.
author: Mimi T.

description:
One of the best decisions I've ever made in terms of wandering into a restaurant. Myself and a friend, after a long walk around Golden Gate, decided to step in for lunch, and I was pleasantly surprised to have one of the best confit de canard that I've ever had. Wonderfully crisp skin yet still tender meat coupled with fried potatoes and a stuffed tomato. My friend was extremely satisfied by the croque-monsieur, which was quite large and prepared exactly as I remember them to be in France. 

Our waitress was wonderful, constantly checking in on us. I felt very at home, especially because she spoke a blend of Creole and English. Speaking to her in French was a wonderful opportunity to practice the language,  and she was extremely welcoming. Would definitely go again to at least say hello!
author: Travis L.

description: New dating partner person took me here on our weekly date before hitting a show at the Palace of Fine Arts. I have to admit, it was a great idea. Super cute and super close to the theater. It was raining and he dropped me out in front to grab a table- so sweet. We were in a rush so ordered our entrees pretty quickly. I had the mussels while he had the chicken special. My order of mussels was GINORMOUS. I mean, it could feed 5 people at best. But of course, being the lady that I am, finished it off in one swoop. Wait staff is attentive and food came out in a timely matter. Great spot for a date or casual gathering.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: The food was really good and the price was relatively reasonable. The restaurant is super cute and the staff is nice.   Overall, the service was lacking. We were there for brunch and ordered drinks which seem to take forever to arrive. Coffee refills were almost nonexistent. We repeatedly asked to have our cups refilled and it took probably 20 minutes before coffee arrived.  While the food was delivered to the table in a reasonable period of time, no one ever returned to ask us if everything was okay or if we were enjoying the meal.  I would return to the restaurant in a pinch but it's not on the top of my list.
author: Frank H.

description:
Baker Street Bistro has been a mainstay for me and my husband.  We came here for our first Valentine's together 10 years ago, and we have been back nearly every year since.  It is such a cozy place, and they have excellent food and service.  At our dinner 10 years ago, we were college students looking for a romantic evening on a budget...and they weren't snobby about it or anything.  They've never failed to disappoint us.

Minor caveat: Realistically, I acknowledge that there are other restaurants that might a more delicious (e.g., Bouchon has better duck).  However, the food is solid (I'd say 90th percentile) and we know that we're in for a wonderful evening every time we go.
author: Fontane L.

description: I had the burger and it was good but needed some more flavor. The cream puffs were really good though.
author: Jacob P.

description:
I came here regularly for awhile.  This place is cute, but it's really past its time.  Go to Bistro Central Parc instead; same folks run it, but it's a newer location.

Also, the staff here are not friendly.  The only one who is nice is the woman who works here.
author: Erika C.

description:
This place lives up to the Yelp 3-star moniker -- "A-OK".  That's sort of how I felt after leaving.  

The atmosphere is really nice, intimate and cozy, a good place to have a long casual meal with someone.

Food was decent -- didn't blow my mind, but it was satisfying.  I had the duck breast l'Orange.  Duck was overcooked and lacked a good layer of crispy melty fat that really makes duck knock my socks off.

The real annoyances were the service, selection and prices.  Service was slow and our waiter just had that forced, fake style of waiting that makes my skin crawl.  Many of the items on the menu were not available, including the duck confit, which was my original choice.

AND NOTE BENE: the prices are about $2-3 dollars more than listed on their menu online.  You'll mostly be paying in the $20-$22 range for an entree (more for specials), and this was a bummer for us b/c we picked it thinking most would be under $20.
author: Cersei L.

description: I had brunch with a couple friends here on a saturday morning and there was no wait for a table but we waited a while before we were given menus. Our server even came to take our order but we didn't get the menu's yet. The servers were friendly but very slow even though the restaurant wasn't packed. At least our food was good.
author: Krystle J.

description: Enjoyed the French onionsoup and for foie gras. The beef borgoigne was tasty but the beef was a bit lean for me.
author: george s.

description: Authentic French bistro in the Marina, there's a few patio tables, so you can bring you dog. We ordered the clams, seafood stew and the poached eggs with ratatouille. So if you want something other than your traditional American breakfast, then this is a nice spot to check out.
author: Ennie L.

description: Probably the best hollandaise I've ever had. Adorable cafe setting, great service. Only gripe was that potatoes were served lukewarm. Minor gripe but hey, that's what yelp is for. Will be back for sure!
author: Michael M.

description: We have been hitting this place for years, but usually for the brunch.  Best eggs bene in town by my account.  Perfect place when the weather is nice, outside seating in a cool neighborhood.  Head over to the Final Final for the big game and some more pre-lunch libations.
author: Michael B.

description:
Went here before going to see Cavalia last week and had a surprisingly delicious, authentic French dinner.  The place it TINY and we had 7 people in our group so the seating was a bit snug but it worked.
I had the salad with goat cheese to start and the salmon special for dinner. The salad was huge and the goat cheese was encrusted with walnuts with a delicate dressing that was perfect. The salmon was cooked exactly the way it should be, tender with lots of butter. A couple people had ordered the French onion soup and said it was legit and I did see big, gooey globs of cheese. My hubby ordered the classic steak with salad and frites and all were superb.
Very cute place with outside seating. I will for sure be going back!
author: Sara D.

description:
We went to Baker Street Bistro in Sept of 2013 while on our honeymoon.  We arrived there for a late supper about 45 minutes before closing, and were treated to the most amazing meal we have ever had!  Though the other guests had left and most of the staff, our lovely hostess assured us that it was no inconvenience for us to linger and enjoy.  So we did.  We'll into the night.
The pate and escargots were mind blowing.  The quality of the ingredients in the French onion soup was easily the best we ever had.
The duck leg confit, cooked in its own fat, was so tender and delicious, and the duck medallions absolutely brilliant!
We sipped on a bottle of French wine while we dined and were tended to attentively by our hostess.
Each course was timed perfectly, so no overlapping on the table.  Our hostess watched us carefully, bringing out the next course only when we had finished the previous one.  I wish I had gotten her name... as the service was outstanding.
Once finished with the meal, we asked to finish our wine outside on the patio so they could clear the dining room.  We lingered outside in the lovely night, sipping our wine, reminiscing on the meal we just had, and the excellent service.
Our hostess invited us back to have French toast for brunch over the weekend.  How could we say no?  We returned for a delicious breakfast to the only place in the city we went to more than once.  I could have gone every day if it was up to me.  Next trip to SF definitely includes many visits back to Baker Street bistro.  Thank you for making our trip that much more special.
author: Sharon L.

description:
I love neighborhood bistros.  Just not this particular one.  Everything about it should work.  The menu reads well, the location is tucked away from all the hubub, it's quaint, it's got a chalkboard with wines listed by the glass... Everything feels right.

The wine immediately put me on a different course.  As others have noted here, you'll be sorely disappointed by the pour if you order a wine by the glass.  It isn't dictated by the waiter but rather by the thimble-sized wine glasses they use. 

The food kind of went downhill from there.  The duck alternated between horribly overcooked on one end, to still-squacking-like-Daffy on the other end. The seafood stew had its own challenges, featuring way-overcooked salmon and scallops, though the shrimp magically came out perfectly in a rich tasting lobster broth.

My guess?  They've been doing this for so long that they're just kind of mailing it in at this point...
author: Laurence W.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for years.  Finally went, and am kicking myself for not trying earlier. 

First off, loved our server.  She was always there, but never intrusive..  The mussels were to die for, and the broth was perfect.  The fries could have been shared; huge portion.  My friend had the lamb chops, and I don't like lamb, but had to try them.  They were also great...and again, I don't like lamb.  

The noise level was low, and it made for easy conversation.  The prices were reasonable: glass of wine, shared appetizer, entrée, and 2 shared desserts was about $45 per person.

I think overall, you'd be hard pressed to find a more charming spot with better food.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Dinner for 4 started out with the restaurant barely full but bursting at the seams within minutes of our arrival.  A happy buzz in a very pleasing space.  Tables are very very tiny so it is a bit of a challenge to manage wine bottle, glass, water after the large entree platters arrive.
I had lamb chops which came out perfectly medium and deliciously flavorful.  Hubby had steak grille which was excellent with the most wonderful frites.  Friends had beef bouguignon and the chops and enjoyed them as well.  Split the mereingue in a custardy sauce with my hubby - he liked, I found it too eggy.
author: Ash A.

description:
This is a delightful place. I went here with a friend on a week night. The food was delicious and the service was outstanding. Oh and the wine, excellent! And the desserts, yummy! 

Two points I must make. If you are on a diet, Baker Street Bistro is not the place. And if you are on a tight budget, then you need to wait until you have a bit extra money to splurge on. 

Not that the prices are sky high, but if you have some wine with dinner, which I recommend, then be prepared to spend a bit more money. 

On my most recent visit, I had the salmon with a ginger, carrot, spinach mixture. So delicious and full of flavor. The chocolate mousse was so good! 

And, the onion soup was good too, although it is heavy on cheese. Next time I go back I want to try the salad with the walnut caramelized glazed Feta cheese. 

My friend had that and said it was delicious! Perhaps for me one of the best aspects of Baker Street Bistro is to sit outside. I like the way the outdoor seating is set up. It is cozy but not crowded. And, on a nice evening, sitting outside is enjoyable.
author: Jonathan F.

description: Their menu is somewhat limited, and their portion sizes aren't large, but it's still one of my favorite restaurants in the Marina area.  Why?  The food is consistently good (as long as you're not expecting big portions), and the atmosphere is perfect for a relaxing get-together with your significant other or a few friends.  Seating is cozy.  You don't have to scream to be heard.  Patrons are respectful.  Never had to put up with loud and obnoxious diners.
author: Robert C.

description: This is a 3.5, but on my first visit I always give a restaurant the benefit of doubt. Visited for lunch on a bike trip to the visit the Disney Family Museum. Solid french fare, but nothing that got us excited. The Croque Monsieur was very good, but again not extraordinary. If you want French comfort food I think this is a reasonably choice.
author: Gregg S.

description:
I came here for brunch and left slightly disappointed, possibly because I had BSB hyped up in my head.  I loved the French atmosphere, as the Francophile that I am, and the service was very charming - our French waiter with the piercing blue eyes was very pleasant.

However, the food itself fell short.  I ordered the Steak a Cheval (steak and eggs, and though the steak was large (as long as my hand), I asked for it medium rare, and received a medium-done steak.  It was hard to enjoy after cutting into the big slab of meat and finding not a hint of pink anywhere, and the meat was too chewy.  The eggs were better, scrambled in butter.  My dish came with a side of salad and potatoes, and for $16.50 would have been better had the steak been cooked better.

I'm willing to give BSB another try, and chalk up the steak fiasco to a loss in translation.
author: Kira K.

description: Found this place by chance while visiting the city. So glad we did. Such simple and flavorful food. Great service. Will definitely go back for the brunch menu. Will have a difficult time deciding between the ratatouille and pain perdu!
author: Janhavi A.

description:
Meal: brunch
Service: seated quickly only with a reservation; dessert menu and bill took forever
Ordered: Croque Madame and Crème Brulée; tried others' Oeufs Benedicte and Tarte Tartin à la Poire

Personally preferred the Oeufs Benedicte to the Croque Madame, but only because the latter was a little too oily for me and I realized I don't like Swiss cheese as much as I thought I did.  The portions were generous and both desserts tasted absolutely amazing!
author: D. A.

description: Always solid, with friendly bistro style service, and wonderful French delights. The French Onion Soup is very hearty, which is how I like it. The Tartare is always a joy, but not too overwhelming a portion, which is great as it gives you an opportunity to try other treats from the menu. Everything is enjoyable, and for what it is (slow, relaxed service and atmosphere), it's perfect.... a cute little local bistro to enjoy when you aren't sure where else to go! =) Thanks for being there, and see you soon, see you again, bonne journee!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Last night my wife a friend and I enjoyed a very nice dinner. The service was friendly and not overwhelming. When we travel we always look for the off the beat spot and last night we found one that we will go back visit again when we are in SF.  It is always nice to fine a local neighborhood bistro when you are traveling.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Have been here three times after the Presidio 10K, but I swear this review is not in any way affected by eating here after running my ass off.  At this point it's an annual tradition; 6 years of Presidio 10, last three celebrated at Baker Street.

Cute, small, French bistro on a side street in the Marina with very tasy coffee, bacon, eggs Florentine, and french toast.  The seating is a bit cramped inside but the oudoor patio seating is much more spacious.  Waiters are very French and were probably judging friend and me in our sweaty running clothes and sweet runner's hair.  

Yum.
author: Julie M.

description: When the reservation was made online, it specifically asked if this was for a special occasions--ie--anniversary, birthday, etc.  I had placed birthday.  But nothing was ever done that evening to honor that occasion-not even a candle on the dessert.  While the onion soup was very good, it was nothing spectacular.  I ordered the lamb chops which came luke-warm, and there was more gristle than meat on the chop.  Also, it came with no green vegetable.  Not once did anyone come over to ask how everything was.  They only did that after we were done.  The staff were too busy either on their cell phone or chatting with some of their "regulars".  We did order dessert which I think was the best thing I had ordered.  I saw no real French in the kitchen.   And when the bill came, it was outrageous.
author: David P.

description: Great service and the food is outstanding! Try the Baker Street Eggs. Best brunch I've had in a long time.
author: Emily R.

description:
Came here on a Saturday around 1pm and was able to sit at an outdoor table and catch some must-needed San Francisco sun!

We split Oeufs Baker Street Bistro for the entrée and started with a bowl of fresh fruits. The bowl of fresh fruits was much larger than we'd expect and was delicious. They dusted some powdered sugar on top with some mint in the center, not your normal fruit-plate but still healthy and delicious. Neither of us had tried ratatouille before so we had to try it and weren't disappointed. Not a sensational meal, but far passed mediocre. Portions are pretty large for brunch, plan accordingly :)
author: Ami D.

description:
I love how cute and unassuming this place is.  The food was great--I had brunch here with my siblings, and it honestly was like being transported to an charming Parisian cafe.  Their french toast and croque monsieur are top notch.  

We went here because we didn't want to wait in the ridiculous line at Mama's (I'm sure it's good too, but I really have no idea because I never have patience for that line), and it was a good call.
author: Caroline L.

description:
This place is adorable, has out door seating for beautiful days that we are so limited to in SF! I can't believe I have never noticed it before. 

This place definitely deserves 5 stars for the food. I'm a huge fan of eggs Florentine, that's basically all I will order for brunch, way to live life on the edge. But I like to stick to what I like. The potato's and salad served on the side were both great! Every potato was perfectly cooked, often times you get a partially raw one or two. The side salad was also dressed perfectly, I'm assuming it's a house dressing of some sort. 

One down side is the service sucked! We felt our server was extremely unfriendly, and seemed a bit annoyed with us. It wasn't that busy, so there really was no necessity to act snooty. 

Overall I'm sure we'll brunch here again!
author: yana Z.

description: I definitely was not impressed.  Baker street bistro is very cute and has a nice location away from the craziness that can be the marina and cow hollow on the weekends, but i just wasn't impressed with the brunch.  service was slow, food was only ok, and they actually didn't even really listen when i asked them to go light on something that would make me sick.  i don't think i'd come back here for brunch.
author: Lisa C.

description: I took my sister here after a long week, long day and a long flight into SFO. She was tired, hungry and indecisive. We arrived late in the evening and were seated by the front window. She found a delicious dish that was prepared and served perfectly. The chef at Baker Street Bistro is spot on with his sauces and balances all the dishes with flavor and texture without over doing any single aspect. I look forward to both brunch and dinner here.
author: Chelsea M.

description:
Baker Street Bistro is a charming spot to enjoy a leisurely Sunday brunch over mimosas and french toast. The service was friendly, the ambiance warm, and our tummies left full.

I enjoyed the cinnamon french toast topped with powdered sugar, heavy whipping cream and a strawberry coulis. It was moist and delicious, with a side of fresh fruit. My friend enjoyed an omelette made to order with a side salad and well-seasoned potatoes. The food was simple yet satisfying.

I've never tasted their dinner menu before, but would recommend Baker Street Bistro as a relaxed, casual place to enjoy the company of your companion over Sunday brunch.
author: Britt M.

description: Good food, but the interior needs a major face lift.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Make no mistake, Baker Street Bistro is a nice hidden gem in Northern San Fran, but it's not perfect.

Two friends and I went there for dinner at around 7pm on a Tuesday (I think).  Inside seating had all been booked, so we opted to sit on the patio and were seated in seconds.  The service outside was seemingly as prompt as it was inside.

The wine and beer selection is somewhat limited given the small size of the establishment, but what they have is more than acceptable.

A friend and I split the assorted cheeses for a starter and it was superb.  The portions were just right although I could have done with more croutons.  Walnut chunks and grapes were provided to compliment the floors of the cheese.  It was a very satisfying apeteiser.

I ordered the pork chops (medium rare).  They were succulent and very well seasoned, but the stuffed tomato stole the show.  I could frankly eat an entire plate of those things.  There was also a tasty but forgettable potato side.

My friend ordered the steak.  It was about 30% fat and wasn't that tasty.  Pretty disappointing for a $20 dish.

Overall the experience was very positive.  The service was quick and courteous and the food was quite good.  I might not return here when I'm back in San Fran because of its distance from everything that is cultural and cool about the city, but I would definitively recommend it to anyone looking to grab a bite in that particular area.

Also, one of my party claimed Willem Dafoe was dining inside, but I sincerely don't think it was him (although it totally might have been . . . I mean, who eats alone on a weekday?).
author: Julian S.

description:
Great for brunch. Relaxing vibe and friendly service. 

Order the French toast! And grilled chicken on the side of any side - done just right!
author: Vicki L.

description: On vacation strolling around our hotel, we come upon a bistro, seems nice so we take a seat. A man comes out and pushes the tables together, because our large party of three needed more room. Menus, bread and water follow quickly. I asked for a Chimay, but i am told their is only Duval ,, ok. so I wait, order taken I order chicken, wife salmon, son burger. Others seated, wifes french onion soup comes, still waiting for the beer, others get wine, refills, still no beer. Finally I ask for it, and the server says "oh" and then brings it out. As the dinner crowd thins out Daniel stares out at our table and then brings the food, My chicken lifeless tastless hunks that anyone could cook up. My wife likes her salmon, son hates the burger. i hate the service most of all, the thing I hate the worst, to be forgotten while others are laughing wine-ing and dining. French bistro please,  I have been to France, where the servers were pleasant and the food good, this was a so so restaurant with a guy running around talking in a French accent.
author: Toren V.

description:
This place is extremely cutesy! My friends and I came here this past Sunday on a rare, beautiful and warm day. We came here right before the lunch rush and was able to secure a seat outside. 

I already knew what I wanted before I came here!! I checked out the menu and was set on ordering the Oeufs Baker Street Bistro which is  ratatouille, poached eggs, w/ tomato sauce. OMG.. so good. When (not if!) I come back, I'm going to order this again.. I don't even want to try anything else on their menu! This is comparable to La Note's Ratatouille/Eggs Benedict.

One star less for the service. It got pretty swamped while we were there, but our waitress/server got our order wrong and took forever with the bill.
author: Lina W.

description:
A great restaurant for brunch!

I got the steak and eggs! the best breakfast ever. The plate was huge, the steak was as big as my face and was cooked the way i wanted it, eggs was great also! My sister also ordered something good but i forgot what it was.. But she said it was GREAT! but the butter was overwhelming. The waitress was very kind and sweet, though she didn't tell us that the steak and eggs included homemade potatoes! I could've save $, if i hadn't ordered a plate of homemade potatoes. 

But it is a great restaurant, the food is all that matters and it was very very good.
author: Jan C.

description:
escargot is really good. was seated immediately, however, seating is very tight.
it was ok but i prefer le charm.
author: Fins L.

description:
Had brunch here. Steak and eggs....Steak was bigger than my hand and very very tasty cooked medium rare. Mimosas are pretty expensive compared to other places in the city $8 for a champers glass full, but they were tasty. Got out of here spending $31/person, so that's what you should expect if you want to eat heartily and get a revitalizing morning cocktail at brunch.
We got there at right around noon and the sun was already pretty covered by the surrounding buildings so if you go during typical SF weather you should request that they turn the heaters on, or bring a sweater (or sit inside I suppose, but how charming is that?).
author: Mike M.

description:
It's a refreshing change to experience French cuisine without amputating your arm or your leg.  Fiance and I ate here on a Saturday night around 9:15pm after spending the day in Marin.  

Pros:  I appreciate a French restaurant where the chef and the staff actually speaks French.  The location of this bistro is very unassuming with seats both inside and outside the restaurant.  Because of our late seating time, we had a wonderful little table for two by the window.  

The menu had enough selections without feeling like they were trying too hard.  While they were out of the oysters (which I was told was delightful), we couldn't help ourselves and ordered 3 appetizers to share - the escargot, a foie gras terrine, and an assortment plate with cold cuts and another pate.  They had a decent wine selection as well.  We also ordered a NY Steak and a seafood stew.  Finally, because that's the only dessert I can't possibly resist even though I'm trying to fit into a wedding dress, we shared an order of profiteroles.

Let's talk about the food.  The foie gras terrine had a wonderfully rich flavor that made me keep reaching back for more bread.  According to the waiter, the foie gras is braised with cognac rather than port, and while the alcohol is faint, it's noticeable.  The melt in your mouth quality is superb, and it took an extreme amount of willpower not to reach over and eat my fiance's share.  The assorted meats and pate platter was very good.  If we didn't already order the terrine, I'd have attacked the pate like there was no tomorrow.  It was so good that I decided we needed to box it up and eat it the next day.  Which is today, and I can still tell you it was delicious. 

Our main course arrived with generous portions of food.  Tried a bite of fiance's NY Steak and found it acceptable, but not stellar.  My seafood stew on the other hand was wonderful.  Most seafood stews I've had had an overabundance of tomato, but the seafood broth for this dish was flavorful without taking away the individual flavors of the seafood inside.  The side of risotto was also delicious.

By the time the profiteroles came along, I was more than pleasantly full.  The ice cream was teeth hurting cold, which made the chocolate sauce harden.  But it was wonderfully good.  Many restaurants don't serve this, but when I do get my fix, it's most certainly a treat.

Last but certainly not least, the waiters were superb.  It might have to do with the fact we were the last diners of the evening, but our glasses were always full, never had a moment to complain about.  We had wonderful service.

Cons:  Despite the mostly glowing review above, there were a few small things which make me unfortunately give this place a solid 4 rather than the 5 stars I so wanted.

I found Krab with a "K" in my seafood stew.  Now, I'm not an entire snob, but Krab with a "K" had no place in there.  I'm a firm believer that if you do not have the actual decent ingredient, you don't put it in.  I definitely think it didn't need to be there, and the dish would have turned out equally wonderful.  So yes, slightly disillusioned now that the seafood stew was not perfect after all.

Also, I was not in love with the escargot dish.  I think it's one of those things where the garlic butter sauce completely overpowered the escargot to the point I couldn't really tell what I was eating.  To be honest, the size and the quality could have been better for the price they charged.  Slightly disappointed.  But completely forgotten after eating a piece of the foie gras terrine (see the raving positive comments above).

And lastly, I was slightly disappointed when they refused to let me get a box for the remains of my seafood stew.  They worried I might get food poisoning if I took it home with us, and did not pack it for me to go.  Was somewhat upset that they made that determination for me.  Which noble in their intent to cover their butts if I die of food poisoning, that was my call to make.  Plus, had I known they wouldn't have let me take it home, I'd have finished all my mussels!  Argh!

Bottom line:  I would definitely come here again.  And I would skip the escargot.  And not share the foie gras terrine, because it's awesome.  And the best part of the night - despite all the binge ordering, the meal came out before tip, under $100.  Imagine that!  If I live in the city, I'd most assuredly come back whenever I'd like a bistro fix.
author: Minnie L.

description: This was the second time we'd eaten at the Baker Street Bistro. It is an excellent neighborhood French restaurant. The food and the service were superb. This is not a pretentious place, and we were made to feel quite at home from the moment we entered. Hearing the staff banter back and forth in French added a nice touch to our overall experience. The owner took our order and attended to our needs, without hovering or attempting to oversell his offerings. My lamb stew was excellent, and it is a regular menu item. My wife ordered the salmon special. She commented on how moist the fish was - we cook salmon a lot and know it takes extra care to avoid drying it out while cooking. All the wines are French, at least that's what I recall. The prices for the meal was reasonable. We plan to repeat.
author: Matt P.

description:
We ordered mimosas and the mussels and seafood stew.  They were all very good, and the atmosphere was nice and cozy.  However, it took FOREVER to get our food, and the restaurant wasn't even very busy.  We were there for brunch around 2 so it didn't seem like there was a good reason for the wait.  Plus the waitstaff never even acknowledged how long we had to wait.

Other than that, our food was very good, and when the waitstaff served us, they were friendly and helpful.
author: B. Y.

description:
This intimate french restaurant is a must! You cannot find a better date spot than this. 

The only down side is the limited menu.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Baker St. Bistro is an adorable, authentic French experience tucked away from too much Marina hubbub - it is so charming that I'm willing to overlook that the food was mostly mushy, creamy versions of protein+starch.  Add salt!

Occasion brought us here for dinner after walking across the GG bridge from Sausalito.  We were cold, very hungry, not so snazzily dressed, and the Bistro fit the bill.  This is a romantic casual dinner spot with excellent service and a great wine selection, unexpectedly reasonable prices (ie, $16.50 prix fixe menu! - weekends from 5:30-7), and country French food.  Warm and cozy on an overcast day.

Hits: heirloom tomato salad, field greens, honey mustard chicken, brandied mousse.  Didn't try the duck, but a few people said this is the best dish in the restaurant.
Skip: Snapper (cooked well but mismatched with the sauce), mashed potatoes (unless you love yours pureed on almost-liquid setting and half composed of cream.  Surely some people do), vegetable soup (hearty and good enough but just not exciting).  Bread could be better.

I couldn't really decide between 3 and 4 stars - it seems to depend on what you order.  I'm rounding up because I had such a lovely evening.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Pros: Very authentic casual French food and a fun atmosphere.

Cons: Maitre D/waiter had incredible B.O. (thus taking the authentic french act a bit too far).

I'd suggest going in the fall/winter, when the waitstaff isn't working up as much of a sweat.
author: Jennifer M.

description: I went to dinner here with a 10 person party.  Service was excellant, and if you like French food, you will be quite happy.  I personally am not a big fan of French cuisine, but my dish was well prepared.  This is a a cozy bistro.  I would give this place a 3.5 stars.  Can't give it a 4, but better than a 3 star.
author: Tom W.

description: Went here for brunch, love the renovation.  Really bright and welcoming.  I always felt like this place blended in too much to the street scape and people might not have noticed it.  The outside seating is great on a sunny day.  I had the Bistro eggs benedict, it was super healthy (no hollandaise) and tasty.  Friendly service and the bathroom was clean and cute, something I always appreciate!
author: Andrea R.

description:
I do enjoy this bistro tucked away in the North-end of Cow Hollow and I'm sure it must be profitable. 

Any restaurant that puts that few wait staff on the floor when booked to the rafters must be wildly profitable.  It's at this point that I must compliment the too-few-on-ground wait staff for giving it their all and attempting to compensate for their thin numbers.

Although some times a bit heavy-handed with sauces, the overall food experience is good and we do enjoy the cozy atmosphere.
author: Jay D.

description:
I happen to know the owners, which doesn't bias me at all because I can tell everyone how passionate they are about their food and how hard he works. This guy has the same amount of obsession that the owner of Burma Superstar has... (A high school friend of mine is one of her friends and knew her before she started. Wow, she was so attentive to what we did and didn't eat and constantly asking us why or why not... ). 

I can't explain it, but there are a lot of things that are very important that are hard to measure on spreadsheets. It's extremely difficult to recognize when someone's talented at business.  

 It's hard for me to even write a clever food review because it's not my territory. I'm like the truck driver wandering by mistake into the beauty salon. Heck, even I am out of my territory in the beauty salon.

French food is really a cliche in America based on the 1990s superpower Impressionist art shows in all the great museums and weird ideas based on 1890s France. I wouldn't be surprised if most American tourists stumbled out of the airplane expecting French people to be working part time on Serge Gainsbourg style videos and reading Japanese novels, which is the subconscious mentality I had.

 and it's so nice to stumble into a little French Basque bistro like this.  I didn't even -know- there were Basques in France. 

One of my best friends took me to a down-home country style French restaraunt when I was in Paris and it was a mild shock to me, because I'm so used to French food being marketed to a weird market segment, mainly nouveau riche people who like to buy $400 high heels. It was really neat. There are farmers in France and they eat food that's very different from what's usually presented. So that's the same feeling I got at the Baker Street Bistro. 

It's extremely refreshing for an uncouth barbarian like me to find stuff like this, but in truth my friends are all real-deal food and wine maniacs,   so I stumbled on this place only through their great wisdom. 

My friends like to tease me about my bad habits, as I used to never consider food this essential life item (that's what hip hop records and the truly great sneakers are for), so I appreciate them gently guiding me back to the light. 

Thanks for introducing me to this place, it's run by good people who make great food! That's something no corporate powerpoint can ever pull off consistently.
author: Romy I.

description:
When I go to cute little neighborhood spots, I am already biased before I walk in, since the whole idea of a neighborhood spot already makes me like the place. You'd have to do alot to make me unhappy here. 

And in the case of Baker Street Bistro, they didn't disappoint. 
Portions are a good size, prices are not unreasonable, ambiance is quaint and intimate, service is attentive, and the food is pretty good! 

I ordered the pate platter and pretty much polished if off myself. (Let's not even think of the calorie count for that). I topped it off with the escargot, and though I felt the butter slowly raising my cholesterol, I was also slowly dying happily.
author: Denise B.

description:
We stumbled upon this place tucked away in the Marina, driving around looking for brunch places with outdoor seating.

It's a cute little traditional French bistro that has been around for 20 years! The staff was very endearing and friendly and helpful in recommending things based on our preferences. They are very French and do not hurry you to leave, nor do they give you your bill unless you ask for it.

Great spot for a leisurely weekend brunch.
author: Lina L.

description: Sister chose this for her birthday dinner. We started with escargot, the charcuterie platter, two salads, and mussels. We had also ordered soup, but the server warned us that it was way too much food. My brother was not swayed. He had the apps as well as the french onion soup and a salad. And yes, he finished his meal. The escargot was buttery, but not garlicky enough. We also could not enjoy this as much because we could not get bread. We ordered twice, but we were done with apps by the time she finally remembered. The birthday girl seemed to enjoy the charcuterie platter, but I did not really sample. What I tried was bland. I prefer Italian charcuterie over the French style. The salads came with a wheel of fried, breaded goat cheese. That was the best tasting and prepared fried goat cheese I have had. The rest of the salad was a simple mix of lettuce in a light vinaigrette. The star dish of the night was the mussels with fries. It is meant to be an entree portion, but we thought it would be okay for an app for our party of five. The serving was HUGE and seemed endless. Mussels were fresh, flavorful, and cooked perfectly. We were also surprised by how crispy and tasty the fries were. We dipped them in the mussel broth (since we had no bread) which made them even tastier. Entrees were disappointing. Four of us ordered the duck, all medium. They all came well-done which means dry and tasteless. My brother ordered the scallop special for $30. Four small scallops on the plate. It is a good thing he had all the apps, soup, and salad.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Pretty good.  My main issue was that it seemed to take a while to get our orders, they only had 2 people working the whole time, but we just needed to be patient.  Ordered the smoked salmon salad with a poached egg.  Amanda got the mussels, and both very very tasty.  

Warning though!  their online menu is out of date.  Food items have gone up about $2 each, at least.
author: Phil J.

description:
Went here on Saturday night with the little lady. Great ambiance and plenty of tables at 7:30pm. Got a spot outside and it was perfect (with heater turned on). 

We split the warm goat cheese salad -- bomb, and perfect for two. We each got a glass of pinot noir which was really good as well. Service was good and waiter was helpful and timely. I ordered the new york steak w/ fries and the lady ordered the mussels. 

The mussels and fries (dipped in juice) were excellent. Tons of mussels, easily enough to share. My salad and fries were also excellent, but my steak was mediocre. I feel like it was cooked to my liking (medium rare), but was still really tough and chewy. If I had to guess, I think the initial quality of the meat is to blame. I think I'll go with the duck confit next time.
author: Trevor F.

description:
This place gets 4 stars and is one of the best bistros in San Francisco???
What a freaking joke!
The food is NOT authentic and just a huge mess of whatever with supposedly a French accent...
Being originally from Paris and having been to this "bistro", I can only say one thing, how can this place stay open serving the food they serve?
A place like this in Paris would last a month...Come on San Francisco, you can do much better!!!!
author: bob b.

description:
I love French accents. In food, I mean. Yeah, food. 

Mom-in-law asked us when we could go to lunch a while ago. My Lady arranged for it on a Friday afternoon, during warm weather, while the markets were slow. Off we went on the 43, just a ten-minute ride! 

At about 1 pm the restaurant was about half full. The diners around us were regulars, and told us what the "good stuff" was, while we browsed the menus over kir royales. 

Not knowing what escargot was, one of us who shall remain nameless asked for it without the snails. This immediately evoked the humor of our host, who owned the restaurant, and we had a lovely time dancing through the menu choices. Ultimately, we did order the escargot and French fries. Wait, we had entrees as well. The bourride, a fish stew, was delicious. The Caesar salad was just right. The croque monsieur brought ham and cheese to a new level of consciousness. Really, it was amazing! 

Somewhere in the middle of all this we decided to order wine. Quelle surprise! Given that we were trying to decide on three glasses, the owner suggested we share a half bottle of the Sancerre 2007 sauvignon blanc. We were delighted to discover it "was fermented without introducing cultured yeasts," and we savored its complexity. 

Dessert was mandatory, of course!  Chocolate cake, creme broulee, and profiteroles graced the table, with 2 coffees and 1 tea. The whole afternoon cost $137.43 + tip, of which $25 was the Sancerre, and $25.50 was the 3 kir royales. 

We engaged the owner in conversation, and found out he was a neighbor of ours! The rumors of a new restaurant opening in NoPa turned out to be true -- lots of exciting changes are happening in our neighborhood this year. We are eagerly looking forward to the grand opening! 

Now I want to learn French so I can speak English with that accent.
author: David D.

description: Very chill & very French. I mean, VERY French. Not always a good thing in my view, but I really enjoyed the food, a classic bouride. In fact everything about this place is a classic, including the older gentleman wearing a black beret who came in for his (regular?) dinner. The menu is straight-up-the-middle French bistro fare. Service was very good. I was on holiday, so not particularly price-sensitive. An all-around nice dining experience in a cliche sort-of-way.
author: Paul E.

description: Love this little place tucked away near the a Presidio. It's my go to bistro for a quiet, good dinner with a warm and friendly staff.
author: Subho C.

description:
We came here on a super rainy Sunday afternoon for brunch. Would have been perfect to eat outside on the patio...boo

I got the brioche French toast. Delicious! Could have used a bit more syrup though. My friend got an omelette, which was huuuuge, probably 4 eggs worth. Prices were reasonable, about $12ish for brunch. Mussels were $20 I think.

Service was good. It's a nice and quaint place to grab brunch in the Marina. Probably not good for groups as there aren't too many tables unless you call in advance.
author: Kenny J.

description: Delicious food, very cute restaurant and very professional and courteous service.  We ordered a bottle of champagne at the end of  the meal and it was quite sweet when we tasted it; hot what we were expecting.  Our server said, no problem!  Let me have you try this rose sparkling wine.  That was perfect and we had that bottle instead.  Would definitely come back...the food was fantastic and the portion sizes were VERY generous.  5 stars!
author: Janelle C.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place...hmm.

PROs
- Outdoor seating on a nice sunny day!
- You can bring your dog if you sit outside.
- They keep refilling your water cup.
- They make a mean croque monsieur!! A bit on the oily side though. The amount of bechammel sauce on it is delicious, and the swiss they use is good as well, but I've had better with gruyere since gruyere is saltier and has a different consistency. 


CONs
- Their grilled chicken with mustard is so small..! Doesn't warrant $12.50.
- The grilled chicken dish comes with potatoes. Only 3 half pieces...
- Service is SLOW. We waited roughly 15 mins to get our check, then I had to hold out the check booklet thing in order for the waitress to get it. I swear I had it out for 2 minutes. 

Everyone raves about their french toast which I neglected to get because I wasn't craving anything sweet. I suppose if I'm around in the area and don't have a brunch place to go to, I'll pay Baker St. Bistro another visit to try out their french toast.
author: Heidi C.

description: Came here for brunch because of the cute reviews, but have to say, am a little disappointed. I really really wanted to like this place - the server was really nice, but the whole meal just didn't quite come together for me. We shared the Croque Monsieur and the Oeufs Copenhague (smoked salmon benedicts). Both were mediocre, but nothing you can't get at other brunches. May need to come back and try the dinner sometime.
author: Angela S.

description:
We came because of the rave reviews. Unfortunately, the food here was just so so, and overpriced. 
All the food we ordered was good, but nothing 4 star like what people seemed to be giving it. I guess the food didn't seem to have delicate flavors like the French dinners that we had elsewhere. 
The escargot was okay, but the warm goat cheese salad was a little disappointing. The cheese was not flavorful. 
The grilled lamb chops were ordinary, not exceptional. The prix fixe dinner was good value, but the main dish - roasted chicken with marsh potatoes - was nothing special. The sauce was ordinary, and not that much, and the portion for the marsh potatoes was small. 
The warm apple tart was tasty. But the prix fixe dessert: peach bread pudding, was freezing cold. I would definitely prefer it to be warm.
The manager is very nice and that's a saving grace. Service was great. But overall, it is a bistro with four-star prices and three-star food, unfortunately.
author: Clara L.

description:
We discovered Baker Street Bistro one Sunday morning while looking to branch out from our typical brunch locations in the Inner Richmond.  What a find!  It's a great little place with a romantic ambiance and a creative menu of French-inspired dishes.

The Nicoise salad immediately caught my eye.  Unlike the nicoise salads I've enjoyed at Harry's Bar and at Park Chow, this one was served with "canned tuna."  At first glance, I didn't think the canned tuna would have a chance against a seared ahi tuna.  Well, simply speaking, I was wrong.  The salad, which was huge, came with all the typical nicoise fixings, including olives, potatoes, hard-boiled eggs, and peppers.  The crowning glory was a healthy helping of a flavorful tuna salad which was far from boring.  Well done!  Any hope of taking some of it home for leftovers was shattered when I realized I had devoured every last bit.

Bottom line, the staff was very pleasant, the service timely, and the food  high quality.  We hope to visit BSB again very soon.
author: Tim N.

description:
So cute. Very friendly staff. Strong coffee. Great bread and cheese.

Stay away from the chicken with cream sauce. It did not sit well with me hours later.
author: Judy L.

description:
I think I may have had too much wine when I gave this restaurant an undeserved 5-star rating a few weeks ago. I came back to Baker Street Bistro recently for a second go. My meal was good, not spectacular, and certainly not worth the excessive praise I gave it during my first review.

As always, the ambience was great--cozy, homey, comfortable. Servers were jovial, albeit somewhat less attentive this time around. As for the food, it was very clear that they didn't want us to order from their much-hyped prix fixe menu. All of the non-prix fixe entrees (duck confit, filet with foie gras, risotto, etc.) were eloquently and deliciously described in the menu, while the prix fixe entree was referred to unenthusiastically as "chicken stew with tomatoes and potatoes." The dessert? "Something with coconuts." I guess we won't be having that...

I ordered the new york steak with shallots, tarragon butter and pommes frites. The steak was just okay; a bit over-buttered, uncomfortably chewy and undercooked. I definitely would not order it again. However, the pommes frites (i.e., french fries) were delicious--nicely salted, crispy and overall very tasty. For dessert, we once again ordered the profiteroles--chocolate covered cream puffs with vanilla bean ice cream and strawberries. They were incredible the first time I had them, and even better this time around. The cabernet and bread complemented the meal well, but I could not get past the disappointing main course. I usually love steak, but this time I left the restaurant feeling a bit uninspired.

I still need to come back for breakfast. Perhaps a good AM experience will tip the scales in favor a 5-star review once again.
author: Joseph F.

description: Went here last night and had a lovely experience! Quick, friendly service, and our meals were great. I had the salad with smoked salmon and a poached egg, and it was delicious. I'd definitely go here again for a cozy, comfortable spot.
author: Heather K.

description: I love this place.  Oh man the food was good.  I had this steak with fois gras on top of it.  I might have cried.  We also had this raw salmon appetizer.  Out of sight.  I thought the prices were reasonable.  Our waiter was all French and nice.  I thought it was a great experience.
author: Michelle K.

description: Awesome little breakfast spot, great to sit outdoors
author: John A.

description: Happy Bastille Day! Wonderful dinner, excuse my lack of French! Goat cheese salad, very well done, all you can eat Mussels & Pomme Frits, yummy! Chocolate Mousse & Balsamic Strawberries, oh so good. Real busy because of the holiday but staff did a great job rolling with it!
author: Beth G.

description:
This is one of my absolute favorites!  I've been here many times and am always impressed with the wonderful French food at reasonable prices. Bonus: the waitstaff and owners speak French, so you feel as though you're on a mini-vacation and may actually have left the country for a brief interlude!  

The last time we were meeting friends here for dinner(two weeks ago or so), we'd made reservations, but when we arrived our table wasn't quite ready, so they offered us complimentary kir royales out on the patio while we waited.  As it was a bit brisk that evening, they turned the overhead heaters on just for us--very nice.

We split salads (the goat cheese was delish), and I had the duck confit, which was absolutely fabulous!  My husband chose the mussels and left not a speck.  The recommended wines perfectly complemented our dinners, but sadly we had no room for dessert.
