Conversation was lively over coffee and we hadn't seen our friends in ages.... I'm afraid we stayed a bit late.  Kudos to the staff who were quite gracious as we were the penultimate party to leave the premises that night.

We love, love, love this place! :-)
author: Julia R.

description: Best mussels in the city - the broth is to die for.  Great service and cute ambiance - feels like you're in France.
author: Jen N.

description: Super-charming neighborhood gem! I have had delicious duck for dinner, and their brunch is really good too. Parking is pretty easy around this area too.
author: C B.

description: Quaint little French Bistro in the Expensive Presidio area of San Francisco. Came here on a whim with family of four and our dog. Nice little patio area out front. A little cramped but, worked for all of us. Sat down immediately. Service was a little slow. Menu for brunch was a little sparse I felt. Had Ham and Swiss Baguette Sandwich. That's all it was. Some greens on side. Nothing special. Kids had French Toast with fruit. Fruit looked like it came from canned fruit. Rather syrupy. Kids didn't really touch fruit. Wife had the Mussels. Were good. Came with French Fries. Probably, the best item. Overall, was okay. Looking for simple. This is your place.
author: J G.

description:
A great place for Sunday brunch on a sun-kissed day.  Heated by the late morning sun, water and mimosas kept me refreshed.  The waiter visited infrequently, but brought a congenial presence.  

The food was slowed by a number of large Easter parties donning their Sunday Best. I was one of a few heathens sporting athletic wear, but didn't feel too out of place.  Once the food arrived, I quickly devoured my spinach omelet, side salad and potatoes. Simple and basic, the food was naturally delicious.  And yet, by the end of the meal I was left with a disappointed reaction to my three halves of white potatoes.
author: Andrew D.

description: The food is pretty good (3-4 stars) but the service and treatment from owner/chef Danel is One Star or less.    I live a block and a half from here and every time I go and get Danel as a server-  he is consistently rude.    Liverpool Lil's around the corner has much better service.
author: Lisa W.

description: Really chill and cool place for lunch. add some spinach and swiss cheese to your Copenhagen and it tastes wonderful! Thank you!
author: stephanie b.

description: Great french onion soup.  Steak plate was huge and tasty.  Prix fix us always a deal.  Charming atmosphere in a nice neighborhood.  Great staff.   An older crowd.  Nice place to take mom or your auntie.
author: J S.

description: The most intimate setting and the most delicious food, all without any pretense. The moules marinières are wonderful, as is the terrine. I can't wait to return!
author: Michelle S.

description: It's definitely a quaint place. We ate outside on the patio, it was wonderful. We couldn't sit at the table we wanted because it was saved for regulars with dogs. The food was really good and the guy who filled our waters was fast. The french waiter on the other hand was not pleasant at all, very disappointed with the service.
author: Snow F.

description:
Rumor had it the french toast was amazing. Worth a trek over on the 22. Even in the rain. And the verdict? It was.

Granted, it could have been because I was famished after the Salted party, and a long bus ride wasn't helping things. But wow it was amazing, especially the orange/cinnamon syrup. Loved the ginormous slices of bread - perfect for sharing.

We also split the two eggs whites scrambled, which was better than average thanks to generous portions and what seemed to be a lack of excess oil and butter. Salad and potatoes on the side were a nice touch.

Definitely looking forward to returning for dinner.
author: Jason B.

description:
***UPDATED***
After a visit to Paris, I'm upgrading this restaurant to full 5 stars.  I was very much disappointed by ALL of street bistros/cafes over there.

Food at Baker Street Bistro, in SF USA, is by far better.   At every plain dish served in real France, I couldn't help imaging back this restaurant in the rim of Marina district.

And changed my mind about the fruit fly.    After all, fruit flies make me nostalgic of the good old high school experiment...


***ORIGINAL REVIEW 8/19/07***
Thanks to Sofi O., I was able to discover this wonderful restaurant.  Many say it's a cute neighborhood restaurant, but it's actually more than that.  Went here for dinner, and food was very good.

I say they have the best food out of  other similar-type French restaurants -- namely Fringale, Chapeau, Cassis, South Park Bistro, etc. -- that are noted for cozy Parisian feel, quality food, and reasonable prices.

The only reason for one less star is bugging flies.  There were one or two flying throughout our meal, and I found a fruit fly in my Sauterne (a dessert wine).  I will have to go back here again and check for flies next time in order to give full 5 stars.
author: Mami T.

description:
Had a great experience. 
Not just the food, but the service and ambiance were excellent. French Bistro with a Basque twist met the high standards of my "foodie" twenty year old daughter, and we look forward to our next visit to this cute neighborhood gem.
author: Bob B.

description:
Honey took me here on our first date, so I have very fond memories of this bistro.  Unfortunately, it wasn't because of the food.  Kinda last minute, so my fave places were booked.  Ended up at Baker after reading the yelp reviews.

Small and charming.  Right in the middle of a neighborhood.  Foodwise, it was average.  We had the french onion soup, hangar steak, and an encrusted white fish.  Washed it down with a bottle of pinot noir.  I never saw the bill, but the prices on the a la carte menu weren't on par with the quality of food.

It's probably only worth it if you have their prix fixe:  soup, salad, entree, and dessert for around $17.00.  If you're in the area before 7p or during brunch time, I'd say give it a try.  Not worth a dinner reservation and the a la carte prices.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Everything in this place is soooo good. Especially the "pain perdu" 
Service is awesome! And all speak French if you wanted to brush up on your french skills.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Bonjour 

Je ne sais pas. 

Sad to say, those are the only french I know after taking french for 4 years in high school. It's not that I have a learning disability or that I'm retarded; it's just that I never had the chance to practice my french and so as time elapsed, my french deteriorated. 

But you don't have to know French when attending Baker Street Bistro. I ordered the Eggs Florentine (in english),- two poached eggs with spinach, topped off with hollandaise on two English muffins. The plate comes with country potatoes and a small salad. The eggs were poached to perfection, with the yolk oozing out. SOOO delicious! 
My friend ordered their famous French Toast special with fresh fruit. It looked absolutely divine; and my friend, who usually always leaves food on her plate, ate absolutely everything! Good for her anorexic ass! ( jk) 

The restaurant itself was lovely, with an outside patio. Pictures of the Eiffel Tower and the Louvre adorn their wooden walls. There was a lady sitting next to us singing along to the music in french. I told my friend she was annoying, but deep down i felt jealous. I was jealous because I couldn't sing in French, order in French and make small talk in French with the waitress. But hey, that's cus i'm a hater. Oh well. 

Au Revoir!!
author: Linda L.

description: Sitting at one of the sidewalk tables at this spot, located on a quiet tree-lined street near the entrance to the Presidio, you can almost imagine you're in a quiet Parisian neighborhood. A friendly French staff - that apparently lost its attitude somewhere over the Atlantic - delicious country French cuisine, and reasonable prices make it a terrific find. Based on Todd's review, I guess it's been a while since I've been here, since the four-course prix fixe dinner was only $14.95, as I recall, but it's still more than worth the $2 increase. At various times I've enjoyed cauliflower soup, escargots, osso bucco, and a breast of chicken in ginger sauce, and all of it was wonderful, so much so that the more I think about it, the more I realize it's time to go back.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Have you been to bistros in Paris?  If yes, then you know that they are mostly casual, family owned and the food is usually good.  Baker Street Bistro has all the ambiance of a Parisian bistro ..  You are sitting very close to others and depending on what time you are there, it can be romantic, or fun and noisy with a party atmosphere.

Good food?  My husband and I enjoyed the chicken in mushroom sauce and the duck breast.  The chocolate cake was great.  This is not a 5 star restaurant that will cost you $100 a person.  It's a great little bistro that takes you to Paris and that's why we enjoy it!

Bon appetite!
author: Rose J.

description:
Minus a star off the bat due to the eye rolling that I got from the French waitress.  I. kid. you. not.  I was ready to slice and dice with my recently used butter knife.

It was a friend's b-day, we order some apps  the assorted pate plate w/ crostini, ordered a nice bottle of Pinot Grigio and start to enjoy the evening.  We got to ordering the entree.  Now though I am a big fan of the meat and love to eat it, very very rarely do I order steak.  I don't really know the cuts of meats etc...I can be a simple girl at times.  I order "steak" when I'm with the folks and they want the fine dining of Black Angus, I don't do steak at some fancy sassy Bistro.  I digress.

So this is how it goes:

Me:  "I'll have the New York Steak"
Waitress:  "Medium rare. yes?"
Me: "Hmm...medium, I'm not a big fan of bloody meat.  Maybe..."
Waitress: She just looks at me like I'm crazy, "how dare she ask for it medium!"

Pause...

My sister interrupts, "New York steak is best served medium rare, otherwise it ruins the cut of the steak. You don't want it overcooked."

Me:  "I guess, still not a fan of the bloody meat.  I'll try it.   Medium rare, then.  Thanks."

Okay, so the waitress does one of these Euro type hmmmphs, tilts her head to the right, and ROLLS HER EYES!!!  I know in her head, she is thinking, "Theeese steww-pid Ah-merhi-CAN with their gauche ways!! I can't beleeeve she wants it medium.  Sacre bleu!!!"

Anyway, it set me off and was unnecessary and rude.  This just further adds to my stereotypes of French people.  However karma is a bitch, she broke two glasses throughout the evening.

So I got my steak, I'm not a hypocrite, it was good, it wasn't too bloody, and it was a nice cut of meat.  However, I could have done without the eye rolling.  The shallot tarragon butter?  It tasted like regular butter.  But who knows, I may not be that discerning in taste since I didn't know New York steak is best served medium rare.  Whatevah! 

I'd love to try the prix fixe since it's damn cheap, but I found the service somewhat undesirable.
author: Jenn A.

description: Really authentic and everything was delicious both times I went. I recommend the duck a la orange and the creme brûlée.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Tiny little bistro with excellent service. The food was quite delicious, but I think what did it for me was the service. 
So my friends and I are sometimes laggers that miss our reservations and dam, missing your reservation slot at this place sure blows! You will wait, and wait.. 
It was your typical foggy cold San Francisco night and we had to wait outside for our table. They turned on the heat lamps for us and were able to get us started on bread and wine. The owner himself was apologetic and kept coming out to check on us and keep us updated even though it was our own faults for missing our reservation.
Don't skip out on dessert. Get creme brulee and the flan. Yes, get 2 desserts dammit. Why? BECAUSE SUSY EFFING SAID SO. We couldn't make up our minds but in the end we ordered the creme brulee. The owner brought us a flan as well - on the house!
Anyway. 
Although I enjoyed the food and ambiance here, it was a somber night for my friends and I as one of them had to give us extremely bad news.
author: Susy C.

description:
I've been here three times now---although previous visits were quite a few years back.  This is a nice little neighborhood place, and being in a neighborhood, even though it's just off the bend where Lombard (the boulevard) becomes Richardson, there isn't a lot of parking---I'd cab it, if you can find one of those, these days.  Baker Street Bistro seems to be very popular among the ladies of a certain age, as for most of our time there the place was divided nearly by half between thirty somethings and posh older women.

The menu is fairly diverse and from my standpoint a delight in that there was NO pizza, NO burgers, NO mac-n-cheese, and NO hangar steak (for the burger/pizza/mac-n-cheese crowd who are evolving).  Whoopee!  The by-the-bottle wine list was decent, with the most expensive bottle at $65.00.  We very much enjoyed our selection, and it was a great improvement over they by-the-glass reds available, and the sparkling wine.

Where Baker Street falls short is in value.  With entrees (main courses) right around $30.00 it's up there with the City's best establishments (or, perversely, right down there with the tourist joints in the Wharf) yet I didn't think the food was at the same level as the price.  I started with oysters (if the oysters aren't bad, they're bound to be good, and the sauce was spot on), and then had the Foie Gras, just because it's going to be illegal---I don't see what the attraction is, it's liver that tastes like very mild liver, but now that it's illegal I'll have to have more of it to fight the Nanny State.  The partner had the warm chevre salad, which he also liked, although I thought it was better at Chez Papa.  For our main course I had the Boeuf Bourgignon and the Partner had the halibut, which he pronounced delightful.  My boeuf bourgignon was decent;  the beef was flavorful and soft, although the sauce seemed a bit thin and there were no mushrooms, but recipes vary by region and I'm no expert on French cooking.  Still, when my own recipe (Julia Child) tastes better than an expensive restaurant dish, I'm never a happy camper.  I want to aspire to restaurant quality, but I want the restaurants to wow me.

We finished with dessert---a Tarte Tatin with pears, and strawberries with black pepper and basalmic, with vanilla ice cream.  The vanilla ice cream was very good, but next time I'd request it on the side of not at all, as the berry/basalmic/pepper combination was a bit overwhelmed by by the ice cream.  The flavors are very subtle and I think that without the ice cream this dessert would have stolen the night's show.  I want to try it at home.

Because another poster brought it up, I'll mention that we were asked if we'd like to move to the window table as it became available (next to us), just as we finished our first glasses of wine.  I had been dying to ask to do so, but since we'd already dusted our table cloth with crumbs I thought, with only one waiter on duty,  it would be rude, so I was most thankful as I don't like having people close by on both sides (what can I say).  We were only asked, it was not a request, and I was thrilled.

Over all, the disconnect between the expense and the level of the food puts this review at two stars.  If the plates had been $20.00, I might have been more enthusiastic.  One can hope the prices are justified by decent wages and perhaps benefits, but still, for that price I expect to be wowed and Wow! was not a word either of us uttered, all night long.
author: Paul T.

description:
Trusting the positive TV food program review, my family and I made reservations for what we thought would be a nice place to celebrate a birthday. What a disappointment! Our experience was poles apart from what the group said on the show. 
From the moment we entered, the visit was negative, with the owner/chef greeting us, in a less than friendly way. There were 5 of us, and we could see a table for 5 was already set up, but instead of seating us there, asked us to wait, and proceeded to pull tables together in a corner at the back, just beside the kitchen. I should mention that the restaurant was practically empty, so that was completely incomprehensible, and after we were sitting for a few minutes it became obvious the table was the worst in the room, and the heat from the open kitchen started to become unbearable. We asked the owner (who was waiting tables) if we could move down away from the heat, (remember the place was almost empty) he was not pleased. We were moved but very grudgingly, and were made to feel like we had really asked for something outrageous! 
We made a couple of attempts to engage the owner in conversation, as he took our order and served us, but it quickly became apparent he was not interested in being pleasant or helpful. On his video, he mentions that he learned to cook with his grandmother and mother, and with their passion. We saw none of that, and wonder if his mother and grandmother were as unfriendly as he was, or would they be ashamed of his attitude!! 
As for the food - 2 of us ordered the soup of the day, which was supposed to be vegetable soup, but it was so bland one could not really tell what it was, and it was served lukewarm. The French Onion soup was overdone with cheese. We each had a different entre and the consensus was the same, just ok, nothing to distinguish them from any other mediocre restaurant/bistro. 
The attitude and the almost hostile behavior of the owner left us completely baffled and shocked. In case you might be thinking we were dressed weirdly, or behaved in an odd way, let me assure you we were just a regular family of adults out for a celebration meal, in what we had expected to be a nice bistro that had been recommended.
My husband and I plan on a trip to France in September and were looking forward to it, but after this experience, it really has set a negative tone to the trip. 
We do not recommend this bistro and certainly will not be back.
Marcella M
author: Marcella M.

description: Had a great dinner here last month with the family - we had a great table, fantastic waiter and altogether delicious food. They had a fantastic prix fixe menu that offered 3 courses for $18 plus coffee - one person ordered that while the rest mixed and matched appetizers with entrees on the regular menu. It was very fun with lots of food - their boeuf bourgionon was delightful, as was their salads and soups. Also, great desserts.
author: Amy D.

description:
when: friday dinner

This place was well worth the 40 minute bus ride from SOMA to the Marina. It was a quaint restaurant that was packed with people. We had made reservations ahead of time and was seated almost immediately. The atmosphere was soft, the decor was very warm. The tables seemed a little smaller than my liking, but appropriate for such a small place. The waiter was very nice and helpful when it came to placing our orders as well.

I had ordered a slow cooked duck confit that came with a side of diced potatoes and mushrooms. The duck itself was tender and juicy. I didnt have to use a knife to separate the meat from the bone. There was little fat to be found in the duck, as it is commonly known to have a nice layer of it. The potatoes and mushroom were delicious. I normally dont eat mushrooms at all, but i scarfed most of it down. This meal was well worth its price, which wasnt bad at all.
author: Rena Y.

description: Honestly the food here is probably much better at brunch than dinner... We wandered in, had a completely lovely dinner, but nothing better than I could make at home. Except maybe for the fries. My hubby had a steak, and I can't even remember what I had (we just went last week). That is a sign! Our waiter was perfectly nice, we didn't have to wait on a Friday night for a table, it was, nice. And I want more than nice these days.
author: Lesly S.

description: A very pleasant place! I had some time to kill before a wedding, so I parked myself at the sunniest table, ordered a croquet Madame, Stella and fries. Per my request, they provided aioli. All food was very good, and the next time in in the area, I'll probably have exactly the same meal. The service was fine. Basically attentive enough, but certainly not overbearing. I like that. While I enjoyed the sun and outdoor seating, I imagine this would also be a great place to have breakfast and a latte on a rainy day.
author: Karen Z.

description:
I was tempted to give this place a 5, but I might need to come back here again for that.  When I arrived, it was far enough away from the rest of the Marina that I didn't have any trouble finding parking (that or it was just a quiet weekend).  Walked in and realized its a really small, cute little place that really has an intimate feel to it.

I just barely missed the pre-mix dinner cut off time (7pm on Fridays) which looked like an amazing deal!  It's okay though.  I ended up ordering a seafood stew (something I can't pronounce and definitely can't spell) with risotto on the side.  The stew was delicious!  Tons of flavor and it was big so it was enough just almost fill me up.  Towards the bottom of the bowl the flavor was starting to become a little much which sounds kind of weird but I don't really know how else to describe it).  I personally thought the risotto was a little bland, but it was a side so I didn't expect that much from it.

This place is very affordable for a very good meal and I will have to come back and try something else!
author: Tom Y.

description:
One of my favorite places in San Francisco for dinner! Yes it's cramped, but it's a great place for conversation over some good food. Solid French food that harkens me back to Parisian bistros and days of lingering over dinner for hours.

Great dessert and wine list. You won't be disappointed. The proprietor is friendly and engaging, but not obnoxiously so! Enjoy him and the spot. You'll feel like you're in on one of the best kept secrets in SF.
author: Charlene L.

description:
nice.
I am glad that San Francisco has this type of place here and there.
small, little and friendly French bistro.
I just love that.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Wow, how'd I miss this place all these years? I moved into the neighborhood 10 years ago and must have driven by this place hundreds of times. But finally, a wrong has been righted, and my stomach was oh-so-greatly pleased by a solid and reasonbly priced dinner. 

I definitely recommend this place for dinner, especially if you want something cozy and different from the usual Marina/Cow Hollow commercial venues. With a pseudo-French bistro atmosphere, what appears to be a small place is suprisingly large, seating upwards of 40, and those closer the door can observe (to some extent) the action in the kitchen nearby. The bay window tables are a real treat, and there is outdoor seating for when the weather is pleasant.

The menu is suprisingly robust - lots of choices, and there's also a Prix Fixe menu - flat fee for a fixed three course meal of an appetizer (soup), entree and dessert. Tonight it was cauliflower soup, pork loin with an applekraut side and a salad, and a blissfully decadent light chocolate cake with a dreamy cream and strawberries on the side - with just the right dash of powdered sugar. And this was $14.50! You're damn skippy I was happy with this meal. :)

The Prix Fixe menu rotates, so you can keep coming back and try something different. And if you want whatever you want, you can order anything else from the menu. 

Recommendation: the French Onion soup is ((insert Homer Simpson drool sound effect here)). In a word, lovely! I was definitely pleased - this is one of my all-time favorite dishes, and I'm happy to have found a new favorite spot for it since my once-favorite French restaurant on Chestnut shut down years ago (it's now occupied by Ashoka, the Indian restaurant near Fillmore). 

I'll definitely be coming back here, and heartily recommend it to everyone. If you plan to go on a busy night, bear in mind this is a small establishment, so it will be cozy, and if it's really busy you might have to put up with a wait - it's a small kitchen and not a lot of room for staff, so be sure you're not starving when you go. We were served in a reasonble time, but it wasn't that busy (especially for a Tuesday night), so I imagine Friday and Saturday nights must be a long wait for service.

But yes, go! You'll have happy stomach and nice experience without shoveling out too much money. This place is a keeper.

(FEB '08 UPDATE: Avoid going here on busy nights like Friday and Saturday - the kitchen and dining room staff get overwhelmed, service is ridiculously slow on these nights, and the prix fixe menu looks like a chef's lazy shortcut. Pick a slower night when they're all unrushed and paying attention to quality food and service. We went on a Saturday night - the place was packed, and service and the prix fixe menu was simply awful... never go to a French restaurant to eat German food.)
author: Gregg G.

description: We enjoyed the food.  The goat cheese salad was refreshing and tasty.  My Duck L'Orange was delicious.  My wife's steak tartare was good, but had a slightly catsup-like taste.  Food presentation was good.  We'd go back.
author: Haig A.

description:
I continue to say this place is wonderful! I went here for lunch yesterday and sat inside, where I found the environment to be very relaxing. 

Yesterday, I had the chicken with a creamy sauce, with a side of salad that I surprisingly ate. Also, they substituted the roasted potatoes for the pommes frites, which I love.

I continue to say, "go here as soon as possible, it is fabulous."
author: Christopher W.

description:
J'aime beaucoup.

I love that this little place doesn't rush you 
out the door as soon as the cheque is delivered. 

 I've spent many an evening here lingering over
my coffee hoping that the night would go on and 
on.

Simple, clean, classic French cuisine.  
No pretension.

I hope Jacques resists the need to add foam, a la Marcel,
to stay a la mode...
author: K-leen F.

description:
OMG...

One block from my apartment
Sancerre by the bottle
Croque-monsieur  is the best in SF--ask for it golden brown!
French toast to-die-for!!

VOILA!!!!!!
author: Trish t.

description:
It's a shame. I live close to this restaurant and after a number of tries, I won't go back. The food simply did not pass muster. Not very fresh at all. 

The staff is friendly enough, but when you spend a few minutes discussing how you would like your steak prepared, it should be right the first time. We even discussed French v. American preparation, but the steak I got was barely cooked. If I had wanted bleu, I would have asked for bleu. Gross. Bleu is hardly medium well, is it?

My feeling is that this place is tired, and employees are no longer inspired by their jobs. No one really pays any attention to the decor, or to details of food preparation. They get away with phoning it in because of the tourists staying at the hotels on Lombard, and because some people actually speak French on the waitstaff. 

Give the place a good interior cleaning, take more care with the food preparation, update the menu, and locals may come back.
author: Mary W.

description:
A french entree for under $20-- while kinda pricey for dinner for a poor post-grad student like me, its still rather reasonable for a french bistro restaurant. Baker Street Bistro is tucked away at the end of all the trendy Union St. restaurants. So the fact that this place is packed should tell u something. I would've given this place 5 stars, if is weren't for the bitterness of the figs in my duck breast dish. I've had duck & figs together before, and is was always sweet and savory, so I was disappointed that the figs and sauce were under seasoned and bitter. There needed to be more of a tart-iness to it. I also didn't care much for the polenta cake on the side. There are far better sides to go along with duck. 

This place is really cute and intimate. Friendly french speaking staff, a good dessert menu (HMMMMM... the creme brulee is to die for), some wine, and good company= one enjoyable meal worth the splurge!

TIP: make reservations!
author: Sue Y.

description:
Great place, service and food. My favorite brunch spot on a weekend. Take a seat outside on their patio and order a Mimosa. All their food is tasty and affordable! I have never been for their prefix menu, but look forward to trying it out. My favorite menu items are always the soups. The salmon salad is good, but I prefer the one at La Terasse in the Presidio. 

Overall, a worth while dining experience!
author: Megan M.

description:
Baker Street Bistro was very enjoyable. Cutely designed, organized seating, nice staff... did I mention the amazing brunch!? Wow. This place sure does the eggs benedict right. There was just enough sauce and the poached egg had sunshine colored yoke that poured all over the english muffin. I love eggs benedict! 

The absolute best part of the meal was the pommes frites. It doesn't matter what meal you are on, breakfast, brunch, lunch or dinner, even dessert, these are the best. Hot and crispy and fried goodness. I would honestly go back and just order those. They were god-like.
author: Natalie N.

description:
A rather disappointing experiencing at an anticipated dining outing  The welcome that our group received was as cold as the steaks that they served that night.  

Definitely not a destination restaurant, but I can see this place being a nice neighborhood joint.

Small glasses if you order by the glass... better to get bottles (..as always), desserts were quite good.
author: shaun l.

description:
We hadn't planned on waking up early enough for breakfast the morning after a wedding we had all went to, and I had no idea where to get breakfast in the area, so I called up a friend and he told me to try Baker Street Bistro--where they have "fantastic french toast!"

I hate french toast, but I was desperate since I had to offer an alternative place to eat since my friend who was driving was really set on Denny's. Ugh. I did not come all the way up north to be in San Francisco to eat at DENNY'S.

We sat down and the amigos were put off by the prices. But the ex and I ignored them and continued to scan the menu... Croque Madame! Yes! That's exactly what I wanted. Ex and Denny's-fan had no idea what a croque-madame actually was, but were persuaded by my excitement into ordering the same. We fell in love with the incredible sandwich bite after bite. Denny's-fan exclaimed at the start with "Oh my goodness. This is worth every penny." The portion was perfect and we were completely satisfied, while our other friend who ordered the "famous french toast" kept looking over at our sandwiches in envy. 

The french toast was actually quite good, I had a bite.

Staff was super friendly, efficient, patient, and attentive. And it was awesome hearing french flowing out of the open kitchen. Decor was homey and unpretentious, totally warming and welcoming. I appreciated seeing pictures of bistros/cafes on the walls that I myself have visited in Paris, completing my dining experience with more warm and fuzzy feelings.

Would come back every week if I could! I'm definitely trying the duck next time
author: Kat L.

description: I love this place.  Great prices and delicious food!!!  The pate and escargot are to die for.
author: Ammala B.

description:
Excellent, inexpensive French bistro!!!

Very well-rounded dining experience. All courses are done well, including dessert. There are always several specials that change regularly. I've been to the restaurant 4 or 5 times, and have never been disappointed with any of my choices. 

The food is a great value for the price, and the decor is nice enough that you forget it's inexpensive.

Recommended dishes: Scallop mousseline appetizer, lamb and veal stews, rabbit, creme brulee, poached
author: zoe s.

description:
What a cute brunch spot, nestled right in between the busy streets of the Marina and the quiet and demure neighborhood of the Presidio.

I came here on a quest for Sunday brunch with a girlfriend of mine and was surprised at how many tables were available -- we were quickly seated next to the bar and had easy access to take in the sights.  I simply adored all the framed photography on the walls!

We ordered the Frittata and the Eggs Florentine -- everything was super very tasty and fresh.  The lacking part of my experience here was the service which was a tad on the flighty side, but whatever.

Would definitely come back!
author: Katie C.

description:
went for lunch, got soup of the day (a tomato soup) and a walnut, goat cheese salad.

the salad was so delicous! only if i could make that at home :)

the soup is pretty good also.

decent price too: about 20 total.
author: Danielle A.

description:
1 star - Super duper cute seating and atmosphere. Genuinely felt like a street cafe in Paris. And oh-so-unpretentious! It's a perfect place for lunch/brunch on a beautiful SF day. 

1 star -  Attentive service. Gotta love the cute accents and eavesdropping on the waitstaff as they banter in French - and by eavesdrop, I mean occasionally catching an English word thrown in the furry of French.

2 stars - Delightful food! Croque Monsieur were mmm-mmm G-double O-D good! Each bite left me wanting more. 

I am absolutely looking forward to returning here for dinner! I wish my neighborhood had a gem like this one!
author: Felicia H.

description:
2 stars for the food, 1 star for the cuteness neighborhoody feel with acceptably clean, but unisex bathroom.

2 star less for stickiness kinda everywhere and friendly but extremely unprofessional service. Namely, a French speaking gentleman who appeared to be the manager or the owner, was extremely unpleasant to watch. He would yell or question the employees in front of the tables in rude manners.

Surprisingly food tasted pretty good, well justified by the price. I appreciated that the portion wasn't humongous either. I had the risotto with golden beats and it was very good after adding some salt and freshly ground pepper.

It was a nice change after witnessing this B2B city wide madness everybody act like college kids day. The whole event is alot more pleasant watching on TV.
author: Kokoro I.

description:
I just love this little bistro!
The menu is not very big and neither is the restaurant, but this place is full of charm! I have had good service and some yummy food every time I have come. I love the crouq monsieur and the crispy fries and they also have a nice brunch menu. The seating can be tight, but the feeling I get while eating there, more than makes up for that!
author: Lisa A.

description:
Delicious food, perfectly balanced bistro fare. The service was also great.
A true gem, not at all pretentious, it is like being in Paris
author: lulu b.

description:
Cute brunch spot- try to get a table outside on a nice, sunny day.  For me, my experience here was more about the ambiance rather than the food.  My girlfriend and I shared 2 entrees:  we had the french toast and a mushroom omelette.  The french toast was comforting, savory, sweet, and very filling.  It's served with a delicious cream/fruit sauce and fruit.  Hello sweet tooth!  The omelette was served with a salad and (some) potatoes.  I felt the omelette was a bit too buttery, but hey, it's a French spot.  

Service was pretty good- they were good about refilling my water glass, and I didn't feel rushed during my meal.  Good for people watching.
author: Sarah F.

description: Went here and used a Bloomspot ticket. This brunch was fantastic! Had the cheese and charcuterie, smoked salmon and poached eggs with hollandaise, and french toast. All were really well-executed dishes. I didn't expect french toast to be interesting, but the red and white sauce (creme fraiche and berry sauce maybe?) was really good. What takes this place to the fifth star is that our server was extremely kind, genuine, and accommodating. She was happy to help us fit plates onto the table by adding an extra table, brought us bread when requested, and so on, with a great demeanor about her. I will be coming back!
author: Eric R.

description:
I adore this place.  If that isn't explanation enough...this was "our" place and even a very bad breakup can't ruin my love and admiration of the food and ambiance.   

Very local, right on the edge of the Presidio on one side and Marina on the other.  The waiters are actually french (at least some of them), so don't expect hand holding waiters.   The tables are quite close together as the restaurant is relatively small.  I love sitting by the window.   I would go for a nice intimate or romantic dinner where you don't want to spend an arm and a leg.  

I usually get the rabbit.  It's a heavy meal.  Rich and creamy sauce, delicious rabbit...almost thick soup like.   I also really like the veal dishes.  I've never had a meal cooked badly.  Although sometimes the wait staff can be slow.  Since this is a french restaurant where you are expected to eat slowly and savor your food.  They usually have specials for the new Beaujolais season.  Those are some great meals and good wines.
author: Emily G.

description: Excellent ~ everything was Excellent.  The service was what you dream of - and the food ~ well, I will be back again and again for the mussels and next time we're coming with a group so we can try more. The portions are so generous that there was no room for dessert - but we drooled as they went by us to other tables.
author: Kim A.

description: So delicious, we thought we were back in Paris.  The salmon was perfectly cooked with amazing crispy skin, placed on a gorgeous bed of spinach and a puree of carrots with ginger which was unbelievable.  So well done.  What a wonderful dinner.  For light desserts, the Iles Flottante  is amazing and the balsamic berries are a wonderful treat.
author: w. r.

description:
This used to be my favorite restaurant in SF, but the last few visits have been pretty mediocre.  I love the manager (owner?), but service is, well, very French.

Note that I've only been for dinner and never for brunch, which people seem to love.

Anyway, go for the prix fixe menu if you're in the neighborhood, but it's not really a destination for me anytime after 7p...
author: S J.

description: We ordered Oeufs Copenhague, Florentine and Benedicte it was good, but the wait was a bit long, and there wasn't many customers in the restaurant either.
author: Lovetea C.

description:
I have been to this place for both dinner and brunch and I have to say both times this place succeeded in satisfying me. I love th quaint French style of the restaurant ( for those of you who are rolling your eyes and thinking "that means tiny, crowded with tables squished together..." you may not want to visit). The wait staff is polite and on top of it. For brunch they had tables outside and the sun hits right around 10:30 am which made it a pleasant brunch experience. Their eggs Benedict was wonderful!

It is a little of out the way unless you live in the presidio or the marina but it is well worth it!
author: Jessica K.

description:
Ok I think I can honestly say this was the best meal I had in SF. Each breakfast/brunch I would have French Toast and potatoes at every restaurant. They all said they were famous for it and here the french toast was by far the best! Each thick slice of bread was very moist and full of flavor. The orange cinnamon syrup was a perfect combination with the fruit, french toast and fruity french whipped cream it came with. The potaoes were seasoned with just the right amount of herbs and cooked perfectly. The croque monsieur was apparently to die for as well. My partner practically licked his plate clean.

The wait staff was very friendly and it's on a great street to watch people walk by.  It's a little bit away from the hustle and bustle so it provides a nice atmosphere. A++++!
author: Glenn M.

description:
This restaurant is small and cute inside. The staff is nice...we made reservations, but arrived a few minutes late. They accommodated us nicely and moved us to a better table for our group. 

The food was decent, but I don't think it was justified by the price. There isn't really any reason to return to this place. But we went there for dinner, and I might try their brunch as people seem to enjoy what they have to offer.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Good local Brunch place if you're in the mood for Eggs Benedict or other such dishes. And their French Toast (menu description: "Two slices of our panned pain de mie with homemade crème fraiche, fresh fruit & orange/cinnamon syrup - OUR YUMMIEST SPECIALTY!") does quite possibly live up to its name as their "yummiest specialty". :)

I still prefer Zazie in Cole Valley for both their menu options and their ambiance (their back patio is the best); but if I'm not willing to make the trek across town, Baker St is definitely a great alternative.
author: Sally M.

description:
I don't eat French cuisine at all, so I'm not the best judge of its dishes so I'm reviewing this place to share my experience.

I came in here on a Tuesday 1 pm, I found the place small, but cozy with classic, elegant decor. There was also outside seating which was a nice touch. I ended up deciding to try the croque madame. I found the dish to be a cool idea; all my favorite breakfast foods stacked on each other. It also came with a salad. The croque madam was ok, but there was too much cheese, and it just got too oily to enjoy throughout. The salad was good to relieve the palate, but not so appetizing either.

Maybe I ordered the wrong thing, but again I'm not the best judge of French cuisine. I'd be willing to come back again to try something else.
author: Peter N.

description:
Great neighborhood bistro.  Outside tables are fantastic in the morning (the place is on the west side of the street, so the front tables get the sun in the morning).

Loved the French toast and the benedict for brunch.  The mussels were good too.
author: J B.

description: Cute little sidewalk seating and great for our doggies. Plus, the breakfast options are yummy too.
author: Jennee D.

description:
This place is adorable and a great choice for brunch, lunch, or dinner. The restaurant itself is a little cramped - cute, but it makes me feel like a combination of an obese person and Andre the Giant. The Bourride Provençale is amazing, as are all of their salads (endive in particular). Another positive - very affordable, especially for the neighborhood. 

I'm not sure if Laurent is still there. He is so nice and accommodating and if you hit it off he might hook you up with a complimentary champagne or kir. Fabulous!
author: Jen L.

description:
By far, the best Eggs Benedict I have eaten in San Francisco!
Brunch is outstanding.  I recommend  ordering individual plates and the French Toast to split with the table.  This is the best way to go to maximize the brunch experience at Baker Street Bistro.
The service is fantastic, as well.  I love this place.
author: O G.

description: Fantastic service and food! The Oefs Baker is absolutely divine - ratatoullie and poached egg on an English muffin. Our waiter was clearly very french, and his mannerisms made me feel like I was sitting somewhere in Paris, not across from the Presidio. I'll be back!
author: Niels J.

description: Delightful atmosphere:  bustling, crowded, lively bistro, with attentive, welcoming, knowledgeable wait staff.  The place is jumpin'; go to experience the most authentic French bistro in The City.  Do NOT go for a quiet dinner; you will likely be disappointed.  DO GO for great food at a great price.  Request to sit on the banquette if you want comfort and "a view."  Limited outdoor seating is available for the very special days / evenings.  Having lived in the South of France, I am a fan of confit de canard; it is expertly prepared  and has an absolute minimum of fat remaining on the leg and thigh.  The mâche salade is superbe!  My recommendation, quite simply:  GO if you are looking for affordable, "unstuffy" French fare!  Bon appétit!
author: Jean Yves E.

description:
Screw it, you get all five.  I've been here a few times when it opened, but I was kinda too young to care.  Dinner with the 'rents is dinner with the 'rents.  But point is it didn't offend me at 14.  I went here a month ago and it was the shit.  All the food was effortlessly good, the service was fine, the place is cute and nice and pretty and such.  I didn't read the other reviews yet but I'm sure they'll tell you all about it.

What I'm here to tell you is that my brother and I were talking about a band, and my mom asked us what kind of music it was.  "Sorta like The Clash," I told her.  "I don't know them," she said.  "Yeah you do, y'know, 'shawee don like it....rock the casbah, rock the casbah.'"  (shakes head)  "Y'know, 'Should I stay or should I go.'"  "Oh THAT I know," sez mommy.

Right then, old french dude walking by (owner?  maitre d'?) remarks "aw yees, Ze Clash.  I sow zem in 82, at zee orpheum tseatre."

One of those moments that just kinda makes a night.
author: Nick P.

description:
Went here for brunch last Sunday.  It was busy, but we were promptly seated by the window and given a basket of French bread to start. 

It was difficult deciding because several dishes looked good--lots of bistro classics and favorites. I ordered the eggs Benedict with salmon, and the boy ordered the eggs Florentine, which came with a giant butterflied sausage, potatoes and salad.  

Food was simple, but delicious. We used the rest of our bread to sop up anything that dared to remain on the plate. Price-wise, I think this place is incredibly reasonable, especially for dinner, which is next on my list.
author: Kelly R.

description: Despite a busy lunch hour and the fact that one of the owners was working by herself, We experienced good and attentive service. The food was yummy and we spent nearly 3 hours enjoying the food and atmosphere. Overall, a great place for a leisurely, and tasty lunch!
author: Michelle D.

description:
We never remember to come here when we're hungry and hunting for an alternative to the usual places we hit up for dining out. It's too bad, really, because the food is decent, as are the prices. 

I DID remember the Baker Street Bistro recently, however, when I was hosting a brunch for 35 people. The management staff was extremely laid back about the whole thing, the service was nigh-flawless, the food was great and the prices were too. I definitely recommend this as a place to do an event / catering a party, as long as it's 50 people or less... I think that pretty much maxes out the space.
author: Hannah Q.

description:
A tad pricey, else I'd be happy to give them the five stars.

Friends made the reservation, and off we went. Parking wasn't an issue (we took two cars), and we found ourselves at a window seat in short order.

The service was nothing short of spectacular. I'd venture a guess and say it may have been the best service we've ever gotten at a restaurant. The waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, and very proactive. He saw us taking photos and asked if he could take a few - this seemed like a strange request, until we saw the photos and he told us he moonlighted as a wedding photographer! His wine recommendations were solid, and when we finished the bottle and a couple people had empty glasses, he topped them off gratis from a different bottle because "... I've found that this meal requires a fine wine." He was on hand to recommend food items and suggest alternatives that we might prefer. Very attentive, and very proactive.

On the food side, the lamb stew, the hanger steaks and the new york strip were excellent - but the pomes frites that accompanied them would give McDees a run for their money. Appetizers included a crab bisque, the french onion soup, and a plate of beets. All were excellent as per the consensus. As usual, dessert was the creme brulee and the creme caramel. One of us enjoyed a port.

All in all, a fine meal. Pricey, as I mentioned earlier (about $45 a person), but worth it. We'll be back. And they do take plastic.
author: Maxx L.

description:
If you had to get one brunch item here it would have to be the French Toast. As my wifey and me were waiting for our table we must've seen a dozen French Toasts come out. When we sat down and finally ordered, I Iet my wife get the FT and I got the Croque Monsieur which was one of the best CMs that I've ever had in the city, the Pain de Mie was nice and crispy on the bottom and the cheese was melted just right, i think what would've made it incredible is if they used real Jambon ham instead of  what looked like pre-sliced ham. The FT my wife had (also made with the Pan de Mie) was incredibly tender and tasty, served with fresh fruit, creme fraiche and cinnamon syrup.
The service can be spotty if they get slammed.
author: Brian J.

description:
1. Sophie walks (w/mom & dad) from lower Pac Heights through Presidio.
2. Then we go to Crissy Field beach which is unbearably exciting and fun! The water, the sand, the stinky stuff embedded in the sand! Yay!
3. The Sophie takes a nap at Baker Street Bistro while mom & dad have brunch & champagne.
4. Finally, we all slowly walk up the hill to home!
author: Eric W.

description:
I had dinner with 2 friends there last night, and though this isn't a fancy place, it rated 4+ stars for the following reasons:
-  though we were very early for our table, we were seated right away
-  service was very attentive
-  the prix fixe meal was a terrific value at less than $20 (fabulous asparagus puree soup, perfectly dressed side salad, flavorful and moist roasted chicken leg with wild mushrooms, perfectly done chocolate mousse with whipped cream and a raspberry)
-  reasonably price wine by the glass
-  even the decaf coffee was really really good!

I have been here at least a dozen times previously (always for dinner, sometimes getting the prix fixe option), and they are very consistent.  The meals are beautifully (but not extravagantly) presented, the portions are healthy but not ridiculous, the flavors are always complex but not overdone, and the service is European (your plates won't be cleared right away and your water glass may not be topped off often, but on the other hand you won't be rushed to "turn" the table).  They now have a handful of outside tables as well, which are made comfortable on breezy nights with the help of overhead heaters).  This is a great place to have an authentic French bistro experience without overheated prices.
author: Lana C.

description: I have been to this place twice and LOVED it both times.  The food is great, but more importantly, the owner and staff are some of the sweetest people I have yet to meet in San Francisco.  The atmosphere lends itself to a little romance or good times for a large crowd.  The menu changes seasonally.  I liked my mussels - nice white wine broth and yummy french fries and loved the salmon dish.  I am always too full to try dessert, but they sure look good!!
author: Kamael S.

description: One of the best steals in town.  The $15 fixed price dinner menu is awesome.
author: Wendy L.

description: This neighborhood bistro is the best in SF!  The food is superb especially the cassoulet, French onion soup, and all the trimmings. The atmosphere is inviting and warm. The service is with personal touch and personality. We love Bakers Street Bistro and will return often.
author: Sbh H.

description:
A solid 4 stars. This is officially my new fave restaurant in the Marina. I've know about it for some time now and can't believe it's taken this long for me to finally go. My fiance and I had reservation for 7 pm this past Saturday. The restaurant is super cute and off the main Chestnut drag, right up against the Presidio. One knock against it is that the seats are not too comfortable. 

We were out for a casual dinner and so asked the waiter for a wine recommendation under $40. He said the Syrah for $42 was great. For $2 more, we were very pleased with the wine. To start, we had the fresh pan seared foie gras, apple compote, and figs. AMAZING! It was so fresh and just melted in my mouth. This is an absolute must! 

For my entree, I had the traditional duck leg confit, sautéed potatoes, mushrooms with garlic & parsley, and cooked tomato. The duck fell off the bone and was so succulent. The potatoes were perfectly seasoned and so delicious. The cooked tomato was stuffed with some type of breading and baked. It was very different than anything I've had and was also very delicious. My fiance had the cassoulet (as always) and was in love. We absolutely devoured the meal and completely cleaned our plates. 

We split the profiteroles for dessert. These were just okay. The chocolate sauce was amazing, but it was served just room temperature. The pastry was also cold and didn't' taste that fresh. It was still delicious, but I've had much better profiteroles. 

Still, we had a fantastic time and the prices are very reasonable. The menu is great and extensive. There are bunch of items I want to try. Fyi, all of the online specials were available when we came. We will definitely be back!
author: Katie S.

description:
We didn't have reservations. I did not know that we needed any. The place was half full at the outside patio, all full inside the rstaurant when we got there and by the time we sat down, the outside patio was almost empty. 

It took forever to be seated, We told the staff member (female) that we preferred inside because it was chilly outside. She took our name and asked us to wait outside. OK, the restaurant is small but still, it was chilly. Over 10 minutes later, I went back inside to tell her that we would be fine sitting outside,  but that we were hungry. She said OK, but was distracted (because she was also a server). We went back to waiting outside. There were a few tables available and had I been functioning, I would have just sat in one, but I wasn't, so we continued to wait outside. Another server (male with a friendly smile) came over to us and asked us if we had been helped. I explained and he offered us a seat. We sat down, only to have the first server (female) apologize for the confusion and try to clean off our table for us. 

Eventually someone who I would assume was an owner (female, dressed professionally, French speaker). She took our order  without writing anything down and was very sweet. She and her male server also helped us to push the wasp away from our table when it hovered around us. 

The food was pretty good. I had an egg white omlette with Swiss cheese and onions and a decaf coffee. They did not refill the coffee until I specifically asked for it.  And then, the coffee she used to refill my cup with caffeinated. Besides that, I liked that they had Benedict options (some vegetarian) and parking was not too hard to find. I do wish though that they had had a vegan dish or two and not charged so many extra fees for the eggs. Omlette was something like 8 dollars, egg whites was an additional 1.50, cheese .75, and onions .75.  I felt nickle and dimed. Plus, they claimed they only had Swiss cheese but I saw them give my friend parm cheese for her Caesar salad.  
 
Nice touches:
-Warm milk was served with the decaf
-cute outside patio 
-they offered ketchup (I declined)

Not-so-nice touches
-They did not give us sugar or substitutes, I had to reach over to the unoccupied table next to us to get it.
-They did not give us salt and pepper;  had to reach over to the unoccupied table next to us to get it.

All in all, I was glad to be there because it meant that I was spending time with my close friends. I would go there again, but  perhaps for dinner? It was nice to go to a place so close to the Presidio but not quite in it.
author: Abi W.

description:
What a cozy, romantic, and friendly little French bistro.  The prix-fix dinner menu is a great deal for some kickass French food.   

The profiterole was totally orgasmic.....
author: Claire Y.

description:
Yawn, but at least you get a French experience. The chef reminds me of Nino Quincampoix. 

Moulle Frite is a very large serving. Probably three times the service than Fringale. It is however, very salty. I could have just that and some bread for dinner.

Everything else is pasmal, but you know you're not in Paris.
author: Pandora B.

description:
Location - Way out on the edge of the presidio, it was a $12 cab ride from my place and some of my co-diners took the bus. I can't say it was easy to get to, but there are cabs on Lombard so at least you're not stranded on the way back (like you are in the Sunset; why are there no cabs in the Sunset?). No star.

Atmosphere - We went on a Monday night and it was quiet but cheerful. The place looks and feels inviting. 1 star.

Service - Great. Knowledgeable and friendly and authentically French, which is always a good recommendation for French cuisine. 1 star.

Food - Lovely. The cheese platter was amazing, the charcuterie platter also delicious, and all our entrees were high-quality, inventive, and delicious. We had lamb shank, filet mignon, chicken in ginger and carrot, and more. 1 star.

Prices - with a bunch of starters, entree each, a bottle of wine, and several desserts, we were $50 a head including the tip. That's pretty damn good. 1 star.

So a total of 4 stars! If only it were somewhere closer to my house...
author: Laurie V.

description:
A quaint neighborhood bistro that has such good value!  They were playing some French oldies when we were there.  
We ordered one prix fixe dinner which had a simple salad, nice black bean soup, an entree which was salmon and creme caramel for dessert (around $17).  Is that awesome value or what?!  I got one entree (seafood stew) and dessert.  We both got a glass of wine and the tab came out to be around $60!  The food was pretty good too.  If I lived in the area, I'd definitely be a regular.  Otherwise, parking isn't that great in the area.  Don't expect fancy decor or anything, but if you want a low key dinner at a cozy bistro, this is a good place..
author: Pelina C.

description:
The first thought on our minds after we parked the car (yes, we drove) - was "why is everything French themed?!" 

Needless to say, we walked up to the bistro and was greeted by none other than a French man, with a real French accent.  "BONJOUR!" he proclaimed.  As we walked in the door, a table had just opened by the window and they were clearing the evidence from the last party's visit.  We sit down, and ordered mimosas (yes, thanks to my lead!) and then sat... and sat... and sat.  

My waiter corrected me in the way I said "frittata" - he kept pronouncing it fri-TA-TA.... so I gave up trying to be butcher the little French that I knew.  We ordered the ham and cheese on a baguette, an omelet, and the French Toast.  It wasn't GREAT but it wasn't not great... just as Holly would put it  - "meh". 

It just felt like a very slow experience.  No one was in a hurry... then again, maybe this is how the French live.  I am too busy running around in my San Franciscan lifestyle, where as the French just lounge and say, "d'accord". 

D'accord. Au Revoir!
author: Lisa L.

description: I recently returned to Baker Street to share my french toast experience with my boyfriend. It seems that my memories deceived me because the french toast wasn't nearly as good as I remembered. And Baker St. doesn't hold a candle to Joanne's Cafe. Overall, still a decent place to brunch, but if I'm going to go out of my way for french toast, I'll cruise down to Daly City for Joanne's.
author: Amy B.

description: True, it is not quite the exquisite French cuisine, however, you don't pay the price either.  We order the prix fixe, the tomato soup was tasty, not too creamy, we liked it.  The main course was like a beef stew, can't recall the name, it was delicious but more like home cooking.  The green salad was fresh however quite ordinary.  The desert.was the bread pudding, it was good but again more like home cooking.  It was good value, we will go back,.
author: jen j.

description:
Fine brunch place, but nothing spectacular.

Our waitress was attentive, but the kitchen was quite slow. I had to remind the waitress that I hadn't received my Latte three times before it finally arrived (I had ordered the Latte prior to ordering anything else, and still hadn't received it by the time we had both finished our food).

If lived near there, I'd consider it for a regular brunch place. Since I don't I won't be going out of my way to visit.
author: Eric B.

description:
I love the out of the way, cozy feel of this place. No one is ever in a hurry and the service is usual perfect. I've only been for brunch...the french toast and the eggs florentine are amazing. The lattes and cappuchinos are also impeccibly done. 

I would love to try this place for dinner...
author: Jenn G.

description:
I just can't believe this restaurant doesn't have five stars.

Even in France ( je suis Francaise) they would get five. The food is perfect, the ambiance is perfect, the chef is perfect, the service is perfect.

I should go there more often.
author: Del D.

description:
This place is delicious! I got the prix fixe meal. It was all yummy. The salmon was crispy on the outside and nice a juicy on the inside. It was awesome because I love salmon. The dessert, chocolate mousse with strawberry and whipped cream was perfect. Simple and made just right!

I would definitely go here again..someone ordered the mussels and it smelled so GOOD.

I got the Pinot Noir which was a great pair with my salmon.

I was dining with two French ladies and they loved the food.

The wait staff was very friendly and attentive.

Minus one star for being cramped. The place was busy and I came on a Thursday night at 6pm.
author: Chatree T.

description:
Yes I am a very big fan;)  A- they have chateau neuf du pape.  Always an excellent and solid wine choice!!! B- the seafood 'stew' if I may be so gauche to call it that was lovely.  Although I thought the scallops could be a touch more tender, this was still amazing.  My gentleman friend had the steak and a monster piece of foie gras on top.  I am in love.  I love foie gras and on top of steak w/ delicious ratatouille on the side.  Child please, let me die now!!!

Escargot always on point.  This place is very quiet and off the beaten path, so this is love.  No one bugs you, no screaming children and everyone speaks French.  Yes I have arrived!!  Baker St. Bistro I shall be back!!
author: Nicole F.

description: Went here for brunch on the weekend and really enjoyed the food.  I wish there were a bit more variety in terms of the food options but I ordered the goat cheese salad with tomato vinaigrette and it was delicious.
author: Ella E.

description: Best French Toast in the city! Great staff. Rarely have to wait for table. Little on the expensive side for breakfast food, but one bite of the french toast and it makes you not care how much the bill is!
author: Lauren S.

description: We went to Baker street bistro with some friends we set outside the brunch was great the food was fresh and not over cook. It was the best way to start your day i sf .    thank you for a good time will be back soon when we come back to SF.
author: Wes R.

description:
Baker Street Bistro c'est Bon!

I love BSB. . .nooo not the Back Street Boys, Baker Street Bistro! This is my favorite place for brunch. Their french toast is decadent and they have the best eggs benedict in the Marina. . . simply wonderful hollandaise sauce. I like that the egg dishes come with a wonderful spring salad and roasted potatoes. 

The atmosphere is very simple and inviting. The staff has always been friendly and the service is excellent. On a nice day, be sure to get a table outside. 

Although BSB has been here for years, it never seems overcrowded and scenester like many other places in the Marina area. It's just a nice little bistro with excellent food.

I've never been to BSB for dinner, but I hear it's great and I will defintely try it soon.
author: David R.

description:
Always a good meal. I adore the rabbit with mustard sauce.

This is a perfect date spot. Take someone you have a crush on and get a little closer over some outstanding food.
author: Angela K.

description:
Navigating Lombard without dangerous situations... an oxymoron... slowing down to find and turn onto Baker Street... whoops, turn on the next one and nose about a bit to find some parking... Look, a spot On Lombard!...  Is it true that Cow Hollow is hard to navigate and find?  ;-) 

I bring family and out of town visitors here for a good meal, shoulder to shoulder and toe to toe but the meal and atmosphere are great!  And in the occasional good weather there is small outdoor seating.  

I have Always had a great dining experience here, great meal and never a bad one.  This is a cuisine, not just food, and the choice of wines and the desserts make for a really good time.
author: Joe J.

description:
Located in a lovely residential area of San Francisco, Baker Street Bistro is cozy and charming. On a chilly evening in San Francisco, you can sit comfortably outside or inside near the window, and enjoy all the flavors of their French cuisines. 

This was my first experience with escargot, and it was both tasty and visually delightful. They have a full bar and a good wine list. The wine you select politely chills at your table, while you enjoy your bread while waiting for your meal.

Favorite Dish: 

Duck (the meat is so tender, if falls off the fork)
Chicken (deeply marinated)


escargot (skr-g)
n. pl. escargots (-g) 
An edible snail, especially one prepared as an appetizer or entre.
author: Ana S.

description: Mediocre food, average (-) service, over rated and overpriced. Soup was called, lamb over cooked, dessert over baked. Giving 3 stars just for great bottle of red wine and location, beautiful weather helped a lot (!), otherwise 2 stars.
author: Alexandra S.

description: I went to this restaurant because it was literally around the corner from our hotel (Country Hearth Inn). The atmosphere is so adorable and made me feel like I was in Europe. My whole party ordered the "Fixed Price" menu. It included the soup of the day, a mixed greens salad, the plate of the day and the dessert of the day for only $17 (a steal compared to the rest of the menu)! Everything was delicious, especially the entree which was a fillet of trout with a lovely lemon butter sauce and sliced almonds, and the chocolate mousse dessert. The service was spectacular, as all the waiters were french, and naturally charming and gorgeous. My water glass was never less than half full and our server was very friendly and helpful. As a new student in the city of San Francisco, my first dining experience here went very well and I am very excited to bring my friends here!
author: Julie C.

description: This is a very cozy place. Great food and good service. I only went there for dinner. Will try breakfast or lunch next time.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Was not expecting Cajun...

I remember many years ago going to this cute bistro and considering it a "find."   Romantic, good food, wallet friendly prices.   They must have cranked up the burners in the kitchen since then.  Our entrees were (in descending debacle order) scorched, dried out, dehydrated.  We started with dry, flavorless risotto and duck that was about as overdone as I have seen.  After sending the risotto back (it was the worse of the two), we got scorched scallops - waitress' response?  "they are burned.  It is because of the sauce."  All I could think was - did ya ever think about using a different sauce??  

We thought she was shockingly indifferent to our clear unhappiness with the meal, but then she surprised us with a desert on the house.  Nice touch (saved them from the single star), but not enough. 

So sad that the reality does not line up with my fond memories.  we won't be going back
author: Pavel F.

description:
Was here in the Marina for a runner friend's birthday and we had a group birthday dinner. At the end of the night I can say I was not disappointed at all with (a) the food, (b) the service and (c) the atmosphere. The menu selection did appear somewhat limited but hey sometimes change isn't necessary? I walked out of the restaurant with a full and satisfied feeling in my stomach  :)

My dish consisted of: chardonnay wine, soup of the day, duck Breast with potenta, braised fennel, orange Bigarrade (fabulous entree by the way!), more wine, one slice of creme brule and some champagne.

At some point I may go back to this place and try their Sunday brunch after a morning road bike ride into Sausalito/Tiburon.

Good times, thanks Dan for introducing me to this place!
author: Will C.

description:
We met some friends at the Baker Street Bistro for Sunday brunch and it was a wonderful experience! We were immediately seated outside at one of  the sidewalk tables after being given a choice of that or one of the inside tables. Although my quick look inside indicated that it was quite inviting in there, we opted to eat outside on such a beautiful morning. This table availability is worth noting as it was 11:00AM on a Sunday, and one of our friends who had walked up Chestnut noted that many of the "regular" places had crowds waiting out front. 

Now to the food; it was simply delicious! I got to taste the croque monsieur, the french toast and the risotto, as well as having eggs florentine myself. The croque monsieur and the french toast with creme fraiche were both sinful for lack of a better description! The french toast was thick but very light and fluffy. I'm sure it had absorbed pointy of butter, combined with he creme fraiche and what I think was a light raspberry sauce made me feel more like I was eating a warm pastry. I only had one bite of my friend's croque monsieur, but that was enough for me to question having ordered anything else. I did also enjoy my eggs florentine as the eggs were cooked perfectly and the sauce was rich and delicious and the spinach was plentiful.

We went expecting a simple cafe/bistro experience, and that is exactly what we got, along with great food and a pleasant and attentive waitress.

If you are looking for a simple, delicious brunch in the marina, but don't want to deal with crowds, then this is the place!
author: Rob S.

description: The food is terrific. We enjoyed a great Sunday brunch - eggs Benedict, scramble with salmon and veggies, and Cinnamon French toast - all yummy. Ambience is very casual and they have outdoor seating on a quiet street.
author: Jane W.

description: I really wanted to like this place. My boyfriend and I went here on a Sunday afternoon in late November, after finishing a run at Crissy field.  We were seated right away and I was excited to have potentially found a new neighborhood gem.  The decor inside was cute, and the staff was friendly and efficient.  However, when my french toast arrived it was super greasy and served with FAKE maple syrup.  Doesn't everyone knew that REAL maple syrup is better?! But OH, the kicker was the creme-not-so-fraiche.  UG. It tasted so vile to me, like it was spoiled.  I paid for those two bites of bad creme fraiche the next day...I became nauseous at work that morning and puked (literally had to RUN down the hall).  I then went home sick and puked again that afternoon.  I had to call out sick the following day because my stomach hurt so bad.  This was definitely food poisoning.  I barely made my flight to Hawaii that Wednesday morning, and was subpar that whole week.  Yes, Baker Street Bistro nearly ruined my birthday vacation and I will never be back.
author: Amy B.

description: I live in Chicago and would come to San Fran just to eat at this restaurant. Food is amazing, service is wonderful, and the chef/owners are really incredible.  When I was there last year, we had the bouillabaisse, quail with risotto, lamb chops, and profiteroles, and "peppered strawberries"- all delicious.  I still remember every bite and cannot wait to go back!
author: Amanda S.

description:
This is a cozy, charming little bistro with fantastic food at very reasonable prices. The waitstaff is authentically French (minus the attitude), and the owner is quite friendly. This place is great for either brunch or dinner, and is especially good for romantic meals or dates. 

The place is rather small, so it's not good for large groups, but it's perfect for an intimate dining experience with just a few people.  There's also sidewalk dining available, which is perfect for brunch on a sunny day. 

The kitchen is tiny, which makes it even more amazing that they can produce such quality food. And their prices are quite reasonable, especially considering the quality. All in all, you can't go wrong with this gem.
author: Peter B.

description:
Great place.  Like previous posters said, the service here is incredibly friendly, especially if you get the manager to come out and chat at your table.  Every wine suggestion I've been given here has been spot-on, and they make a point to suggest wines that are a little bit out of the ordinary (ones that you probably wouldn't order on your own).  
The food is pretty good as well, although not completely orgasmic.  Very solid french fare, especially the mussels (just be sure to get them with pommes frites to dip in the wine sauce).  In fact, every seafood dish I've gotten here was excellent, and their creme brulee is incredibly creamy and smooth. 
I liked this place so much that I ate here with my family and a few friends for my college graduation dinner and everyone, even my cheap parents, left happy and satisfied.
author: Dana B.

description:
Caveat: I get the same thing everytime I go, and it's their killer kick ass delicious French toast.  That's all.  Very good.  Very big portion.  

Dings for no bacon, and for saying "fresh-squeezed orange juice" when its just Odwalla.
author: Ashley S.

description: Came here for a dinner party on a Friday night at 7:30 and found the restaurant it to be partially filled.  I ordered the mixed greens and duck confit. The mixed greens had an appropriate amount of dressing and the duck confit was tender but the sauce was not as tasty as expected. The food was ok but not something I can get excited about. I'm curious about brunch since everyone raves about it but I'd rather check out other places in the city first since this one doesn't seem to stand out. The atmosphere is cozy but very cramped. Strange to say but the restroom seems literally bigger than our table of six. The service was excellent. I'd say this place would be better off for tourists because of its cozy feel and its close proximity to Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Luna L.

description: Everything was so very delicious. Chicken was moist and flavorful. The Steak grilled perfectly. Creme Brulee was worth every bite.
author: Zo E.

description:
Cutting to the chase, best to avoid if you are looking for true French cuisine. But acceptable for tourist quality level and a quick fix.
This restaurant was recommended by a man friend, a mistake.
The ambience is fine with French speaking waiters, but not real french type. Parking is very difficult and be there early. The bread is soft and chewy, more Italian than French bread. Onion soup is lightly salted with Rose Mary-Bay leaves flavored. Excessive Mozzarella cheese on top. Froie Grois is bland and Sauce is not as flavorful, the accompanied Figs are done to perfection. Looks like the Chefs are changing again here. Steak Frites is average at best, chewy and no flavor. Stay away from the Mussel, it is fouled flavor and the soup has a stinky scent and taste. becareful with gettign sick.
I don't think I am coming back again. BTW, they screwed up the Cream Brulee, it is eggy and watery  loose. Very amaterish....
Try Chouchou in Forest hill., it is worth to die for...
author: Bob W.

description: I really liked the atmosphere, the service was good, and the food was delicious.  The problem was the portion size.  I had the halibut for $30.  This consisted of about a 3" cube of halibut placed on a type of vegetable puree.  Great tasting, but for $30 it can't just taste good, it has got to leave you at least somewhat satisfied.  I could have eaten three servings  no probem.  I' m 6 feet tall and 180lb, so it's not like I'm expecting an all-you-can-eat buffet.  My friend got the Salmon for $24, same problem, but at least she had ordered a side salad (not included with the meal).
author: Rodney S.

description:
This place is exellent. I recommend the rabbit with risoto. The duck was also very good. 

Make sure to sit outside. The restaurant is on a quiet street, so you won't be disturbed by curious onlookers or noisy traffic.
author: Jerome F.

description:
This is a wonderful neighborhood place, cozy and quaint.  The first time I was here, smoke came out of the kitchen, a firetruck pulled up, firemen came in, all the customers clapped and continued eating.  Nothing was on fire, but no one cared.  That's customer loyalty

Another time, I saw some guy in a convertible pulled up, gave the owner an empty plate, thanked him in French and drove off like we're in sidewalk cafe in Europe.  It was a doggy bag from the night before and he got take the real plate home.
author: cc c.

description: You have to get their specialty french toast. It was the best i've had in my life, even better than Mama's!  The strawberry creme fraiche was amazing. Also had the poached egg with ratatouille, which was great as well. Fresh squeezed orange juice topped it all off with a delicious finish. But you just have to get the french toast. You won't be disappointed!
author: Jennifer R.

description: We had light dinner - salads as a main course, wine, dessert and some tea.  Everything was tasty' and the service was o.k. Greta atmosphere!
author: michelle k.

description: brunch today in the city.  Love the French toast, served with fresh fruit salad.  It was too sweet for my friend, but I love it.  she had eggs Benedict , came with a small salad. I wanted to see the dinner menu, asked for it twice,never got it.  Not  a big deal, I could read it on Yelp,  One crucial point for me: clean and spacious unisex bathroom.  parking is a pain, so drop off your party to grab a table, then go park. good luck.
author: Ppl C.

description:
I was really disappointed with this place.  After reading so many glowing Yelp reviews, I had lofty expectations of a mind-blowing brunch and great service.  Instead, I had a mushy piece of french toast and received extremely poor treatment.  

The second I walked in, I was confused.  Do I seat myself?  No one looked up to even acknowledge my presence.  Once shoved into a tiny corner table, it took over 5 minutes to get a menu.

I arrived 10 minutes ahead of a friend.  The second he sat down, a server pounced on us to order.  When we asked for a few more minutes, we got a nasty look and about 30 seconds.  Then another server came over and demanded that we order.
