I understand that this is a small place and that the weekend brunch crowd is critical for their business.  But the key to keeping customers coming back is quality service.  As the food was totally underwhelming, I'll doubt I'll ever be back.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
It's been awhile since I've wandered over to Baker Street Bistro so last weekend we were in the market for brunch/lunch.  It was Fleet Week but since the Blue Angels got fogged out, BSB wasn't crowded when we arrived a little after 2PM.  
As others have said, the Croque Madame was fabulous!  The egg was perfectly cooked and the bread was toasted on both sides (something you don't find in France).  BF had an egg white omelete that had tons of mushrooms and spinach.  We split an order of french fries which were hot and crispy.  
The house white by the glass was a little on the sweet side.  But I was so into my Croque that I didn't care!  I'm planning a return trip soon!
For those not in the neighborhood, while this place seems off the main Marina track, it's very convenient to the #30, 43 and 28.
author: Melissa A.

description: Came here for Sunday Brunch for me and my sis birthday:-)  I myself had the French toast which was so so good!!! Presentation was just as good as it tastes! It came with a good variety of fresh fruits too which was a plus for me.  My sister had the mussels with French fries. It was a huge portion..so much she shared with the table. The French fries stayed crispy all the way to the end! I don't like soggy fries so this gets an extra star!  My friends had the eggs benedict with smoked salmon, and the one with ratatouille.  They didn't really like the potatoes that came with it..i tasted it and it was dry and had a heavy herb and olive oil taste to it.  Well, its not the kind I like.  And bf had the Croque Madame which looked oh so good. He finished the whole thing which was a good sign!  He loves Swiss cheese and it was melted just the right way:-)  One thing was I looked around at all the other tables and they got bread and butter without requesting.  We were the only one with no bread to start off with!  I'm a total bread whore! So I need my bread!!!! I had to request it.  But my friends were annoyed by it and said they were racist. Lol:-D An extra extra star for not charging us the cake fee but just thought it was odd they charged us gratuity when it's just five of us. I always thought it was six or more.  We brought a stuffed Domo with us..did that count???
author: Betty L.

description:
Dinner for 2 on Wednesday, November 3, 2010.  
FOOD IS YUMMY.  SALAD AND HALIBUT TRULY EXCELLENT.  SERVICE IS AT BEST "HIT AND MISS".  This evening it was mostly MISS.

ALSO, TRULY LACKED WARMTH AND FRIENDLINESS.  I don't care if you are French and have excellent food.  Be polite!

Note:  We were 2 females:  Polite we were - - I guarantee you.

Dessert - - skip.  Had the profiteroles and ice cream - - and it really was not that good.  Not worth the calories.  SERVICE PRETTY MUCH SUCKED UPON REFLECTION.  

Would have gladly tipped MORE than 15% IF SERVICE HAD BEEN BETTER.

I was greeted in a friendly enough manner by waitress when I first entered restaurant.  

When I went to ask the chef what the Fixed price menu consisted of, rather than answering my question, he opened the menu and pointed his finger at it.  RUDE.  I didn't get upset or display any negative stuff, though.  I just sat down and read the menu.  

I still had to wait for my friend to arrive, and she was driving over from Oakland specifically to meet me at this restaurant.  

Wait person (female) was nice enough to start, but FORGOT to bring us a bread basket during our meal and FORGOT to bring me a glass of wine during the meal.  RESTAURANT WAS NOT CROWDED AT ALL, so being overly busy not adequate excuse/reason.

I noticed the waitress "fawning" over an older couple, and basically, giving me bare-bones service.  I had to wait for lemon for water.  She eventually brought it, though it seemed like a really long wait for something so simple, and there was only 2 other people in the restaurant at the time besides me.

I ordered a second glass of wine during the middle of my meal,  which she just forgot to bring.  Okay.  Did not get upset, just noticed the sub-standard service.  Very slow as well.  

Again, dessert is not worth it.  Tasted bland and like the profiterole was stale.  NOW, UPON REFLECTION, I REALIZE THAT IT IS UNIVERSAL THAT NOTHING IS FRESHLY BAKED ON A WEDNESDAY.  

So, that being the case, better to order something else.  WHEN WE LEFT THE RESTAURANT, NO ONE SAID A "Thank you".  All of the little touches were LEFT OUT, and contributed to make the experience less than warm and enjoyable.  THE FOOD IS GOOD, THOUGH.  THE ENTREE WAS TRULY, TRULY, YUMMY, AND SO WAS THE SALAD.
author: Diane F.

description: Fantastic brunch at an incredibly reasonable price! I had an omelette -- cooked so well, creamy and stuffed with goat cheese and tomato. The side of potatoes were just crispy, and the mesclun greens were lightly dressed in a creamy-tangy vinaigrette.
author: MichLee A.

description: OK, the atmosphere is charming - gotta love the neighborhood bistro.  The food and service, however...  The steak quality is questionable.  Sure, with rich sauces it tastes better, but i ordered my FILET with the morel sauce on the side and ... chewy gristle much?    Service was very ... French.  I ordered a glass of wine, after starting with water, and the waiter acted like he was doing me a favor getting it for me.  Didnt even stay around long enough to see if my dinner companion wanted a glass ... of anything!  Similarly, one water glass was refilled - the other?  Couldnt be bothered.  If you're packed and serving quality food, I might overlook the occasional empty water glass but on a Sunday night with all of 4 tables full - unacceptable!  Pull it together, Baker St Bistro.  I want to love you!
author: Hope T.

description: I wanted so much to like this place, but I came away from my birthday here underwhelmed.  The best thing there was the escargot, fries and walnut encrusted goat cheese salad.  Everything else was bland and needed to be tasted by the chef/cooks.  Too bad.  I really had high hopes.
author: E P.

description: Only been to brunch, but it is my default brunch place. Everything is good. French Toast and Eggs Benedict are the best. Never too crowded, great on weekends. Super-friendly staff. Great neighborhood feel. You will love it!
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Like a Paris sidewalk bistro

This place pulls it off, you'd think you had just stepped off the street in Paris.  We went here for lunch, and sat outside on a very nice day.

We had the meat and cheese plate (very good) and the croque monsier.  It was just like one from Paris...it was buttery and crunchy and just felt decadent.  Probably not health food...but oh well.

Even the pomme frite (french fries) we bought for the little one were some of the best I've had.

Two thumbs up...visit this place soon!

http://www.theholstory.blogspot.com/
author: nunov y.

description: I have only had the pleasure of experiencing breakfast here but I was impressed.  Eggs over easy perfectly done-ie eggs were still runny-, yummy potatoes and all you can eat baguette.  The owner is very French and very charming.  The prints of Paris that grace the walls make you feel like you're in a tiny Parisian bistro.
author: Amber L.

description:
after the heart wrenching film 'la vie en rose,' about french chanteuse edith piaf, my dear friend and i wanted to keep the french theme going well into dinner.  we decided to swing by baker street bistro, an old favorite and an always solid standard.

i love a good prix fixe menu, and on sunday evenings at BBB, it lasts all night.  delicious creme of asparagus soup, a large bone in pork chop with reduction, creamy mashed potatoes, a small mixed green salad, and the most delightful chocolate pot-au-creme for dessert.  for $16.50.  enough said.

also great for weekend brunch.  they do an excellent eggs benedict.   the hollandaise sauce is light and delicate, not heavy and oily.  homemade pate with petit cornichons  is always good. and where else can you regularly find rabbit on the menu? 

service can sometimes be spotty, but i chalk it up the the french atmosphere, and try to enjoy it.  it is a nice break from being rushed out the door, hat in hand.

j'aime baker street bistro.
author: Mimi G.

description:
I went here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon. The food was excellent (4-5 stars) but the service was pretty bad. 

It took the waitress 30 minutes to give us our drinks, and we had to remind someone to bring us bread. When we finally got our food, which was delicious, we realized that half of us were missing silverware and we had to track down a waiter.

Come here if you are not in a rush!
author: Nicole V.

description: I went here recently on a date and I had the absolute best time.  The pinot noir was majestic!!!  I also reccomend the chicken...it was juicy and very flavorfull.  It has a  really nice and romantic atmosphere and I love any place where the owner will come around to the tables to see how everyone is doing.  I cannot say enough about this place, just go!
author: Jess S.

description:
I left this restaurant pissed. Very pissed. I left without even getting my food. I realize that the restaurant was slammed, but please don't seat me if you can't handle more customers! We waited for over an hour and still had not received our food. We had to wait for over fifteen minutes just to have our waiter come to our table! Then, when the table of six french tourists got their food before ours, despite them arriving twenty minutes after us, I couldn't take it. 

I told the French speaking waiter/manager/host person that we had been waiting for our food for too long. Are we actually expected to pay the same amount as if we had received good service? He acted like a prick. Acted obnoxious and did nothing. Thats when my boyfriend asked for the bill to pay for the wine (we had finished long ago) and the soup. Then we biz-ounced.

I am only giving this place two stars because the soup was good and the woman that worked there was very nice. Otherwise, it was annoying, frustrating and obnoxious. They need to hire more people or a better manager.
author: Renee H.

description: There's something about waking up late on a sunny sunday morning with nothing to do and going to a little bistro to eat outside in the warmth and sip mimosas and chowing down on some delicoius breakfast foods AND lunch.  BRUNCH!   I adored this place and recommend it to everyone and anyone.  We hardly had to wait considering it was easter sunday and got a nice table outside in the sun.  I had the french toast and a glass of the mimosas and made my pal get the mussles with the pommes frites.  One of the most enjoyable moments in my San Francisco eating experiences.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Really good. We had a great time.  Good service and good food.  Duck, salmon, and the steak and fries were good.  Desserts were good as well.
author: Dan W.

description: This is a terrific neighborhood spot, right by the Presidio. They have a delicious brunch but dinner is pretty good as well. Service can be spotty but you're there with friends, so what's the rush? The mussels are heavenly. I was saddened to find out they would not make my favorite drink - an Arnold Palmer.
author: Nish N.

description: Had the cheese omlete it was decent. I like how it was pretty cheesey. A friend ordered the croque madam after seeing people next to us ordering it. Now THAT looked and tasted amazing
author: Jenny C.

description: 2 Stars is solely for the Croque Madame, it was really good! That's all!
author: Christina D.

description: C'est vachement bon et absolument francais. Le menu prix fixe est formidable (quelle valeur!) et ce n'est pas mal commander a la carte non plus. Les garcons sont tres aimables.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Met some friends here for brunch this morning. We were able to be seated immediately (started at 10:30) and enjoyed a long, leisurely brunch. We chose to sit inside, though the tables outside were perfectly covered in sun. 
3 of the 4 of us had the french toast, and the odd man out had the nicoise salad. I loved the french toast, but needed to have a stomach the size of Paul Bunyan's to finish my dish. The pieces of bread looked like Wonder Bread on steroids! So much goodness, but so filling. 
My second choice was the croque monsieur, and I'm certainly going to go back to try it. I'm sure the person at the table next to me was wishing I'd stop staring at their dish over their shoulder too! 
My cafe au lait was just fair, nothing spectacular. And I'm sure that some wheelchair accessibility could be made if you called ahead and/or asked the wait staff for help.
Best of all, we were able to enjoy a nearly 2-2/12 hours at the table with no one breathing down our neck to leave. That's what you want in your Sunday brunch!
author: Jennifer C.

description: The service is a little slow but friendly, and you can't beat the $14.50 prix fixe menu of decent generic French food.
author: Tak K.

description: The best eggs benny in town.  Served on a sunny sidewalk with rosemary potatoes and a mixed green salad.  Seriously, the best.
author: Amme P.

description: The prix fixe for $16.50 is definitely the way to go here, what a great deal!  The food is good - nothing mindblowing, but you get a bowl of soup, a small salad, entree and dessert.  The service is wonderful and the owner comes around to make sure you are enjoying yourself.  The crowd tends to be an older Pac Heights crew and eavesdropping is always interesting (don't mean to, but the tables are smooshed together).  Be sure to make reservations!
author: Lisa C.

description:
For some, Baker Street Bistro may have a certain charm.  It's small and reminiscent of corner cafes in Paris neighborhoods. 

But in the end it's the food that counts and I've been disppointed twice now. My first dinner there  was off the menu and so unremarkable that I 
can't remember what I had.  

On my last visit, I chose the prix fix dinner.  At $16 it  was a "bargain" but the food lacked  personality or appeal.  The  chicken and potato were smothered in a tomato-based sauce and had almsot no taste; the  white pepper available at the table didn't help boast the flavor.  
The cheese coating on the lobster bisque was stringy,  making it  awkward to eat.  The finale was a small  white colored  gelatin- based dessert, with a faint coconut flavor.

My companion had the  steak ($24)  and said "It was ok, nothing great."

Another  disappointment was the 5 oz. serving of  unexceptional wine for  $7.50.  

The cheesey American music from the 80's playing  in the background became vaguely annoying; it was certainly incongruous.  

On the positive side; the service was pleasant; the waitor served us  promptly.  My chicken dish arrived luke-warm and the waitor took it back without a problem to have it reheated.  The french bread was fresh.
author: susan m.

description: So friendly and the food is always great. Our son, who's 29 mos, loves it and service is so accommodating for families. This is a staple.
author: traci n.

description: I love this place, have been coming here from time to time for the last 13 years. Very nice atmosphere, great for a simple romantic dinner.
author: Miki M.

description: This classic San Francisco icon keeps on giving.  I have been there for lunch several times and I am impressed to see that the quality of the food and service easily surpasses what it used to be under the previous owner.  Prices are very reasonable, the ambience is cozy and friendly and the chef/owner manages to turn out delicious, classic French dishes without the traditional use of heavy sauces.  A keeper.
author: Fabrice H.

description: This is a lovely and cheap place for authetic french food...and not so authentic breakfasts...try the brioche french toast, if you don't die from insulin shock you will be very very happy.
author: Chris C.

description: Baker Street Bistro is an authentic French cafe and is one of my two favorite restaurants in all of San Francisco.  (the other being A16 which is much pricier!)  The food is extraordinary, fresh and delicious with only the best local ingredients.  For those who said the service was sub-par I urge you to reconsider.  This is a true French cafe, by that I mean that when you come here you should expect that your meal is an adventure in and of itself and that you should take your time enjoying the entire process of French dining.  I think too many of us, myself included, are so used to the rush and hectic pace of the Bay Area that we simply can't enjoy food and a slower pace the way the authentic French staff at Baker Street Bistro expect people to.  I love that I can even bring my dog if we sit outside under the heat lamps on a cool day.  Honestly, you won't get better food for the price here,  it's hard to get better food anywhere in my opinion.
author: Julia S.

description: Intimate neigborhood bistro... All the French bistro fare one would expect. Great fish and salads.  A bit cramped, but with a $17 prix fixe you can't complain.  I almost forgot... brunch is a hidden treasure here. Usually no wait and good eggs benedict.
author: Todd J.

description: You have to like the prix fixe menu.  You can get some great food in the little neighborhood for surprisingly good prices.  Interesting wine list, and the waitstaff gives great recommendations.  Parking is usually not too bad, so if you aren't having an entire bottle, feel free to drive over.
author: Robert R.

description: This place is a bit hidden but really cute - a good date place. The food was amazing. I had a seafood stew that I really enjoyed. The staff was crazy friendly - our waiter was very knowledgeable and helpful. I'll definitely have to go back to try the four course fixed price menu for $15.
author: Barney M.

description: I've been here for lunch and dinner.  For dinner, I've ordered off their regular menu and ordered from their prix-fixe menu as well and I have to say that everything I've tried has been really good.  Service can be a bit slow when they are busy but otherwise a great place to go for couples, or a friend or two.  This is not a kid place nor a big group kind of place.  Parking can be difficult at times.
author: Stella C.

description: A great small french cafe.  One of the best breakfast's i've found in the city so far.  Order the French Toast or if you like omlette's try the only one on the menu, ham and swiss cheese with mushrooms.
author: Brian P.

description:
awesome find in the Marina, their prix fix meal was amazing... the duck confit so delicious and the potato leak soup was really good to.  definitely a great night out,  sit outside order their three course meal, and a carafe of wine. Affordable and fun. 

but be prepared to enjoy a leisurely meal, our server seemed way stressed even on a Sunday night, I cut him some slack as they were pretty busy and he was the only one running the front of the house.
author: Joy Y.

description: The best prix fixe value in the city! And wonderful service. They have fantastic frites and great brunch.
author: Lucinda N.

description:
I went there prior to seeing a concert at the Palace of fine arts, I took my gf who's has a better taste for french cuisine, so while I cannot comment on the "frenchness" of the dishes, I'll boil this down for the casual diner.

Ambience: It's a 'hole in the wall' which is great, it was packed and lots of people talking/laughing and having a good time.  Atypical of most french restaurants.  There were even families there with their kids, so as one who knows little about french cuisine, I actually liked it.

Bread was good, crunchy on the outiside chewy on the inside, however, they didn't bring us any bread plates so we had to use napkins.

Wine:  We had a glass of the house Syrah and Chardonney.  The odd thing was that if you ordered a bottle of wine, they brought you larger/thinner wine glasses, while if you ordered just a glass, they filled your the small wine glasses that were already on the table.

I had a "mixed greens salad" and that was exactly that.  A plate of mixed greens like you'd find in a bag at the supermarket lightly coated with olive oil.  While I like mixed greens, there was nothing else in the salad and for $7, it was no worth it.

Duck breast glazed, this was actually quite good, duck was very tender and flavorful.  While the duck confit appeared overdone and there were more lentils then duck.

Dessert:  Peach melba. The peach had the taste as if it came out of a Del Monte can with two raspberries and some cream.  For $12 they could use real peaches.  the apple tart was much better, but it really tasted like a slice of apple pie with creme fresh on top.  Not the best pie and many of the apple slices had the 'shells' that surround the seeds still on them.  Seems the cores were cut a bit to close.

I'm ranking this a 2 because honestly, for the high price that we, or rather I, paid for this meal I didn't get much value out of it, nor was the food particularly amazing.  I've eaten in plenty of $50/person places and this wasn't close to delivering what I would expect for dinner.  I wanted it to work out, but there were quite a few let downs.
author: S M.

description: This place is tiny and hidden and really...really good.  The manager is nice, I went with a few of my friends and we were about...an hour late for our reservation (not my fault) so when we got there our reservation had obviously been given away and we had to wait.  However the manager seated us in the outdoor area  while we waited for a table and we ordered appetizers and wine while we waited. The service is great and so is the atmosphere. I came here with my boyfriend once without reservations and we were seated right away. I did feel a bit awkward as the crowd around us was definitively older and, well, caucasian but, still, love the food and love the service. I'll keep coming back.
author: Tiff L.

description: I would come here again because the food is decent, the location good, and the venue welcoming. I was here for lunch so the price was fine but there wasn't a lot to choose from. My friend had gotten the muscles and they were delicious! If you do decide to come here, be prepared for cramped spaces and slow service.
author: Rosa K.

description: Classic french. Good service. Friends were pleased with the tartar and lamb chops. I had the lamb stew which was ok. Meat was good but stew could have some taste.
author: Ivar S.

description: This is a terrific neighborhood gem.  Try the mussels.  They are to die for.
author: Emily M.

description: Went here with friends when we were running late for a show at the Palace of Fine Arts. The waiter was awesome - took our order & had our food on the table in about 15 minutes flat.  Good food, good wine, really intimate neighborhood vibe.
author: Marjorie M.

description: My problem here are the crowds. I just cant stand listening to their conversations. I am just visiting San Francisco so maybe the marina is just not for me. It all seems like boring BS, There are bunch of people in this area that want to play "the see and be seen game" Hell, I just want to eat, The baker street breakfast special is very good. It has an excellent flavor. It is not too heavy and it not too light. Try it,
author: Jason W.

description: As Skylar says, REAL French waiters and waitresses... and they are, but they're amazingly friendly and helpful, too. I've been there a coupla dozen of times and never had a complaint (they run out of dishes on occasion, but good places do that if the food is fresh!) Go for a casual dinner, take the recommendation for wine, and just relax. This isn't full-on atmosphere, but the price is unbeatable.
author: Jeffrey A.

description: Yummy french food (but more Americanized sizes) and a decent wine selection.  A little Marina gem that shouldn't be overlooked.  There's also a fun dive-y bar across the street if you don't want the night to end after dinner :)
author: Allison K.

description: The bland leading the bland. Traditional French dishes prepared poorly and with no seasoning. I really don't recommend this place.
author: Evan S.

description: I love this little bistro. It is right down the street from me. My roommate and I come here frequently. The food is light and fresh, try the warm goat cheese salad its amazing. Its a really cozy restaurant which at times you can hear every word the person is saying next to you. However I love coming here when all you want to do is unwind have some good wine and a good meal and chit chat with a friend/sig other.
author: Erin R.

description: It was my first time at this place, we had brunch on a Saturday morning.  I liked the French charm of the setting and the food was good.  I was a little surprised that there were so few people there (maybe 3 tables in use), but it was a good experience.  I'll definitely go back.
author: Chris P.

description: A solid four stars.  This place has great french food.  The portions are the perfect size.  Very French.  I love the moules frites here.  I had a fish dish which had lavender in it.  What an interesting and refreshing combination.  The steak here is also good.  The wine list could be more extensive, but it is in keeping with France.  Most little bistros in France have fairly limited wine lists.  I want to come back here to give a more detailed review.
author: apple r.

description: Their french onion soup was really good....it was actually a lot of soup, so by the time my duck entree arrived, I was pretty full.  The service was great and the food was excellent.  The duck was very tender but had crispiness on the skin.  I took some bites of steak and pomme frites from my companions, those were delicious as well.  Would go back again.
author: Emiko M.

description: Tucked away in a quiet residential neighborhood between Lombard and Greenwich Streets, this cafe offers an inviting atmosphere inside and out. Great French style brunch and the salad was very yummy. Sit outside on a warm day and bask in the sun rays....
author: Yan M.

description: Great for brunch.  We stopped in after learning that Curbside was no longer.   I had the eggs florentine, which was perfect.   I enjoy the outside seating aspect of the place.  We'll have to come back for dinner.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Stopped by on a Friday evening with no reservation and was seated promptly.  The place can be considered cozy or cramped depending on your mood.  The tables are close enough where you can hear others next to you speak but it doesn't really matter unless you're trying to listen haha.  The bistro is a small little place neatly tucked off Baker St. on the neighborhood side.  The decor was nothing special but felt very warm and natural.  Although we didn't need to make reservations it definitely got busy after we came in (around 7:45).

On to the good stuff; I thought the food was great.  The service was decent to good but not great.  Our waiter did try to check up on us as often has he could but he was clearly busy with many other tables as the whole restaurant only had two waiters.  On the times he did stop by he was very nice and sincere so I'll cut him some slack.  Oh yeah, back to the food.  Everything was great.  We started off  our dinner with the French onion soup and a wild mushroom soup (puree).  Both soups were great.  The French onion had a nice rich broth with plenty of onions and was topped with piece of bread and slice of gruyere all melted and bubbly from the oven.  It was served in a nice little miniature crock pot which was a nice touch.  For our entrees we had the crusted seared sea bass and the seafood stew (cioppino like) served with a vegetable risotto.  Both dishes were great except for the side of risotto which tasted a bit undercooked. We washed everything down with 2 glasses of bordeaux.  Next time I want some authentic French bistro food in a cozy setting i'll be sure to stop by here agian.
author: Steven H.

description: Cute, quaint bistro!  Everyone I talked to before trying this place raved about the great prie fixe menu and now I see why.  The dining area is tiny, not good for groups, but perfect for a date or meeting an old friend to catch up.  Bonus:  easy street parking!
author: Katie P.

description: I haven't eaten here in years and remembered really liking it so I stopped by on Saturday night with the family. We started with the mixed green salad and some escargots. Both were delicious and even my kids enjoyed the salad and snails. We then had the Duck a l'ornage, Lamb stew, and vegetarian risotto. The duck was just okay...kind of bland and with a sauce that had a slightly unpleasant taste. I've had better duck elsewhere. The lamb stew was really good with lots of lamb and vegetables in a delicious broth. My favorite was the risotto, cooked perfectly and with fantastic flavor especially for a vegetarian meal. The desserts are all great, you can't go wrong. Great atmosphere and super friendly waitstaff. On a pleasant evening sit outside under the heatlamps and enjoy the fresh air.
author: Brian L.

description:
Just had lunch here today after a failed attempt to visit the new Academy of Sciences. The mussels and fries were even better than I remembered!! We also had the mixed greens with crusted goat cheese and the cauliflower puree soup. The salad is always satisfying, we can't seem to get enough of that goat cheese. YUM! The cauliflower soup was definitely cauliflower, so I wouldn't recommend it unless you love cauliflower. I do, so it was perfect for me. The mussels and fries were awesome!! For dessert we had the strawberries with balsamic, brown sugar and cracked pepper glaze over vanilla ice cream. TO DIE !! Between us we also had some super strong french press coffee and a mocha...delicious. They seemed to be short staffed today, there was one waitress and the owner/manager and head chef(?) helped out where they could. Even though service was a bit slow it's a nice place to linger. I sympathize with other people on hearing other people's conversations. I hate that!! I try not to listen but it's hard when you're practically sitting on other people's laps. Here's a snippet I overheard today about one guy's croque  monsieur:
Lady: Mmmm is that Bay-Cam-el sauce?
Dude: Oooh yeah 
Lady: I think it's a caramel sauce
Dude: hmmm maybe
Lady: Yeah I think it is
Grrr! I know it's bitchy of me to get irritated over people mispronouncing a widely used French sauce but this couple was sprinkling French all over their conversation like they were oh so sophisticated. Maybe they are but  it just rubbed me the wrong way. The correction was fighting so hard to escape my throat that I had to gulp down a bunch of water. Ah well, that couple being elitist and my own elitism is just par for the course in this area. Snoot Snoot Snoot!!
author: JoAnna S.

description: 4 stars because I've been here for dinner and it was good, but not incredible. BUT their FRENCH TOAST is amazing. The best I've ever had. It's served with creme fraiche on the side and it just melts in your mouth. Plus, there is a head server there that is always snapping at everyone (the staff, not the customers) and she has the best accent and I love watching her run around- pure comedy!
author: E. N.

description: Excellent, cozy place for first class French cuisine.  The owner is always friendly and hospitable, and the food excellent.  On a warm evening it's a great place to sit outside... Prix Fixe early im the evening is especially good value.
author: Martin B.

description: Very cute bistro with delicious food and friendly staff. Great for dinners and they have a prix fixe menu for under $15...I've never been disappointed here. My absolute favorite dish is the Mussels Provencale with fries...ahhh, they have great fries.
author: Mellie D.

description:
Great brunch.  I had the French toast - it was amazing.  Came with some fruit and a creamy sauce.  The portion was large, the toast felt fluffy and tasted very light.

Only word of warning is that the bistro takes a long time.  I personally enjoy that on a nice weekend day, but a word of warning.
author: Zoran M.

description: I really like dining at Baker Street Bistro.  They are casual, inexpensive, cozy and welcoming.  I love their prix-fixe meal that happens before 7pm.  You get a lot of food for roughly $15.  You just cant find a better deal.  The restaurant is tiny, but gives you the feeling you are dining in france.  Their wine selection is nice and reasonable.  I recommend this place to anyone looking for a good meal at a decent price.
author: Lolo S.

description: Friendly service.  My girlfriend's French toast wasn't cooked all the way through, but for the most part the food was good.  Nice, off the 'beaten path' of Union and Chestnut.
author: Andrej A.

description: Very cute little bistro, keeps us coming back.  The food and service are alway really good, never had to worry about anything.  To us it's one of those places that invites people back over and over without an implied invite, you just want to go.
author: Mike S.

description: I recently took over 30 seats in the restaurant for a private party that was a complete success.  Danel the chef was fantastic in helping me design a menu for the event and the staff was wonderful and fun the night of the party.  I highly recommend working with them on private events.  One of the best restaurants in the city for a spectacular quiet dinner and an even better spot for an intimate dinner party.  The food far exceeded our expectations!
author: Tory P.

description:
I came here for dinner a week ago with some friends. I ordered the duck confit with the side of cut potatoes and mushrooms. Its VERY delicious!! We also had snail for appetizer. I'm not much of a snail fan but ate one just to try. I'd have to say..their snail is quite good. =P My two other friends had the steak which they said was 'good' but they tried my duck and they were blown away. haha! Order the DUCK CONFIT!

The place is pretty small but very cozy .The waiter was very nice and always refilled the water. On top of that, the price for each dish is around $20. Great food for an affordable price! I am coming back soon!
author: Jess L.

description: this place makes me miss sf even more.  i used to come here for that prix fixe.  come on, you can't beat a prix fixe for under 20 bucks.  anyway.  the ambiance, location, and food are delightful.  not the best french food i've had (that would have to be fleur de lys... hubert kellers masterpiece), but for a neighborhood french place it's amazing.
author: paul l.

description: A nice little neighborhood French restaurant. This is a great spot for a date or a late Sat/Sun afternoon glass of wine.
author: Raymond M.

description: I don't think they do anything wrong here for lunch.  Food is fantastic.  They have a broad lunchtime selection beyond baguettes and croque monsieurs -- pork chops, sea bass, pastas, etc.  Great deserts as well.  If you're in the Marina/Presidio for lunch, it's hard to do better.
author: Tim G.

description:
first dressy dinner with my grls... food there are pricey that why its kinda of upscale!! I had chicken breast with mashed potato and spinch..it was GReat!! and we shared four different dessert which are creme burlee, stawberry, cake, vanilla ice cream cream puff....hmmm... heavEN!! would go there for dessert!!! witress and waiter have fRENCH ACCENT.. having hard time understanding them!!
    second time i went back with my friends.. i ordered the duck and it was great.. and i tried the vanilla ice cream with peaches and almonds, and a chocolate mousse cake.. all was delicious...
author: Lily T.

description: Lord have merci - my fillet was cooked perfectly, and I ended up eating the whole thing and a good amount of crisp frites too. The apple tartine, although rather too sweet, was a very generous portion.
author: GIR ..

description: I have been going to this resturant for many, many many years with my family. I love the grilled chilcken... the goat cheese salad and the chicken leg with risotto... the mussles in a pesto-white wine sauce are also great!! Wonderful brunches as well..!! xooxo
author: Liz C.

description:
This is a nice little place a block away from the Presidio gates. I've been going here since I moved to SF a couple years ago and at one point it was our weekly dinner spot. The food is great and the casual French menu and relaxed atmosphere make for a nice date spot or friendly night out in the neighborhood. They have a great fixed price menu (at last check $16.50 for four courses) and brunch is outstanding - seriously try the french toast. 

Unfortunately they just can't get the service down (trying to be a little too French?). It is the reason I have to hold back on the making this a four-star review. It seems like they just don't know the basics of serving a table. Across the board they lack the little things: asking for a drink order when approaching the table, checking in on tables, refilling drinks and being friendly. 

The service isn't terrible, but it leaves a lot to be desired. Eventually it was the reason we stopped going there for our weekly dinners and primarily just hit it up for brunch or the occasional dinner. Don't let it stop you from going to the BSB because they've done a great job with the food and bringing a French-style bistro to the city.
author: Dan W.

description: Great brunch option in the Marina neighborhood.  Food was perfectly cooked, service was great too.  Not crowded at all, coffee was really good too.
author: Michael M.

description: This place is great.. REAL French waiters and waitresses. Meow! The croque monsieur is a hit. I went here once with my entire French class and it was great. Eating brunch outside on sunny mornings is very delightful too. Good service with a French accent, and yummy food.. ahh.. Paris!
author: O K.

description: The best brunch place. Period. Je l'aime.
author: Anand I.

description: Food is great!!!  On popular evenings the service may be spotty, but the staff is very warm & friendly.  Just had my first brunch there -- will definitely be eating more early meals at the Bistro!
author: Sharon P.

description: Tres bon!  What I like best is that I really feel like I am in France when I eat here (only the waitstaff is friendly at BSB).  It's cozy here, the food is divine and plentiful, and it has a great neighborhood vibe.
author: Bette K.

description: A solid, but not amazing bistro.  Very small, friendly service, charming atmosphere.  The tuna tartar was a bit on the tough side.  Had a very traditionally prepared steak frite, which was quite good.  Excellent garlic butter on top (how could it not be good!) and well prepared, moderate quality new york strip.  The wine recommended by the waiter (and owner I'm guessing) was good, but not great.  Overall, I'd be fine with returning but it won't be on the top of my list.
author: Graham M.

description:
Best French Toast in the city.

The food at Baker is pretty good all around, although we frequent it more for Sat/Sun breakfast.  The french toast is the best in the city, with sweet creme fraiche and excellet fresh fruit.  This place makes you happy every time you go.
author: Ken M.

description: I really love this place because the prices are great for what you get - great food and excellent service.  It's also a very quaint and romantic place, and it's nice to go to when you want to avoid the restaurants on Chestnut but still want to be close by so you can walk around afterwards.
author: Karen L.

description: We sometimes walk by on neighborhood rambles and it always caught our eye, but we hadn't yet made it in for dinner.  Then this afternoon I happened to be walking by with my dog and noticed all the other diners outside with their dogs, and I took in the tempting aroma of another diner's steamed  mussels, and it seemed like a very good idea to stop and eat.  The salade nicoise and the moules were delicious.  The service was very good. The dog slept at my feet.   It was just lovely.
author: Matilda S.

description: My duck leg (Confit de Canard) was the best I have ever had.  We went here for lunch, utterly delightful.  Authentic French.
author: Allan K.

description:
We've walked by the place a few times, but never stopped in to eat.  Finally decided to walk over for a taste recently.  Though there was room inside, we chose to sit outside, given a rare warm evening in San Francisco.

Star each for location, good bistro feel, and food.

They have a good menu with a number of daily specials that appears to rotate regularly, based on the changes we noticed each time we have walked by and peeked at the menu.  

1 star ding on the service.  It was a Tuesday evening and there was only one waitress, plus a server/helper.  Not sure if they were short staffed, or the combination of us sitting outside.  However, it took a while to get our order taken and it was hard to get service (water refills etc...) in between.  

Also, we passed on the wine, not really in the mood.  Plus the glasses looked like they held about 2 shots of wine (no exaggeration here).

Overall, cozy, off-the-beaten-path neighborhood bistro.  Service was slow, but friendly.  Food was above par.
author: George C.

description: I love this little place.  I have been twice.  Once for Sunday brunch and once for dinner and will definitely be going back.  I had a New York steak cooked to perfection while my boyfriend had th prix fixe menu which, first of all, was cheaper than my steak, and second featured the most delicious duck confit I have ever tasted.  I literally wanted to order everything on the menu.  As much I enjoyed my steak, I saw someone at a nearyby table eating french onion and was like, DAMN! I should have gotten that too.  Next time, and there will be one.  This place is fantastic! Also, some great friends live a block from here and frequent this place all the time.  They got married last October and they received a set of coffee mugs from Baker St. Bistro as a wedding gift.  They were so touched!
author: Knitgirl P.

description: One of my favorite places for almost 10 years.  Take your dog and sit outside for brunch on the weekend. Take your partner and have a special cozy weekday dinner.  Not very private, but it is a bistro after all.  I hear the Gettys walk down the hill to eat here.  Wouldn't know them if I saw them, but the rumor adds a bit of elegance to the experience.
author: Peter F.

description: BSB is second only to Zazie for uber-tasty brunch food in the city.  Their house specialty, the french toast, is to DIE for....thick, rich, a little soggy, and served with fresh fruit and a dollop of sweet yogurt.  The eggs florentine are also absolutely outstanding.  Almost everything is, actually.  Except the service.  The wait staff do try hard but they always have too many tables to give any of them a high level of service.  So don't go if you're in a rush, but know that the food is ALWAYS worth the wait.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The prix fixe dinner is offered between 5:00-7:00 and we arrived at 6:55 and they honored the dinner to us.  It was very good.  Tonight was the pork tenderloin and it was very tender.  The sauce was tastefully prepared.  The fried cauliflower was not oily or greasy.  The dessert was bread pudding and was alittle dense but the sauce was delicous.

They need to update their website to reflect the accurate prices.  The items are about $2-$3 more than the current website.
author: Arlene L.

description:
This place has solid eats but this review isn't about food.

I went here for Mother's Day with 5 other people and didn't realize they had an automatic gratuity policy. I tipped them over 20% on top of the original tip and... they refunded the entire original tip back according to my cc statement.

Call me a cynic but I don't think most places would do such a thing.

One thing that drives me nuts about these receipts is that it's hard to notice the automatic gratuity line, especially when you're in a big group and busy celebrating. I wish our waitress could have told us when she gave us the check.

Still, I'm pleasantly surprised.
author: jj w.

description: Phenomenal! Can't wait until Jacques's new place opens at Grove & Central in NOPA!
author: Brian W.

description: We stumbled onto this place one day when walking to the Presido.  We sat outside and just basked in the sun while we ate our delicious French breakfast.  Much quieter and more intimate then anyplace on Chestnut and Union.  Surely on the expensive side, but pretty much on par with everything in the Marina.
author: She-ra Princess of power M.

description: I went to this restaurant for dinner with some friends.  We sat inside and enjoyed the cozy and quiet atmosphere.  The waiters and waitresses were friendly and helpful.  I liked the salad with goat cheese.  My friends said the lamb stew was delicious.  We all had desserts which were excellent.  I especially like the sauteed strawberries with balsamic vinegar and pepper with ice cream.  It was a pleasant experience and a satisfying meal.
author: Kim S.

description: Beuatiful Saturday afternoon in the city + 4 girlfriends + a perfect lunch menu = you can bet your favorite pair of bunny slippers I'll stop in again
author: N. C.

description: last night was our first time at Baker St Cafe.   Approaching the restaurant, you would know immediately it was a French bistro.  The exterior reminded me very much of the Art Deco style of all Metropolitan station entrances in Paris and many Parisian hotels, complete with elegant chairs and tables in the patio for outside dining (on warmer days).  The interior was warm, cozy, with many touches again of French decors and fabrics.  The friendly host and head chef came to chat with us at our table.  We felt instantly welcomed.  But the best part was the food itself.  The menu was a comprehensive map of France itself with so many authentic items to choose from.  The price was shockingly reasonable for a French restaurant.  The four of us ordered different dishes and appetizers, and each dish was impeccable!  The portion was just sufficient yet not offensively large as in many typical American restaurants.  The desserts were perfect and exquisite, as you would expect a French dessert to be.  The servers and the host knew when to check in and socialize with us and when to leave us to our food and conversations.  We had a wonderful time (for a very small price).  We would definitely bring more friends back here for dinner, lunch or brunch.  Baker St Bistro is a gem in a city that's only second to New York City in the number of restaurants.  You get honest, good, authentic French food at neighborhood-bistro prices in a beautiful ambiance among friendly, pleasant staff and patrons.  I highly recommend Baker St. Bistro.  Try it for yourself and bring many friends.
author: Alain T.

description: This place was just OK.  Service , not good, food OK.  I found it on Yelp and am very dissapointed.  But in all fairness I must say, the people next to me ordered the same thing and raved about it the entire time they ate, so perhaps it's just me (and my boyfriend) who thinks this place is over-rated.
author: Debbie M.

description: Every time I have gone here it has been great.  Need I say more?
author: Jack M.

description: I thought this place wasn't horrible but I expected much better. It doesn't say much when your favorite item is the bread basket. Maybe I just ordered the wrong dishes or something but the french onion soup was kind of bland, the house cured salmon salad was kind of weird (my bf didn't like it, so I ate it for him) and the scallops I thought tasted like dried scallops (chinese style). I was expecting them to be soft in texture and to melt in my mouth like most scallops I've had. Nope. The best dish was the mussels and the french fries, but not eaten together. The soup in the mussel dish was good, however too sweet for my taste and not warm enough. Plus, it's not very good if you dip the fries in the soup, try dipping the bread instead. I just don't understand. I mean the ambiance was nice, I felt like I was really eating at a bistro in France (even though I've never been to France, but it just felt like it). Maybe it was late and the chefs wanted to go home to their families and didn't care about pleasing our palates. Maybe I'm just being too harsh on them. Maybe they're more known for their brunch. Or maybe I'm making too many excuses for them...
author: Mary H.

description: food is more on the average side but for a 3 course prix fixe before 7pm to cost only $16.50....they get an extra star.
author: Katie K.

description: love this place.  the french toast and eggs florentine were delicious- my idea of the perfect breakfast! when we went (sunday morning) we didn't have to wait, which was surprising to me as it is a lot better than a lot of the popular brunch spots in the bay area (in my opinion). definitely a gem.
author: Elle C.

description: Saturday afternoon lunch, Tasty food, great service, and nice alfresco atmosphere, however a limited menu because it was a brunch menu.
author: Bryant M.

description:
Foutage de guele !

I ate with a very large group of people with an overpriced fixed menu.  About half the table got the skate, and unfortunately, most of the pieces reeked and tasted of ammonia (as if the sauce was made of Mr. Clean - that bad). The shockingly rude waiter, instead of apologizing, said that it happens sometimes (afterward I read that  ammonia contamination can happen if the fish is handled improperly as its urine becomes ammonia) and didn't want to take them back even after sniffing them. After some insistence, he did reluctantly. The chef then came out and said that the fish was fresh, again not taking responsibility for putting out inedible and perhaps dangerous plates of food.    No respectable chef would dare have such a vile plate (in this case, about six of them!) of food leave his kitchen, and no decent waiter would dare do anything but apologize profusely and offer some compensation.  

Vous devriez avoir honte, messieurs !
author: Quincy B.

description: Baker Street Bistro is one of the best deal you can find in SF.  The fix price menu should be particularly noted, great food for the price.  We have been having dinner there for many times over the years and are always happy to try new things.  The only downside is the place can get really crowded and it would be tough to have a quality conversation and wait could be long during weekend nights with no reservation taken.
author: Luk S.

description: i love this place a lot! it's cozy, the waitstaff are nice, and it's just overall a good place to eat some awesome french cuisine on the cheap.
author: Tommy C.

description: My hubby and I came here for brunch on a Sunday. Kinda busy, the servers looked harried and didn't seem like they were communicating with each other. We got a seat outside on the sidewalk. Hubby got the Croque Monsieur, it looked tasty and covered in cheese and bechemel, yum. I had the French Toast. Made with 2 slices of Pan de Mie, it was extremely soft and tender and custardy on the inside and crispy on the outside. On the side was a fruit salad, creme fraiche and strawberry jam and the citrusy syrup was just the right touch. I can't say much about the coffee because I had tea instead but the couple beside us seemed to enjoy their coffee and brunch as well. All in all it was a nice place to go to with good food. The restaurant wasn't completely full on this day but I would hate to see what it would be like if this place were in full swing with the service seeming so weak as it is. I would still go back though, for the food and the location (quiet, sleepy little street).
author: cora j.

description: I just had a great Xmas Eve Dinner at this restaurant. The restaurant reopened not too long ago by new owners Danel and Dave.  I like the new decor the new owners brought to this restaurant.  They also designed a chic new logo.  Food was delicious.  We ordered the prix fix menu: I started off with lobster salad, my boyfriend ordered baked oysters with leeks.  Both were really good, but the baked oysters were "out-of-this-world" good.  The leek added a real frenchy taste to this dish.  Our entries were rack of lamb and steak.  Chef Danel is really  an expert at searing meat. Lamb was seasoned perfectly with rosemary and cooked to perfection. There was the crispy crunch from the searing of the meat with herb, then the meat inside is juicy, tender and full of flavor.  Same for the steak.  The outside was seared perfectly, and inside the meat was a perfect medium rare. I also thought it was of good value. Our prix fix menu was $40.  Serving size was generous.  Make this restaurant next on your list to try and add to your favorites!
author: Glenn R.

description: So, here I am with fellow yelper Jacinta J. We ate at the bistro this evening. hmmmm, where do we start.....how about with the fact that there could potentially be fish remnants in my but crack right now. Yeah, you might think this sounds crazy, but I am not kidding. Okay so now that I have your attention, I will tell you about our night......we walk in and the place is looking super cute...not totally full and they tried to give us this table in the corner----but nobody puts baby in a corner!!!!!!! anywho, so we ask for the booth, which they gladly gave us. All is well, and we have fabu glasses of champagne and a nice cheese platter, and THEN, they ask us to move to that f-ing corner table! but they promise us free wine and dessert--a deal we can't pass up. So, we move. Let's just say that the night went downhill from here. We proceeded to wait and wait and wait for some semblance of service, but all we really got was bumped up against, ignored, menus dropped on us, and water glasses left empty....not ideal. then, as we were waiting for our entrees,  they offered us dessert, perfect timing if you ask me ( I'm being sarcastic). After that they tried to serve us the wrong entrees...finally we got the right entrees and just as we were beginning to enjoy our meals, a waiter was walking by with plates he had just cleared and a freaking dirty fish knife dropped onto my coat, and fell into the back of my pants, slipping right into my ass crack...perfect spot for a dirty fish knife, right? Ughhh! kill me. so not my idea of a nice night out! anyway, we already had free dessert and wine, so what else could they do for us? Well maybe they just gave up because they sure seemed to stop trying to make it better. You would think after a dirty knife goes into your ass, they would try to make nice, but NO, not these peeps. I really think that they are good people, but I am just not sure what happened. I mean come on! anyway, our free dessert came, but oddly we had no choice in what type of dessert we got. As we watched the next table over reading their dessert menus, we ate out preselected flan, which I personally don't like. the waitress, however informed me that "everyone likes flan" I said, well I don't. she brought choc cake. whoopdie doo. whatever it is hard to recover from being fish knifed in the butt. Gotta go clean up now!!!
author: Lisa H.

description: Awesome dinner for my first visit to Baker Street Bistro, and I'm not even a fan of French food. I loved the atmosphere - for a small place the layout works well to give diners some privacy even in close quarters. The food and drinks were very tasty and just as described, and the timing on delivery of drinks and each course was perfect. The seafood stew and pear tart (can't remember the actual names of these dishes) were amazing. And the wait staff are hands off, but in a way that is respectful of patrons taking their time, whenever we needed something someone was close by to help. Definitely planning on going back.
author: Dawn R.

description: This place looks adorable from the outside and is a nice, convenient, quiet location - away from the hustle and bustle of Chestnut.  However, the food just wasn't all that good.  It was also very buttery.  Usually the more butter the better!  But butter was all I tasted, not a lot of other flavor.  Maybe dinner is better, but breakast was just ok.
author: Lara B.

description: I have been regular at the Baker for many years and was a little worry when I heard the owner was changing. I went back for the first time with friends on tuesday, their reopening night and I have to say, when I first walked in the place, I was pretty impressed with the change of decor : nice French country look, warmth and comfort all around me! I was already feeling good about the change.The menu is quiet similar to the old one, with a few great additions like lobster salad and my favorite : oysters ...a glass of Sancerre please !The food was excellent overall and we cleaned our dishes. We didn't get to meet the young new chef who seems a little shy but very cute with his French beret... the waiter told us he was the owner as well ...and French, I mean,what else do you need to know !?
author: Jennifer W.

description: Ditto for Julie S.'s review. The change of hands has not been good for the restaurant. Simply not a good value. Some decent things, but mostly mediocre. For ex., each meat dish was cooked wrong--- supposed to be medium rare for the lamb and duck. Each was medium to medium well; supposed to be rare for the steak, but was raw/not even a warm center. In addition, wine prices are EXPLOITIVE.  No bottles for less than $35 and bottles that go for $10 - $20 a bottle were going for minimum of $9 a glass. In such small glasses, this is a 300 - 600 % markup! Many clearly better restaurants have wines at $30 or less. And the service--- we were sitting at a table at which the busboy and waiter could have easily gone to the other side to collect plates, but they asked us to pass them over. Even a server at Denny's wouldn't do that! And why couldn't the waiter tell the busboy where the 1 cappucino went? Our conversation was  interrupted each time they had to deliver something. Who is managing this place?
author: randy b.

description: why is it you never go to places in your neighborhood?  this friendly bistro is right around the corner from chez moi and I JUST went there for the first time today for lunch and a glass of wine. wonderful mussels and frites.  my lunch date had a delicious beet salad. the tart tartine was delish.  so glad this is in the neighborhood. our server was charming and the patron stopped by to see if we enjoyed everything.  stop by.
author: Angela N.

description: We had 50 people arrive pretty much all at once for the 'day after the wedding breakfast'....Jacques and his staff could not have done a better job at accommating us!  The food was fabulous, the presentation delightful and I think people are raving more about the breakfast than the actual wedding!   Thankfully the day was gorgeous so we could take advantage of the outdoor seating.  Baker St Bistro is a fabulous restaurant for any occasion and I am so glad the staff could be part of my wedding weekend!
author: Marina A.

description: This is an adorable little cafe with such ambiance you would almost go for that alone.  The food and wine list are also excellent and the service is attentive, accomodating, and authentic.  I felt I was being served by people who were truly interested in our having a nice dinner.  Small and cozy ... this place truly reminds me of a Parisian cafe.
author: Jen L.

description:
I want to give this place a better rating because i think the food is pretty good and the service is decent considering it is a french place,  but I found the ambiance/atmosphere really lacking.

It is not anything like a street cafe in Paris. Don't be deceived by the quaint yelp picture with christmas lights and outdoor seating. The restaurant is located on a residential street so there is nothing to see nearby (no people, no other stores, just apts and parked cars). Definitely not the same lively, bustling, people- watching paris street cafe feel. The interior also needs some remodeling. I noticed some of the seat cushions are ripped and the menus don't look very clean. There was also a huge wasp-bee flying around that kept on bothering us until a waiter killed it. Also, I came around 7:30 pm on a Fri night and there was only one other group there. Not sure if it was just a slow night, but it definitely took away from the atmosphere. I did notice more people coming after 8:00 pm, but considering the overall high reviews, i thought this place would be more popular. I think maybe it is more of  a brunch place.
author: chrissie s.

description: Not much to say about this place besides that it is small and cozy, well priced, with classic French country/bistro dishes. Worth going here once in a group and trying all the dishes, but since their menu rarely changes, once is enough. Move on. Try another restaurant (plentiful in SF!).
author: Cary W.

description: Good local restaurant.  I would not drive to go to dinner here but if you live in the hood, it's a good staple.  One downside is that they don't mix up there menu enough.
author: kimberly t.

description: Nothing bad to say - EXCEPT- verify your reservation!  We've been here for dinner twice, and twice we made reservations well in advance only to find that they had no record of our reservations, both times.  Fortunately we were eating at 5:50 and they had room.  Great food, and when we asked the owner to call us a cab he poured us free glasses of port to drink while we waited!
author: Judy M.

description: Since relocating here from LA, I"ve had a difficult time finding a great brunch spot...until I checked out Baker St.  The food and sauces are excellent quality, the service is mellow and the sidewalk dining is reminiscent a a Parisian bistro.  Do yourself a favor and stop by.
author: Robin n.

description: My second visit was last night.  This is a cozy little Bistro off the beaten path of Cow Hollow.  My wife and I both had the Prix Fixe dinner and it was excellent.  1st course was a Cream of Wild Mushroom soup that was outstanding.  Tasty, good portion--could have made a meal of it.  Following that came a little green salad--simple butter lettuce and a light dressing.  The main course was Baby Back Ribs in a tasty sauce with a lentil ragout.  Good portion, tasty, done perfect.  For dessert we had a Bread Pudding in a rum type sauce with strawberries and whipped cream.  The cost of this meal wa $16.50 and it was delicious.  The people next to us ordered from the regular menu and one had a lamb steak and the other a chicken breast.  Both looked good and were generous portions.  Service was very good.  For a neighborhood bistro this is a 5 star place.  We will go again.
author: Wayne E.

description: Consistently good service, dog friendly, good food, reasonable prices. Overall value for money.
author: Peter J.

description: I love the place, found it by accident, has that well worn appearance but the food is good value, the service is very attentive and the cuisine is a mix of genuine authentic French dishes with an American twist. The deserts are to die for.
author: Mandy S.

description: This modest, out-of-the-way Bistro is a real find.  I trek all the way from the East Bay to enjoy its laidback atmosphere and tasty offerings - which come at totally reasonable prices.  On the weekends, when most brunch spots are overrun and have waits of over an hour, BSB seems always to have a table available - and this is not because of poor quality.  I just think it's not that well known or as faddish as other places.  There's outdoor seating to enjoy when the smallish interior gets too crowded.  I always order the bouillabase - subtle, red fishy broth, tender scallops and other goodies, topped with a perfectly toasted slice of baguette and pepper aioli.  The other week, my family and I also tried the risotto for a late brunch - it came speckled with squash, beet, and sundried tomatoes - a perfect summertime dish.  It was delicious - not too mushy or overrun with ingredients.  The fluffy french toast is also an excellent standby.  As for the service, there are several attentive and friendly waiters to assist.  The owner also frequently emerges from the back to shmooze with regulars and newcomers alike. (I did find it strange when he chose to dump along the street a bucketful of dirty washwater just outside his place - bad choice!).  The only drawback I see for this place, besides its somewhat remote location over by the Presidio, is its espresso drinks.  They just aren't that strong or flavorful.  I like my cappuccinos dry and theirs was decidedly weak.  Alas, I will return in spite of that.  Again and again.  Sitting outside, with a mellow breeze and fog blowing over, with its quiet atmosphere, gives me images of being at a lazy brasserie in France.
author: David S.

description: Always a safe bet. Always a great value. Safe place for first dates....
author: Jeff B.

description: Went to Baker Street Bistro on the recommendation of someone who lives in the area. French bistro cuisine is one of my favorites, so on my birthday, my wife, daughter and I had to give it a try. At best it was just okay. The ambiance and decor are warm and inviting. The service is friendly and sharp. Our only complaint is the food wasn't so great. I started with the salad with smoked duck, duck gizzard and foie gras. The smoked duck had no smoke flavor, the gizzard was like jerky, but the foie gras was good. The "Julia Child" beef bourginon was salty, the beef was dried out and the sauce lacked complexity. Simply one note flavor like canned stew but WAY saltier than canned. My wife's duck a l'orange was very good. It was served with polenta cakes and she does not like polenta. She asked if she could substitute any other sort of starch and it was made clear that there are "no substitutions" as stated at the bottom of the menu. These days, I would think restaurants would be a little more accommodating with a SIMPLE request like a side starch substitution. My daughter's steak was just that, a steak with fries and a small side of vinaigrette salad. Nothing special. Sad to say, but "you can get that anywhere". We did not partake of the desserts. We frequent Chouchou in the forest hill neighborhood and can say that, by comparison, there is no comparison.  Chouchou is our favorite.  We will probably still return to Baker Street Bistro for another try in the summer for some outdoor sidewalk dining.  We always give it a couple of trys.
author: Andrew L.

description: Again I think I have been transported to Paris.  This charming tiny restaurant is a find and worth driving clear across the City in the rain to  get to it which we had to do.  This is the second time we have been there and it was just as delightful but even more so because we had the prix  fixe menu.  I thought I was reading the menu wrong when it said $16.50 for a four course dinner.  I read it again and yes it was true from I think 5:30 to 7:00, I am not sure of the days but we were their on a Friday night at 6:30 so it worked for us.  The spinach soup was delicious and not just a cup of it but a bowl.  A lightly dressed salad accompanied the delicious boned trout in a nice butter sauce with sliced almonds and rice.  This was then followed by dessert which I assumed would be a dish of ice cream considering the price of the dinner and the full size servings of each course.  But to my happy amazement the dessert was a wonderful brownie like cake garnished with a strawberry and resting on a delightful sauce.  Some of the entrees go for about $18.00 which is still reasonable  but then when you think a four course for $16.50 it is unbelievable.  And to top all that off the waiters are nice, efficient and unassuming.  I much prefer this restaurant to one that charges high prices, gives attitude and bad service and then dismal food .  I can hardly wait to go again and pretend I am in Paris at a fabulous  little charming restaurant that I was so lucky to find.
author: Sally F.
